At this a soldier came up to him and said, ‘Why do you make such a noise?’ ‘Because,’ said the donkey, ‘I am a musician, and am making ready to begin.’ ‘Can you play at anything in particular?’ asked the soldier. ‘Oh, yes!’ said the donkey, ‘I can play at everything that is played on the fiddle.’ ‘Then come with me,’ said the soldier, ‘and let us try that.’ So he took the donkey to an inn, and went in and asked the landlord if he had any fiddle. The landlord said, ‘No,’ he had not, but he would soon get one. Then the soldier took the donkey out again, and sat on a bench with him, and said, ‘Now, then, let us hear what you can do.’ ‘Wait,’ said the donkey, ‘until I have rested myself a little, I have journeyed a long way.’ When he had rested himself, the soldier again said, ‘Now, then, let us hear something.’ ‘Will not Mr Mayor come out here for a moment?’ said the donkey. The soldier sent someone to fetch the Mayor, and he soon came. ‘Why do you desire my presence, soldier?’ said he. ‘Because,’ said the soldier, ‘I have a musician here who wants to play to me, and I want to hear what he can do.’ ‘Is that all?’ said the Mayor. ‘I too am fond of music, so if the donkey can please the soldier, he will please me also.’ Then the donkey said, ‘Will not the sexton come and witness the performance?’ The sexton was sent for, and he came. ‘What is all this about?’ said he. ‘The soldier is going to have the donkey play to him, and as he does it so well for the soldier, he will do it for me also.’ ‘If the sexton is to be there,’ said the donkey, ‘I had better take a little walk first, or my lungs will not be cool enough.’ Then the three waited till he had taken his walk, and had cooled himself sufficiently. ‘Now, donkey,’ said the soldier, ‘come out and begin.’ ‘Just wait a little,’ said the donkey, ‘until I have put on my cloak,’ and he began to look for it. The soldier waited till he had looked for it for some time, and then said, ‘Donkey, why do you make yourself so important? Begin at once.’ ‘Now, then,’ said the donkey, and he began to bray. ‘That is well done,’ said the soldier. ‘Yes,’ said the Mayor, ‘that is well done.’ ‘Yes,’ said the sexton, ‘that is well done.’ ‘I too am pleased,’ said the cook, and came up. ‘What is going on here?’ said he. ‘The donkey is beginning his concert,’ said the soldier. ‘Is that you, rogue?’ said the

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor old woman who lived in a little cottage in the
woods. She had neither money, nor friends, nor relations in the world,
and was very unhappy. ‘What is the use of living,’ said she, ‘when one
has nothing to look forward to but misery and wretchedness?’ So she
decided to end her troubles by putting an end to herself.

She went out into the wood to find a suitable place, and when she had
walked a long way, she sat herself down under a tree, took out a
little knife, and was just going to make the cut, when she happened to
look up and see a little dwarf standing by her side.

‘Bless me!’ said the old woman, ‘who are you?’ ‘I am the little dwarf
of the wood,’ answered he; ‘why do you look so sad and woe-begone?’
‘Because I am so unhappy, and have nothing left to live for.’ ‘What
makes you so unhappy?’ ‘Poverty,’ said the old woman. ‘How do you manage
to live?’ ‘I gather wood and sell it; but what I get for it is not
enough to buy food with.’ ‘How many logs do you sell?’ ‘Seven,’ replied
the old woman. ‘Bring me seven logs tomorrow, and I will give you seven
talers for them.’ ‘Where will you take them to?’ said the old woman.
‘To my house.’ ‘If you will do as I say, I shall be very glad to have
your custom.’ Then the dwarf took the old woman home with him, and
treated her very kindly, and gave her a large room to live in, and as
much to eat as she could wish for.

The next day the dwarf went into his own country, and the old woman
had no one to buy her wood, so she did not know what to do, and was
very much worried. At last she cut down a young tree, and sat herself
down amongst the stumps and cried. Now, as she was sitting there,
another dwarf came up to her, and asked what was the matter. ‘Oh!’ said
the old woman, ‘I am so unhappy; I have no one to buy my wood, and I
know not what will become of me.’ ‘What do you want to sell wood for?’
said the dwarf. ‘Why, to buy food with.’ ‘How much do you ask for seven
logs?’ ‘Full price,’ answered the old woman. ‘I will give you full
price,’ said the dwarf; ‘but you must bring the wood to my house.’
‘Where does that come?’ ‘In the town.’ ‘How far is it?’ ‘A good hour’s
walk.’ So the old woman carried her wood to the town, and the dwarf
gave her full price for it, and then went back to his own country,
and the old woman was left again without anyone to buy her wood.

Then she cut down another tree, and sat down and cried over it as she
had done before, when on a sudden two dwarfs came up to her, and asked
what she was crying for. ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I am so unhappy, for I have
no one to buy my wood, and I know not what will become of me.’ ‘What
do you want to sell wood for?’ said the dwarfs. ‘To buy food with.’ ‘How
much do you ask for seven logs?’ ‘Full price.’ ‘We will give it you,
but you must bring the wood to our house.’ ‘Where does that come?’
‘In the town.’ ‘How far is it?’ ‘A good hour’s walk.’ So the old woman
carried her wood to the town, and the two dwarfs paid her what she
asked, and then went back to their country, and the poor woman was
once more left to shift for herself.

Then she cut down a third tree, and sat down and cried over it as before,
when a merchant came by, and asked what she was doing. ‘Alas!’ said she,
‘I am so unhappy, for I have no one to buy my wood, and I know not what
will become of me.’ ‘What do you want to sell wood for?’ said the
merchant. ‘To buy food with.’ ‘How much do you ask for seven logs?’ ‘Full
price.’ ‘I will give it you,’ said the merchant; ‘but you must bring the
wood to my house.’ ‘Where does that come?’ ‘In the town.’ ‘How far is
it?’ ‘A good hour’s walk.’ So the old woman took her wood to the town,
and the merchant paid her what she asked, and then went his way, and
the poor woman was once more forsaken.

Then she cut down a fourth tree, and cried over it as she had done the
three others, when a huntsman came by, and asked what was the matter.
‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I am so unhappy, for I have no one to buy my wood,
and I know not what will become of me.’ ‘What do you want to sell wood
for?’ said the huntsman. ‘To buy food with.’ ‘How much do you ask for
seven logs?’ ‘Full price.’ ‘I will give it you,’ said the huntsman; ‘but
you must bring the wood to my house.’ ‘Where does that come?’ ‘In the
town.’ ‘How far is it?’ ‘A good hour’s walk.’ So the old woman took
her wood to the town, and the huntsman paid her what she asked, and
then went his way, and the poor woman was once more forsaken.

Then she cut down a fifth tree, and cried over it as before, when a
soldier came by, and asked what was the matter. ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I am
so unhappy, for I have no one to buy my wood, and I know not what will
become of me.’ ‘What do you want to sell wood for?’ said the soldier.
‘To buy food with.’ ‘How much do you ask for seven logs?’ ‘Full price.’
‘I will give it you,’ said the soldier; ‘but you must bring the wood to
my barracks.’ ‘Where does that come?’ ‘In the town.’ ‘How far is it?’
‘A good hour’s walk.’ So the old woman took her wood to the town, and
the soldier paid her what she asked, and then went his way, and the
poor woman was once more forsaken.

Then she cut down a sixth tree, and cried over it as before, when a
fisher came by, and asked what was the matter. ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I am
so unhappy, for I have no one to buy my wood, and I know not what will
become of me.’ ‘What do you want to sell wood for?’ said the fisher.
‘To buy food with.’ ‘How much do you ask for seven logs?’ ‘Full price.’
‘I will give it you,’ said the fisher; ‘but you must bring the wood to
my house.’ ‘Where does that come?’ ‘In the town.’ ‘How far is it?’
‘A good hour’s walk.’ So the old woman took her wood to the town, and
the fisher paid her what she asked, and then went his way, and the
poor woman was once more forsaken.

Then she cut down a seventh tree, and cried over it as before, when a
parliament of dwarfs came up to her, and asked what was the matter.
‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I am so unhappy, for I have no one to buy my wood,
and I know not what will become of me.’ ‘What do you want to sell wood
for?’ said the dwarfs. ‘To buy food with.’ ‘

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a king who had a beautiful garden full of all kinds of fine
flowers, and in the middle stood a large tree. It was so old that one of
its branches touched the sky. Every morning the king’s daughter went
there to take her walk, and when she had done, she always plucked herself
one flower from the garden, and one from the tree, and took them with her
in her lap to her father’s palace.

It happened one day that she plucked a flower from the tree as usual, but
as she was hurrying away with it, the stalk broke, and the flower fell
back into the garden. Then the tree cried out:

 ‘Wait, princess! wait! give me a reason
  Why the cherry tree, so gay and fine,
  Stands here alone, and is not adorned
  With one of thy flowers, so bright and rine!’

 ‘Bless me!’ said the princess, ‘how the
  tree can speak!’ But she went on still
  Hurrying to the palace. The next day
  She took care to bring the tree a flower
  In addition to one from the garden.
  And so it went on for some time: the
  King’s daughter always took two flowers
  Every day, one from the garden and
  One from the tree.

It happened that the princess did not come to the garden one day, but
the tree cried out as usual for its flower. Then a little old woman came
from out of the greenwood, and she plucked a flower for the tree, and said
as she did so: ‘Lady, you shall have a son who will cut off your head.’

The next morning the princess had a son, and seven days after she had a
daughter. Seven days after that, the old woman’s prophecy came true, and
she died. The king ordered the garden to be locked up, and no one was
allowed to go there any more.

The prince grew up, and the princess died, and the king likewise. Then
the prince inherited his father’s kingdom, and he and the princess’s
daughter inherited the garden. They cut down the old tree, for they did
not know that in its roots lived an old enemy, who cried out with a loud
voice: ‘Ah, false treel False tree!’ Three times he cried so, and then all
his strength was gone, and he died.

The prince and the princess’s daughter lived together very happily for a
while; but the princess’s daughter was very beautiful, and it happened
that many suitors came and asked her to marry them. At last one of them
said: ‘I will give you as many roses as there are stars in the sky, if
you will marry me.’ She answered: ‘I will do it, if it can be done.’ Then
the prince said: ‘It cannot be done, for there are so many stars that no
man can count them.’ The princess’s daughter said: ‘I will soon find out,
for I will go up into the heavens at midnight, and see for myself how
many stars there are.’

Then the prince was very sorrowful, and went down into his garden, and
kneeled before a little brook which ran through it, and prayed: ‘If it be
well for me that my dear sister should go into the heavens, that she may
count the stars, then show me some way to go with her.’ And as he prayed,
a little dwarf came out of the brook, and said: ‘True and faithful shall
I be unto thee; go into the garden, and cut down the old tree which is in
the corner, and out of the trunk shalt thou make a bow, and out of the
three largest roots nine arrows; and when thou drawest the bow, and shootest
the arrows, they shall be true and faithful, and carry thee through the
air wherever thou wilt.’

Then the prince did as the dwarf bade him, and took the bow and the nine
arrows, and went to his sister, and said: ‘I will go with you into the
heavens.’ But she said: ‘Alas! how can that be?’ He answered: ‘I have made
a bow and nine arrows, and when I draw the bow and shoot the arrows, we
shall be carried through the air wherever we will.’

Then she said: ‘If that be so, I will go with thee.’ So they went out
together, and he shot the first arrow up into the heavens, and they were
carried through the air upon a cloud as fast as the arrow went. And the
prince drew the bow again, and shot the second arrow, and they were carried
faster still; and so they went on, shooting the eight other arrows one
after another, until the bow was tired, and would draw no more.

Then the prince looked around him, and saw that the whole firmament was
covered with stars, and that his sister was not among them. So he drew the
bow again, and shot another arrow, and prayed that the arrow might carry
them to the moon, that his sister might count the stars upon it. So the
prince and the princess were carried to the moon, and landed on the top of
it, and there they found a garden full of roses, and in the middle stood
a bed that was even larger than the garden from which his mother had plucked
the first flower. Then the princess looked around at all the roses, and
said: ‘I can count these in one day.’

But the prince said: ‘I will run round to the end of the garden, and then
you shall begin to count.’ So he ran to the end of the garden, and it was
so large that he could not run round to the end of it in any time, but
stood still and waited for his sister, that she might begin to count. But
she said: ‘There are so many roses, that I cannot tell where to begin.’
Then the prince said: ‘Take one of the roses in your lap, and begin to
count from that.’ So she took one of the roses, and sat down and began to
count, but she had not counted up to seven before she found that she had
already taken the entire crop of roses from the bed in which they grew,
and laid them in her lap. And she said: ‘I cannot go home with these, for
they are so many that I cannot carry them.’

Then the prince shot another arrow from his bow, and the arrow flew to
the sun, and they were carried in the chariot of the sun through the
air to the earth, and landed in the garden from which the first flower
had been plucked. There stood the old garden full of flowers, and in the
middle stood the tree where the old enemy had died. And the princess
looked around at all the flowers, and said: ‘I will take with me one of
every kind of flower that grows here, and then I shall be able to go home
with them.’

Then the prince said: ‘Take as many as you will, but I must have one
more look round the garden.’ And as he looked round, he saw a beautiful
flower which he had not seen before, lying among the grass at the root
of the tree. So he bent down and plucked it, and took it with him.

Then the princess gathered together all the flowers, and laid them in
a heap, so that there was not one left in the whole garden. And she said
as she did so: ‘I can carry these home upon my lap, and then I shall have
enough to take with me.’ But the heap of flowers became smaller and
smaller, and at last there was not one flower left in the whole garden,
and the princess had nothing to take home with her.

Then the prince shot the last arrow out of his bow, and they were carried
back to the moon again, and landed in the same place where they had been
before. And the princess said: ‘

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor wood-cutter, who had one horse that could no longer work, and had therefore given it to some use to a butcher to be killed. When the wood-cutter went up to the town to settle the account, he took his little daughter with him. Now it chanced that the butcher wanted to try how the creature was cut up, and asked the wood-cutter whether he would like to go into the room and see how the horse was getting on. ‘Oh, yes,’ answered the man, ‘I should like to see it,’ and followed the butcher. When the butcher saw that the man was not at all affected by what he saw, he thought to himself that the horse must have been of little use for work, and cut up the animal without delay. But when the little girl was led outside again, she wept and wept over the blood that was flowing from the horse, and her tears flowed so plentifully that the butcher became uneasy, for he thought: ‘The little wretch will certainly cry herself to death.’ So he ordered the horse to be buried, and paid the father the price of the beast, and gave him something over and above into the bargain.

The little girl, however, did not comfort herself for the death of her beloved horse, and when she was left alone she would sit by the grave and weep. ‘Dear Bummel,’ she would say, ‘how could you let them kill you? You might have run away like the other horses.’ Then she would tell her dead friend all her sorrows, and as she lived in the outskirts of the town, there was no one to hinder her, and her father and mother were so poor that they could not provide her with a maid to keep her company.

One evening, as she sat by the grave, something suddenly caught her little finger in the dark, and she felt a coldness run down her arm. She drew her hand back hastily, and when she looked round saw a white horse standing at the grave. ‘Bummel!’ she cried, ‘is that you? Have you forsaken the grave? I am so glad to see you again!’ ‘Yes,’ answered the horse, ‘it is I. When you wept so bitterly for me, your tears fell into my grave, and as you so often came there and grieved for me, I have come back to you. But as you are still so young and small, I will grant you one wish. You must, however, make it quickly, for the cock will soon crow, and then I shall vanish again.’

The little girl was so overjoyed that she did not know what she should wish for, and at first she could think of nothing but her horse. ‘Then I wish,’ she said at last, ‘that Bummel might have a golden bridle with a collar of shining pearls.’ ‘Your wish is granted,’ said the horse, and as the wood-cutter and his wife were standing nearby, selling their wares, the man looked up and saw a horse standing in the middle of the town, with a golden bridle and a collar of shining pearls. ‘I should like to have that horse,’ said he to the woman, ‘but I have not so much money.’ ‘Just go up to the man,’ said the little girl, ‘and tell him that you will give him twice the price of the horse if he will wait for the gold I am to have from my wish.’ The wood-cutter did as his daughter bade him, and the butcher said: ‘I will wait for the gold,’ and the man paid him what the horse was worth, and took the beast home with him.

The next morning, the little girl went out to the horse, and said: ‘Bummel, now that you are so beautiful, the coachman will come and take you away, and I shall never see you again. I will therefore wish for a second thing. Think, and then I will make my wish.’ ‘Take your time,’ said the horse, ‘and think well of what you wish, for the cock will soon crow.’

The little girl thought for a long time, and at last said: ‘I wish that every year on New Year’s Eve, a piece of gold would come to us, as big as a man’s head.’ ‘Your wish is granted,’ said the horse, and before New Year’s Eve the wood-cutter had a large piece of gold standing in the corner, as big as a man’s head.

When New Year’s Eve came round, the wood-cutter and his wife were overjoyed, and said: ‘Our child is a true fairy, to be able to bring us that great piece of gold.’ And they thought: ‘If every year a piece of gold comes as big as a man’s head, we shall be rich some day.’

The little girl went out to the horse, and said: ‘Bummel, now I have my wish, and have you not any more power?’ ‘Yes,’ answered the horse, ‘but you must think well of something before the cock crows.’

The little girl thought for a long time, and at last said: ‘I wish that I might become a beautiful princess, and that a prince should come, who would take me for his wife, and love me as dearly as ever a man did a woman.’ ‘Your wish is granted,’ said the horse, and before the cock had crowed, the little wood-cutter’s girl was a beautiful princess, and a prince came, who took her for his wife, and loved her as dearly as ever a man did a woman.

The horse said to her: ‘Now you must go, for the cock is crowing, and I must go into the earth again.’ ‘Goodbye, Bummel,’ said the princess, ‘I shall never forget you.’ ‘I too,’ said the horse, ‘will never forget you, and as you have been so kind to me, I will grant you one more wish.’ ‘I have no wish to make,’ answered the princess, and went into the palace with the prince.

The horse went into the earth again, and the princess had a beautiful marble horse with a golden bridle and a collar of shining pearls, which still stands in the palace to this day, and sometimes at midnight, when the moon shines on it, it becomes alive and frisky, and anyone who then looks at it may wish for one thing, but he or she must think of it quickly, for the cock will soon crow.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
Once upon a time there was a king who had twelve beautiful daughters. They slept in twelve beds all in one room, and every morning before daybreak they rose up and did their work. Now it chanced that the king had a daughter who was fairer than all the others, and she lay in a bed by herself in a chamber on the top of the house; and when she arose in the morning, she went down a narrow staircase.

One morning, as the king was sitting in his hall, a feeling of uneasiness came over him, and he said to his court, ‘I should willingly see all my daughters this morning, that I may know whether they are all safe.’ Then the twelve servants went up one after another, and brought down the twelve princesses, but the twelfth came down alone. ‘It is well,’ said the king, ‘that I have seen you all, for I felt as if my heart was heavy within me.’

When the twelfth princess was gone, the king’s sense of uneasiness left him, and he forgot all about it; but the princess felt quite grateful to him for his care, and she took to heart his wish to know that she was safe, and was grieved to think that she should have been the twelfth, and that he had felt uneasy till he had seen her. So she arose very early the next morning, long before it was day, and went to her father, and kissed his hand, and said, ‘I am so grateful to you for your care, that I will never sleep in my bed any more, but will lie on the staircase below my chamber, that you may always see me as you passes up to your chair in the morning.’ Then the king was very glad, and said she should do as she pleased.

So the princess slept on the staircase, and in the morning the king saw her as he went to his chair.

Now it happened that the king held a great feast, and asked thither a nobleman who was a great sorcerer. And when the princess went down to the hall, the sorcerer looked at her and said, ‘You are the most beautiful of all the king’s daughters, but you must dance with me this evening, and you alone.’ Then she promised, and in the evening when the time came she danced with him. And he took her aside, and said, ‘Tell me true, where do you sleep?’ ‘On the staircase,’ said she. Then he said, ‘When you lie down there tonight, twelve men and women will come and carry you away from thence, and if I do not get you again by daybreak, you will never see your father’s palace any more.’

The sorcerer kept his word, and when she lay down that night, twelve men and women came and lifted her up, and carried her away. And they took her to a mill, and washed her with boiling water, that she might be held fast, but it did her no harm. Then they set her to grinding at the mill, and said, ‘You must work, and not stop until you are quite tired.’

But the princess ground at the mill until her heart was light within her, for she knew that daybreak was near, and that she should soon be free. And sure enough, before it was day, she sprang up from the mill, and went out, and the doors flew open, and she walked away quite at her ease.

She walked by a forest, and as she was very hungry she sat herself down under a tree and ate some of the berries. And as she was eating, a little old woman came up to her, and said, ‘Why do you eat the berries, pretty child?’ ‘Because I am very hungry,’ answered she. ‘If that be the case,’ said the little old woman, ‘come with me, and you shall fare well.’ Then she took her by the hand, and led her through the forest, and at last brought her to a little house.

There were twelve old women sitting in the parlour, all with long grey hair and shrivelled faces; but they rose up and welcomed her, and said, ‘Our sister has been a long time coming, and we thought she had forgotten us.’ Then they took her to a little bed, and she slept till it was noon.

When she awoke, they gave her food, and after she had eaten they said, ‘Tell us, pretty child, how it happened that you came here.’ So she told them all her story, how the sorcerer had carried her away, and how she had escaped by daybreak.

‘Well,’ said they, ‘now that you are with us, you must work hard, and do all the housekeeping; for we are spinners, and our work never ends. You must get ready the food, and wash the dishes, and do all the work of the house.’

Then she did all they told her, and worked hard, till her fingers bled, and at night she was so tired that she fell asleep.

The next morning, as day was breaking, she went to the door, and it flew wide open, and she walked out quite at her ease. Then she went on through the forest, and by noon she reached a great city, and passed through the streets till she came to the sea. And there stood a ship with black sails, and the sailors were making ready to sail. ‘What a beautiful ship,’ she said to herself, ‘if I could only get on board of her I should be happy.’

So she went to the captain, and said, ‘I will give you my ring as a gift, if you will let me go with you.’ Then he looked at her, and said, ‘You are very pretty, but what is there in your ring that it should be worth so much?’ ‘I will not tell you that,’ she answered, ‘unless you take me with you.’ Then the captain saw that she was bent on having her own way, and said, ‘Very well, I will let you go with us, for the sake of your ring.’

Then he showed her to the other sailors, and they all came to gaze at her; and she told them how she had been used, and how she had escaped.

When they came to the next town the captain said to her, ‘I have kept my word, and have brought you safely with me, so now you must tell me what the secret of your ring is.’ Then she said, ‘I will tell you if you will take me to my father’s country.’ ‘Where does your father live?’ asked he. ‘Far, far away,’ answered she. ‘How shall we find the way?’ ‘I will hold up my hand, and when it is quite full of stars, you must steer straight on, and you cannot go amiss.’

So they sailed on, and one night her hand was full of stars, and the captain steered straight on as she told him, and by daybreak they came to the country. Then she said, ‘I will go ashore alone, and you must stay here till I come back, and then you shall have your reward.’ So she jumped ashore, and the ship stood still.

She walked on through the forest till she came to the mill, and went in and said, ‘Open the doors, for it is I.’ Then the mill sprang open, and she went on to the king’s palace, and the doors flew open too, and all her brothers and sisters came running to meet her.

She told them all her adventures, and how she had been to the little old women, and how she had sailed away over the sea, and had come back to her own country again.

And now she went to her father, and told him all that had happened, and he was very glad to see her, for he thought he should never have her again. Then the sailors came home, and brought the ship safe into port, and the captain showed the king the beautiful ring which he had got as his reward.

And the king held a great feast, and gave his daughter to the nobleman who was a great sorcerer to wife, as he had before been willing to do; and the wedding was celebrated with great pomp and pleasure, and they lived together very happily

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a forester who had a faithful and diligent servant, called
Karl, who had been with him many years. The forester had a good deal of
money laid by, but had no child to be his heir, and as Karl had behaved
well, he thought he would make him his heir, and said to him one day, ‘I
am very glad to have you, and will always take care of you; but I have
something to tell you now which will make you very happy. I have long
looked upon you as a son, and as I have neither child nor brother, I will
make you my sole heir.’ Karl rejoiced at his master’s kindness, but said
nothing, and seemed very much affected.

Some time after, the forester sent Karl to the town to bring away a
casket which was to be his reward. Karl did as he was told, but when he
came back and was going to give his master the key of the casket, he
found that it was locked, and that there was no key. He was very much
grieved, and did not know what to do, for he saw that his master would
be very angry. At last he thought of a little black boy who lived in the
village, who had once told him that he could find out all secrets, and
could open and shut with a key any casket or box, however hard it might
be. So he took the casket and went to the boy, who soon opened it, and
when Karl looked inside he found it was full of gold. Then he was very
glad, and took the casket to his master.

The forester was well pleased, and said, ‘Now, Karl, you shall have
all that is in the casket, and I will make you my heir.’ ‘Lord and Master,
I will never take a penny of your money,’ said Karl; ‘I am very grateful
to you for what you have done for me already, but I would rather die
than take so great a fortune.’ ‘Nonsense!’ said the forester, ‘you shall
take it, and I will have it as well as given. Sit yourself there on
the bench, and think about it, and don’t go away till you have made up
your mind.’

Karl sat down, but he could think of nothing else all day long, and the
next day he was just the same. At last on the third day, when he thought
he should go mad for thinking, he went to his master, and said, ‘Lord
and Master, as you love me, and as I am so sorry to part with you, I will
go away into the wide world, and if I live I will never come back.’ ‘Well,
Karl,’ said the forester, ‘if that is what you wish, go, but before you
go I will give you a piece of advice. Take care of yourself, and mind and
trust no one.’ ‘I will do all that, lord and master,’ said Karl.

Then the forester gave him a loaf of bread, a piece of bacon, a knife, a
fowling-piece, and a bag, and said, ‘Take that with you, and travel on
till you come to a great wood; in the middle of the wood there is a house
where lives an old woman. Go to her, and let nothing she may say or do
dismay you. If you will do what she tells you, you will fare well.’

Karl thanked his master once more, and then set out, and when he came
to the great wood, he went into the middle of it, and there, just as his
master had told him, he saw the old woman’s house. As he was very hungry
he went in and said, ‘I am very hungry, do pray give me something to eat.’
‘What will you have?’ said the old woman. ‘I have a hen that has just
laid an egg, and I will give it you fried.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said
Karl, ‘that will be very nice.’ So she killed the hen, and fried it with
the egg, and when it was ready she said, ‘Now, Karl, as you like fowls
so well, will you not go and look out for some for me? There is a great
flock of them close by, but they are very hard to catch, for they never
keep still, and fly about from tree to tree.’ ‘I will soon find a way to
tame them,’ said Karl, ‘and then it will be an easy thing to catch them.’

Then the old woman led him into the wood, and showed him the flock of
hens, and as they were flying about, Karl fired into them with his
fowling-piece, and killed one. ‘Now,’ said he, ‘take up that hen, and tie
her legs and wings together, and hang her up in a tree, and tomorrow morning
before daylight tie the other hens close to her, and then they will think
that she is still flying about, and will not dare to stir.’

The old woman did as he told her, and next morning before daylight Karl
took them all and brought them to her house, where he killed and dressed
them, and then said, ‘Now, old woman, you must keep what you have
promised me.’ ‘What is that?’ said she. ‘Why,’ said he, ‘you must give
me a bed to lie on, and some to eat and drink.’ ‘Very well,’ said the
old woman, ‘but who will give you that?’ ‘You must,’ answered Karl.

Then the old woman fetched him a bed, and some bread and cheese to eat,
and a flask of wine, and said, ‘There, now be off, I have done all I could
for you.’ ‘One more thing,’ said Karl, ‘before you go, tell me where the
treasure is that is hidden in the wood.’ ‘What treasure?’ said the old
woman. ‘Why, the one that my master told me of when I went away from
him.’ ‘Ah!’ said the old woman, ‘you would not have that, would you?
You must work for that. Go out tomorrow very early, and you will see
three old men coming into the wood. Let them come up to you, and then
shoot at them with your fowling-piece, and as they will want to run away,
run after them, and bind them fast, and when you have bound all three,
go to their prison, and in the twelfth box that you find there, you
will see the treasure you want so much.’

Karl did as the old woman told him, and when he had bound the three old
men and got the treasure, he thought he should be very glad to have it,
and went back to the old woman. ‘Now, old woman, have you anything more
to say to me?’ said he. ‘Nothing at all,’ answered she, ‘but as you are
so clever, and have done everything I told you, you shall have something
more. You see that there is a great hill behind my house; go up to the top
of it, and in the middle of it you will find a millstone. Bring that
away, and you will find a little house close by, where lives an old woman
with a black cat. Go in and give her the millstone, and she will give
you a piece of bread and cheese, and a flask of wine, and will tell you
where the gold and silver mountain is, which you want so much.’

Karl did as she told him, and when he came back she said, ‘Now, Karl,
you have done all I could ask or wish, and as you have been so clever,
you shall have one more piece of advice. Go out early tomorrow morning,
and you will see three men coming into the wood. Let them come up to you,
and then shoot at them with your fowling-piece, and

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Snow Queen

In a land that was half rock and half forest, there lived a poor old woman. She was so poor that she could not even afford glass for her windows, so she cut out little squares of mica instead.

One day, when the snow had fallen deep, she was clearing her cottage before the fire, when a dazzlingly beautiful child came in. It was the Snow Queen, and she had come to visit the earth. She walked on the snow without leaving a track behind her, and her clothes and hair were like the snow itself.

She looked around at the poor cottage, and then she laughed, for she saw how very poor the old woman was. ‘Pray, old woman, give me some of your fire,’ said she. ‘Nay,’ answered the old woman, ‘it will burn you.’ ‘Just a little,’ said the Snow Queen. The old woman was afraid, and took care not to give her any fire, but only blew the ashes and smoke in her face. Then the Snow Queen went away, but she took a shard of ice and threw it at the old woman, so that it cut her right in the eye. So the old woman’s eye became dim and she could hardly see, and when the Snow Queen had gone away, she thought her loss was greater than her own, and cried out: ‘Ah, how sad it is that such a beautiful child should be so cruel!’

The next morning, as the little boy, whose name was Kai, came home from school, the old woman met him, and when she saw him she was very sad, and her voice trembled as she said: ‘Ah, Kai, do you not remember me? I am your grandmother. I am very glad to see you, but I am in trouble. I have been sitting here all night with a burning fire, and yet I scarcely see you for the smoke. And yet how beautiful the world looks in winter! How the snow glitters! How the trees and the rooftops shine!’ ‘Grandmother,’ said Kai, ‘how can it look beautiful when you say so? It is only a dirty, drab, grey-brown frost and ice. I like fine weather much better.’

‘Come in, come in,’ said the old woman, ‘and look in the glass, I will show you how the world looks.’ Then she led him to the window, and took him by the hand, and put it into the cold pane, and said: ‘Now look at the world through this.’ And when Kai looked through it, he cried out: ‘Oh, Grandmother, how beautiful the world is! How the sun shines! How the trees and the rooftops sparkle! And there in the distance lies a birch-wood, and behind it stands the most beautiful child I ever saw. Grandmother, let me go out and look at the world.’ ‘Never, never,’ said the old woman. ‘It is the Snow Queen, and she is cruel. She has hurt my eye with a shard of ice.’ ‘But, Grandmother,’ said Kai, ‘she must be very beautiful, for I have never seen anything so beautiful. I must go and see her.’ ‘You will forget me, Kai,’ said the old woman. ‘No,’ said Kai, ‘I will always come back and see you.’

Then he ran away, and the next morning set out on his journey. He walked and walked till he came to the birch-wood, and then he went in, and walked on till he came to the end of it. There the Snow Queen was sitting on her throne, in the very rays of the sun. ‘Greetings, Kai,’ said she. ‘Why have you come?’ ‘Because I saw you through the pane of mica, and thought you were beautiful.’ ‘Then come up here by my side,’ said the Snow Queen. So Kai stepped up on to the spot where she sat, and it was as if he had set his foot upon marble, for it was as hard as rock. ‘Do you see the world down there?’ said the Snow Queen. ‘Yes,’ answered Kai. ‘How small and insignificant everything looks!’ ‘Yes,’ said the Snow Queen, ‘and you, too, are quite insignificant, and have no understanding at all.’ Then she took a dart of ice and threw it in his heart. It is said that this dart pierced him through and through, and that he felt no pain, but only that everything was frozen, so that his heart became hard as ice.

Then the Snow Queen rose up and went away, and took Kai with her. She flew over the sea, and Kai did not die, but sat in her lap, and was changed into a living snow-man. His hair became like white wool, and his eyes were like two pieces of coal, but his heart remained hard as ice.

The news of Kai’s departure reached the old woman, and she wept and tore her hair, and cried: ‘O Heaven, what shall I do?’ Then her sister, who lived in the next village, came to see her, and said: ‘Why do you weep, sister? What is the matter?’ ‘Ah,’ answered the old woman, ‘my grandson Kai has been taken away by the Snow Queen.’ ‘What!’ said the sister. ‘Ought not I to go and help you?’ ‘Yes, indeed,’ answered the old woman. ‘Take my sledge, and my whip, and my clothes, for I see no hope of his return.’

Then the sister harnessed herself to the sledge, and the old woman gave her a lump of coal for the cold, and said: ‘Take care of yourself, I am afraid of the Snow Queen.’ So off she went, over the fields, over the marshes, over the heath, over the mountains, till she came to the sea. There stood a shipman by the shore, and she asked him if he would row her over to the Sea-King’s palace, which lay on an island in the middle of the sea. ‘For how much will you do it?’ asked the sister. ‘For your clothes,’ answered the shipman. ‘Very well,’ said she; ‘but promise to row me back again after I have found Kai.’ Then she took off her clothes and gave them to the shipman, and jumped into the boat, and he rowed her over to the island.

There was a great hall in the Sea-King’s palace, and around it were seven rows of seats, filled with all sorts of fish. ‘Pray, whose are these seats?’ asked the sister. ‘The first are for the greatest fishes in the sea,’ said the Sea-King. ‘And the next for the next greatest?’ ‘Yes.’ ‘And the next for the next?’ ‘Yes.’ ‘And the next for the next?’ ‘Yes.’ ‘And the smallest for the smallest?’ ‘Yes.’ ‘And where do you sit?’ ‘I sit on the throne.’ ‘And where does the Snow Queen sit?’ ‘In the rays of the sun.’

Then the sister asked if he knew where Kai was. ‘I do,’ said he; ‘he is with the Snow Queen, and she sits in the rays of the sun.’ ‘Have you seen a sister of mine?’ asked the sister. ‘Yes,’ answered the Sea-King, ‘she is sitting in the first row, next to the biggest fish in the sea.’ ‘Then will you let me have a boat and some oars?’ said the sister. ‘Yes,’ answered the Sea-King; ‘but promise to return by ten o’clock, or the tide will catch you.’

So the sister rowed to the shore, and went on through the birch-wood, till she came to the Snow Queen’s palace. The doors stood wide open, and she saw Kai sitting inside, and he was like a living snow-man. His hair had become like white wool, and his eyes like two pieces of coal, but his heart was hard as ice. Then she took the lump of coal and threw it at him, and cried:

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a miller who had one beautiful daughter. And this miller was so
overjoyed at the thought of her, that he thought of nothing else day or night,
but how she should be well married and provided for. So he went one day to
the king, and begged that he would give him a husband for his daughter. ‘Yes,’
said the king, ‘if the youth be rich, and in high favour with me, I will give
him to her.’ Then the miller promised that he would soon find some one who
would suit him.

The miller went out of the king’s presence, and by the side of a river saw
seven little frogs sitting together. ‘What are you doing here?’ asked the
miller. ‘We are all sisters and brothers,’ said the frogs, ‘and have lost our
father, and do not know where our mother is; we have run away from home, and
are roaming about the world, and do not know where to go. Our father was a
king, and ruled over a wide country; but our brother, who was next in blood
to the throne, was very wicked, and wanted to kill us all, for we were much
younger than he was, and could not defend ourselves. Our father, however,
took us and ran away; but he was overtaken, and killed by a huntsman, and we
are now very unhappy, and do not know where to go.’

‘How do you contrive to live?’ asked the miller. ‘We find a pond or stream
where there is any water, and beg a few penn’orth of cracknels or bread, and
then we live upon them. But who are you?’

‘I am a poor miller, and want to marry my daughter to a king; if you will
be so, and be rich, I will ask the king to give you the kingdom which your
father ruled.’ The frogs were overjoyed at the thought, and said, ‘Yes, yes,
do so, and we will do all you wish.’

Then the miller went back to the king, and said, ‘There is a king’s son who
will marry my daughter, and he is very, very, very, very, very, very, very,
very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very,
very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very,
rich, and in high favour with you.’ The king made haste to say yes to this,
and ordered the wedding to be got ready.

The day soon came when the wedding was to be celebrated. The miller and his
daughter were overjoyed, and the seven little frogs were brought in by the
miller. ‘Do as I bid you,’ said he, ‘and you shall be well rewarded.’ Then he
bade one of them sit on the king’s head, another on the queen’s head, the
third on the marshal’s head, the fourth on the chamberlain’s head, the fifth
on the butler’s head, the sixth on the cook’s head, and the seventh on the
waiter’s head.

So they were seated, and the king and all his court sat down to the wedding
feast. When the time came for eating, the king wanted to take some food, but
the frog on his head cried out, ‘Stop! Stop!’ The king was frightened, and
did not eat. Then the frog said, ‘I am hungry, give me some food.’ So someone
gave the frog a roll, and it ate it all up. After that the king tried to eat,
but the frog cried out, ‘Stop! Stop!’ Again he was told to wait till the frog
had eaten. So it ate another roll, and then the king was allowed to eat.

When the king had finished his dinner, and was merry, the frog on his head
said, ‘I am tired, I want to go to bed.’ Then all the court went to their
seats and beds, but the king and queen went to their bed-chamber. The frog
on the queen’s head, however, cried out, ‘Stop! Stop!’ and did not let them
go in. ‘Why do you cry out?’ said the king. ‘I am tired, and want to sleep,
so let the bed be carried out here,’ said the frog. Then the bed was carried
out, and the king and queen were forced to lie down on it in the antechamber.
The frog on the queen’s bed again cried out, ‘I am hungry, give me something
to eat.’ So they gave it a roll, and it ate it up. After that the king and
queen were allowed to go to bed.

In the morning, before the king and all his court had got up, the frogs jumped
down from their heads, and jumped into a pool close by, and all became kings
and queens, and reigned over their own countries.

The end.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Shepherd and the Star

In a land far away, there lived a poor shepherd who had only one sheep, and one old dog that was as poor as he. They lived in a little hut upon the side of a hill, and in the daytime the shepherd used to take the sheep out upon the heath, and the dog went with him.

One evening, as they were coming home, the sheep found a great stone in its way, and when the shepherd tried to pass it, it laid itself down and would go no farther. Then the shepherd said, ‘What shall I do with you? You have been a true friend to me, and given good service, but now you are grown old and weak, and this stone is too heavy for you. What can I do but kill you?’ So he took his staff and struck the poor animal, and it fell to the ground dead.

Then the old dog came up and licked the blood that flowed from the sheep, and said, ‘Alas! alas! my master will have nothing to live upon, if he kills me next. I will go into the world and try what I can do to help him.’

So away went the dog, over the hills and far away, till he came to a village. Now in this village there was a butcher, who was famous all around for the good roasts that he made, and the great fires that he burnt before his house. So the dog went up to the butcher’s house, and said, ‘All the world knows how good your roasts are, but your fires are what everybody marvels at; they burn with such a little wood, and yet how large they are! Tell me, I pray, how you manage it.’

‘How can that be of any use to me?’ said the butcher; ‘come in, and let’s talk of something worth while.’

Then he brought the dog in, and gave him plenty to eat and drink, and let him lie by the fire; and when he had told his tale, the butcher said, ‘I will tell you what--you are a clever dog, and I like you, so I will teach you how to get me all the wood that you can find, and in return I will give you as much meat as you can eat.’

So the dog went into the woods, and every morning came back loaded with wood, and the butcher gave him as much meat as he could eat. But one morning, as he was going away, he said to the butcher, ‘I have served you long enough; now tell me what it is all about, that you make such a great fire, and yet use so little wood.’

Then the butcher said, ‘I am a witch, and I make my fires with wind, not with wood. I have been trying to find out if you were worthy to be my familiar, and now at last I am going to tell you the truth. You shall go with me to my master, the king of the witches, and you shall be well rewarded.’

So he took the dog with him, and they journeyed on and on, till at last they came to a great castle, where all the lights were out, and yet it looked as if a thousand people lived there. Then the butcher knocked at the door, and when he had spoken to someone within, the door was thrown open, and they went in.

Everything was so grand that the dog could not help standing on his legs, and looking about him; and the butcher said, ‘You have been a faithful servant, and I will reward you as you deserve. Here is a cloak that will make you invisible, and here is a hat that will make you any size you wish to be. Now go into the kitchen, and ask for some broth; then, when they are going to throw it out, tell them you want it for a very poor old man who is at the gate, and who will give you something in return.’

Then the dog put on the cloak, so that he became invisible, and went into the kitchen, and said what the butcher told him. And the cook was just going to throw out some broth that was not good enough for the witches to eat, and she gave it to him.

But as he was going out, the butler saw him, and said, ‘What are you about, stealing our broth?’ Then the dog said, ‘I am taking it to a very poor old man who is at the gate, and will give me something in return.’

‘Give it him,’ said the butler; ‘he talks sensibly.’

So the dog took the broth, and went with it to the butcher, who took it away, and put into it a sleeping draught, so that when the witches came to drink it they should fall asleep.

Then the butcher gave the dog the hat, and said, ‘Put that on, and take such a large size as will enable you to reach the highest shelf.’

So he put on the hat, and grew big and tall, and went into the kitchen, and took the sleeping draught that was in the broth, and brought it to the butcher.

And when the butcher had put on the cloak, and was invisible, he went with the dog into the kitchen, and the butcher cried out, ‘Why do you sleep there?’ and he shook all the witches, so that they awoke and were very angry.

Then the butcher said, ‘What are you doing here?’

‘We are having a feast,’ said they.

‘What are you feasting on?’ said the butcher.

‘On a nice fat dog that I got in the village,’ said one.

‘And I had a beautiful young lamb,’ said another.

‘And I had a fine young calf,’ said a third.

‘You wicked witches!’ said the butcher; ‘you have been eating my familiar, and my two friends who went with him! I thought I should have had a good feast myself, if you had left them to me. Now, as you have eaten them, you shall die in your turn.’

Then he called his servant, the butler, and said, ‘Stretch yonder rope across the room.’

So the butler stretched the rope across the room.

‘And now,’ said the butcher, ‘you witches must dance for me, and whenever I tell you, jump over the rope.’

So they began to dance, and the butcher clapped his hands, and cried, ‘Jump!’ Then they jumped, and stuck their heads and feet fast in the rope, and danced in the air, with their bodies between, till they died.

And the butcher and the dog returned home safe and happy, and the butcher said, ‘As you have served me well, and as you are so clever, I will let you choose whatever you will. Either I will give you a beautiful golden cage, with a golden chain, and you shall be my familiar, and live upon meat, and have plenty to eat and drink; or, if you would rather, I will restore your old master to life, and to everything he had in the world before.’

Then the dog thought a little, and said, ‘I will take my master back to life.’

So the butcher brought him to the hill where the shepherd lived, and gave him his flock of sheep, and his old dog, and all that he had before his poor animal was killed; and there they all lived happily to the end.

The End.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Bremen Town Musicians

In a village lived a dog, a cat, a donkey, and a cock. They had long been old and had no longer been able to work, so they had to provide for themselves out of their own pockets. One day they agreed that they would go into the world and try to earn a living as musicians.

So they set out together, and when they had walked for some time they came to a town. ‘We shall not go straight into the town,’ said the donkey, ‘but will rest here for a while under this bush until we have gathered some strength.’ So they lay down and went to sleep. It was not long before a parson passed by, and seeing four beasts lying there, he said: ‘What a fine sight! Four beasts lying asleep together!’ He called his servant and made him go up to them and see if it was true. The servant approached, and as the beasts showed themselves to be very shy, they thought it would be the best thing to do, and pretended to be asleep. The servant went away and told the parson that it was true, and that they were lying fast asleep. ‘If that is so,’ said the parson, ‘they must be witches who have taken the form of beasts, and have come together for some wicked purpose. We must follow them at once and catch them while they are sleeping.’ The parson was much excited, and took his servant with him and hurried to the town hall and told the mayor and aldermen what had happened, and that four witches were lying fast asleep under the bush, and that it was essential that they should be caught and burnt. The mayor and aldermen were terrified at the thought, and told the parson that he and his servant should wait there until daybreak, and that they themselves would go with a strong body of men and catch the witches while they were asleep.

The night was not long in passing, and the four musicians awoke and said: ‘It is time for us to go, for it is not safe here.’ But when they got upon their legs they felt very weak, and could hardly support themselves. ‘We must rest for a short time,’ said the donkey, ‘until our strength comes back.’ So they lay down again, and soon fell asleep. It was not long before a doctor passed by, and seeing four beasts lying there, he said: ‘What a fine sight! Four beasts lying asleep together!’ He called his servant and made him go up and see if it was true. The servant went and found them fast asleep, and as they did not stir when he approached, he went away and told the doctor that it was true, and that they were lying fast asleep. ‘If that is so,’ said the doctor, ‘they must be poisoned, and have taken the form of beasts, and have come together for the purpose of killing themselves. We must follow them at once and catch them while they are sleeping.’ The doctor was much excited, and took his servant with him and hurried to the town hall and told the mayor and aldermen what had happened, and that four rogues were lying fast asleep under the bush, and that it was essential that they should be caught and hanged. The mayor and aldermen were terrified at the thought, and told the doctor that he and his servant should wait there until daybreak, and that they themselves would go with a strong body of men and catch the rogues while they were sleeping.

The night was not long in passing, and the four musicians awoke and said: ‘It is time for us to go, for it is not safe here.’ But when they got upon their legs they felt very weak, and could hardly support themselves. ‘We must rest for a short time,’ said the donkey, ‘until our strength comes back.’ So they lay down again, and soon fell asleep. It was not long before a soldier passed by, and seeing four beasts lying there, he said: ‘What a fine sight! Four beasts lying asleep together!’ He called his comrade and made him go up and see if it was true. The comrade went and found them fast asleep, and as they did not stir when he approached, he went away and told the soldier that it was true, and that they were lying fast asleep. ‘If that is so,’ said the soldier, ‘they must be thieves who have taken the form of beasts, and have come together for some wicked purpose. We must follow them at once and catch them while they are sleeping.’ The soldier was much excited, and took his comrade with him and hurried to the town hall and told the mayor and aldermen what had happened, and that four thieves were lying fast asleep under the bush, and that it was essential that they should be caught and transported. The mayor and aldermen were terrified at the thought, and told the soldier that he and his comrade should wait there until daybreak, and that they themselves would go with a strong body of soldiers and catch the thieves while they were sleeping.

The night was not long in passing, and the four musicians awoke and said: ‘It is time for us to go, for it is not safe here.’ But when they got upon their legs they felt very weak, and could hardly support themselves. ‘We must rest for a short time,’ said the donkey, ‘until our strength comes back.’ So they lay down again, and soon fell asleep. It was not long before a hunt passed by, and seeing four beasts lying there, the huntsman said: ‘What a fine sight! Four beasts lying asleep together!’ He called his servant and made him go up and see if it was true. The servant went and found them fast asleep, and as they did not stir when he approached, he went away and told the huntsman that it was true, and that they were lying fast asleep. ‘If that is so,’ said the huntsman, ‘they must be deer who have taken the form of beasts, and have come together for some wicked purpose. We must follow them at once and catch them while they are sleeping.’ The huntsman was much excited, and took his servant with him and hurried to the town hall and told the mayor and aldermen what had happened, and that four deer were lying fast asleep under the bush, and that it was essential that they should be caught and killed. The mayor and aldermen were terrified at the thought, and told the huntsman that he and his servant should wait there until daybreak, and that they themselves would go with a strong body of huntsmen and catch the deer while they were sleeping.

But when the day dawned, and the four musicians saw that they had been lucky and had been mistaken for so many things, they said: ‘It is time for us to go into the town and try our luck.’ So they went into the town and placed themselves in front of the gates of the houses and began to play a merry tune. Many people came together and made a crowd, and when they saw four beasts playing music they did not know what to think, and called the mayor and aldermen to come and see the wonder. The mayor and aldermen came and watched them from a distance, and as they were old men they felt no fear, and at last went up to them and asked them what they wanted. ‘We want to live here,’ said the dog, ‘and if you please we will give you some music every day.’ ‘You may live here quite peaceably,’ said the mayor and aldermen, ‘and we will only ask one thing of you, that you shall not play your music too early in the morning.’ ‘That we will not do,’ said the dog. ‘We will wait until it is six o’clock.’ ‘Seven o’clock,’ said the cat. ‘Seven o’clock is still too early,’ said the donkey. ‘We will leave it to eight o’clock.’ ‘That will still be early,’ said the cock. ‘We will wait until nine o’clock.’ ‘That will be all right,’ said the others. ‘We will wait until nine o’clock.’ So the musicians were allowed to live in peace, and every day at nine o’clock they went to the town gates and played a merry tune.

The End

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor old woman who had only one cow, and this cow gave her but little milk. So she was often obliged to go out in the evening to look for food for herself and her child. Now now it so happened that one evening she could find nothing to get, and was very much frightened, for she could not reach home in safety, and the night was dark and stormy. At length she saw a light in a cave, and went up to it, and found a little dwarf sitting there. ‘Do give me something to eat,’ said she, ‘or I shall starve.’ ‘What will you give me in return?’ asked the dwarf. ‘My beautiful cow,’ answered the woman. ‘No,’ said the dwarf, ‘I will not take your cow, for she is not very fat; but I will give you a calf that will always be fat, and will give you a quart of milk every morning.’ So the old woman was very glad, and said she would do what he wished; and the dwarf gave her a calf, and went his way.

The old woman took the calf home, and it always gave a great deal of milk; for the dwarf had kept his word, and every morning there was a quart for the woman. And she thought to herself, ‘If this is the case, what will not the little creature be when it is grown up?’ So she made up her mind to kill it, and take the flesh to the next town to sell, and there she might be able to buy some good clothes with the money. But the calf knew what she was going to do, and one morning when she went to milk it, it gave her a kick with its hind legs, and ran away. Then she was very angry, and cried out, ‘You ungrateful creature, you shall repent this as long as you live!’

She could not run after the calf, for it was very quick, and soon outstripped her; but she still kept on crying out her curse. At length the calf saw a man approaching, and thought to itself, ‘If I take up any food now, and eat it, my mistress will know where I am, and will run and take my life.’ So it did not dare to eat, but went on as fast as it could. And when it had gone about half a mile, it saw a baker sitting by the roadside with some bread. ‘Do give me a loaf,’ cried the calf, ‘or I shall starve.’ ‘Who are you, and what are you doing here?’ said the baker. ‘I am a poor traveller, and have nothing to eat.’ ‘What a big appetite you have!’ said the baker, ‘you must be very strong.’ ‘Yes,’ answered the calf, ‘I am very strong.’ Then the baker said, ‘I will just see you into the next town.’ So he put the calf on his cart, and drove it on, and it ate up the bread that the baker had given it, and was still hungry.

When they came to the town, the baker said, ‘I cannot take you with me, for it is not seemly to drag a calf about the streets; so if you will give me the best of your flesh when I kill you, I will keep you.’ But the calf said, ‘No, I will not do that.’ Then the baker said, ‘I will give you to the butcher.’ And the butcher took the calf, and thought to himself, ‘If I take it to the fair that is soon to be held, and it gets fat on the way, I shall be able to sell it for a great sum of money.’

So he drove it away, and every day it ate more and more, and grew bigger and bigger; till at last it was so large that the butcher could not drive it any farther, and said, ‘I cannot take it to the fair now, for it would push down all the other cattle; so I had better kill it.’

Then the butcher went up to it, and was going to have driven the stake into its heart, when it said, ‘Wait a little, I am not quite ready to die.’ In another minute it said again, ‘Now I am ready.’ Then the butcher drove the stake into its heart, and as soon as it was dead it became quite small, and the butcher carried it home on his shoulder, and cut it up, and sold all that was best to the king’s table.

When the old woman heard that such a fine animal had been found, and that it had been sold to the butcher, and that the butcher had sold part of it to the king, she was very much frightened, and said, ‘They will soon find out who it was, and then they will kill me.’ So she went to the butcher, and said, ‘Do pray give me some of the flesh of the calf, for I am very fond of it.’ ‘Certainly,’ said the butcher, ‘I will give you as much as you can carry.’ Then he gave her a great piece, which she put on her shoulder, and took home with her.

But when she got home, and was going to eat it, she said to herself, ‘I will just make up my mind to take care of myself, in case my wickedness should be discovered.’ Then she set the piece of meat aside for the present, and sat down and combed her grey hair, and when she had done she said, ‘Now I will eat, and enjoy myself, for tomorrow I shall be sorry.’ So she took the meat, and ate it all up.

The next morning, as she was going out to look for food, the policeman met her, and said, ‘You old sinner, you have killed your own child, for the flesh of that calf was its flesh, which you have just eaten.’ Then the old woman fell on her knees, and cried out, ‘Ah, heavens! what shall I do?’ But the policeman took her to the magistrate, and she was sentenced to be hanged.

When the day came that she was to die, she was led up to the gallows, and all the people came out to see her. Then she was bound to the gallows, and the rope put round her neck, and the ladder taken away. But when they were going to let her fall, she said, ‘I will tell you a tale.’ ‘No,’ said the constable, ‘not now, not now.’ ‘Oh, do let her tell her tale,’ cried the people; ‘we will hear what it is, and then she may have it for her last saying.’

So the old woman began to tell her tale, and said, ‘There was once a king’s son who went out hunting, and did not come back, and nobody knew where he was, or what had happened to him.’ ‘Now will you be quiet,’ said the constable; ‘it is of no use to tell your tale, you must die.’

But the old woman still continued, ‘The king sent out people to seek for his son, and they went a great way, till they came to a cave, where a dwarf lived. The dwarf knew at once what had become of the prince, and said he must have followed him into the cave. Then the king sent one of his men into the cave to try if he could find the prince, but he had not gone far before he heard a noise like the noise of a wheel, and the dwarf came up to him, and said, “That is the mill that will turn your prince’s flesh into blood, and then he will be quite dead.” So the man came back, and told the king what had happened, and said, “The dwarf told me that if I would bring him a piece of beef, as big as my head, he would give me the mill, and then I should be able to turn the prince’s flesh into blood.”

Then the king sent the interpreter to the dwarf, to try and find out what the price of the mill was. And the dwarf said, “I will tell you what I will do; I will give you the mill for the flesh of a man.” But the interpreter said, “Not for all the world would

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor woodman who cut wood in the forest, and lived there with his wife. One day he cut too much wood and was very tired, so he sat down and took a nap. While he slept, a little dwarf came and took away all the wood from his cart, and when the woodman awoke and saw that all his work was undone, he was very angry, and called out: ‘Who has been stealing my wood?’ But no one answered, and he saw no one, so he thought it must have been the fairies.

Then he gathered up all the wood and took it home to his wife, and said, ‘I will watch and see who takes my wood, for I am sure it is the fairies.’ So next day, when it was getting dark, he piled up a great deal of wood, and sat himself down behind a tree near by, that he might see who took it.

His wife, too, was curious to see the fairies, and peeped out of the hole in the door while he was away. And as she saw the woodman sitting behind the tree, she ran and hid herself.

Now the fairies soon came. They flew through the air in a merry dance, singing:

 ‘Round and round the wood we go,
  Where the trees in the greenwood grow;
  Little dwarfs are we,
  Merry are we!
  Heigho! heigho!
  Reel and skip,
  And tap your shoes upon my lip.’

And they came to the place where the wood lay, and each took a piece, and sat down upon a stump to smoke his pipe, and enjoy himself. But the woodman was so frightened when he saw them that he ran and hid himself; and when he heard the merry music and laughing, he thought it was a very happy party, and envied them.

Presently they began to gather up their things and go home; and the one who had taken the most wood put all he had in his pocket, and took it away with him. But the woodman, who had been watching him, ran up to him, and took him prisoner, and carried him off to his house, and said, ‘Now, you must work hard for me, and do all the job I tell you to do, or you will have a bad time of it.’ Then he took him to his wife, and said, ‘Look, I have got one of them at last, and he must do all the work for us now.’

The little dwarf was at first very unwilling, and said, ‘How can a poor little fellow like me do all the work?’ But the woodman and his wife were very powerful, and they said, ‘Yes, you must do it.’ So at last he said, ‘Well, I’ll try.’

Then they took him into the forest, and showed him a great tree which they said was full of gold, but that the door was too high for them to reach, and that they had worked hard for three years to get to it, but could not. Then the little dwarf soon set to work, and in a very short time he had cut down the tree, and brought all the gold to the woodman and his wife.

After this, the little dwarf did all the work for them; he dug their garden, kept it clean, and did all the housework, besides working in the forest. And they were very kind to him, and let him have all the food he could eat, and as much to drink as he could want; and every three months he had to go into the mountain and brought home more gold.

But one day the wife said to him, ‘Why do you work so hard for those two silly people? You ought to be sorry for a little dwarf like you to be a servant to two louts like that.’ Then the little dwarf said, ‘How can I help it? They are my masters.’

However, when she saw him so unhappy, she said, ‘I will help you.’ So she called the woodman, and said, ‘Listen, you silly fellow, why do you keep the little dwarf as a servant? He is much cleverer than you are, and he ought to be free. I say he shall be free.’

Then the woodman was very angry, and said, ‘We will see about that.’ So he made a seat on a high tree, and told the dwarf that the fairies were going to sit in judgment upon him, and that he must appear before them. The little dwarf was afraid, and went, but when he got up to the seat the woodman cut the ladder, so that he had to fall from the tree.

When he found that he was not hurt, he was very angry, and said, ‘You have cheated me, and I will cheat you.’ Then he went to a baker and bought a loaf of bread, and cut it into two pieces as big as his head, and went to the woodman and threw one of them down at his feet, and said, ‘Here is a stone.’

The woodman stooped down to pick it up, but the bread was very soft, and the weight was so great that he could not lift it, and he fell on his knees. Then the little dwarf threw down the other piece of bread near his wife, and she fell on her knees and prayed to the fairies to deliver her, for she saw that the little dwarf would take his revenge.

But the little dwarf said, ‘You shall work for me now.’ And then he went home to his own people, and told them how he had been treated, and they were very angry, and went to the woodman and his wife, and took them away, and set the woodman and his wife to work, one grinding and the other spinning, without any rest day or night.

And thus the little dwarf got his revenge, and the woodman and his wife worked till they died, for there is no saying how long fairy magic can last.

The End.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Shepherd Boy and the Wolf

In a village in the Black Forest lived a shepherd boy whose father had
died, and who supported his mother by the scanty earnings he got by
tending the village sheep. One day he took his flock to feed upon the
mountain side, and as he was sitting down to rest, he heard a wolf close
by, making a most dismal howling. He was not at all afraid, but called
out, ‘Do what you will with the sheep, only don’t eat me!’ The wolf came
towards him, and said, ‘I only want to talk with you.’ ‘Very well,’ said
the boy, ‘but if you want to eat me, begin and eat, for there is no
stopping you.’ ‘No,’ said the wolf, ‘I only want to ask you a few
questions. How many sheep have you there?’ ‘How many?’ said the boy, ‘I
have not counted them, but I will tell you what I will do: I will take
you round them, and whatever I say to you, that will be the number. As
you care nothing about eating me, I will tell you the truth. When I say,
‘That is one,’ that means there is one, when I say, ‘That is two,’ that
means there are two, and so on. Now then, come and listen.’ Then he
began to count them, and every time he said any thing the wolf wrote
it down. ‘That is one,’ said the boy, and the wolf wrote down ‘1.’ ‘That
is two,’ said the boy, and the wolf wrote down ‘2.’ ‘That is three,’ said
the boy, and the wolf wrote down ‘3.’ ‘That is four,’ said the boy, and
the wolf wrote down ‘4.’ ‘That is five,’ said the boy, and the wolf wrote
down ‘5.’ ‘That is six,’ said the boy, and the wolf wrote down ‘6.’ ‘That
is seven,’ said the boy, and the wolf wrote down ‘7.’ ‘That is eight,’
said the boy, and the wolf wrote down ‘8.’ ‘That is nine,’ said the boy,
and the wolf wrote down ‘9.’ ‘That is ten,’ said the boy, and the wolf
wrote down ‘10.’ ‘Now, then, how many sheep have you?’ said the wolf.
‘Twenty-one,’ answered the boy. ‘Now,’ said the wolf, ‘lie down there
behind that great stone, and don’t move a finger, and pretend to be
asleep.’ ‘But what are you going to do?’ said the boy. ‘Why, I am going
to make the best of you, that’s all.’ So the wolf went away, and the boy
hid himself behind the stone as he was told. Soon after came a dog, and
then a fox, and then a bear, one after the other, each wanting to share
the sheep with the wolf. ‘It is not fair,’ said the fox, ‘that the wolf
should have them all to himself.’ ‘If you will help me to watch and I
will share them with you,’ said the boy. ‘Very well,’ said the fox, ‘but
you must promise not to call out.’ So they laid themselves down to
watch, but the boy, as soon as it was midnight, cried out at the top of
his voice, ‘Three hundred and sixty-five! Three hundred and sixty-six!
Three hundred and sixty-seven!’ and so on, till he had counted all the
sheep. The wolf was so frightened that he sprang up and ran away as fast
as he could, and the dog, fox, and bear, having got what they could,
scampered away after him. The shepherd boy then came out from behind the
stone, and gathered together his flock, which had run away in the chase,
and went home safely. ‘The End.’
