The Shepherd’s Boy and the Wolf

In a village lived a poor shepherd, who had only one ewe-lamb very much
beloved by him. One day he took the little sheep with him into the forest
to feed, and then went himself home to dinner. The lamb ran about in the
wood, eating here and there, and at last came to a little stream. ‘How
pretty it is here!’ cried the lamb, ‘how cool and clear the water is! I
would so like to take a drink.’ So saying, it leapt down into the stream.
When the shepherd boy came back, his sheep was nowhere to be seen; so he
called and searched, but all in vain. Then he was very sad, and knew not
what to do, when a wolf came by, and said to him, ‘What’s the matter? Why
are you so sad?’ ‘Alas!’ said the shepherd, ‘my little lamb has run away,
and I don’t know where to find it.’ ‘If that be the case,’ said the wolf,
‘I will find it for you, but promise me that you will do what I wish you
to do.’ ‘Anything, anything,’ answered the shepherd, ‘only bring me my
lamb.’ ‘Then listen,’ said the wolf; ‘when you come to a house where a
roast goat is turning on the spit, and two little girls are at the door,
one of them named Hans, and the other Hansel, do not stop with them,
but go on with me.’

The shepherd boy thought to himself: ‘The wolf wants to devour my poor
lamb, and then eat me likewise.’ However, he said: ‘I will do it.’ So the
wolf led him through the forest to the house where the little lamb was.
The shepherd was overjoyed when he saw it was safe, but the wolf cried
out: ‘Stop, stop! This way goes the water, turn back or you will perish.’
Then the shepherd boy was forced to promise that, whenever they should
come to a large tree with a hollow trunk, he would take away the little
lamb, and let the wolf have it. The wolf, however, had no intention of
keeping even this promise, but would have run straight to the shepherd’s
house and devoured his wife and children, if the shepherd had not been
forced to run away by the people who were seeking him on account of the
lamb.

The wolf did not wait until the shepherd was gone, but ate up the poor
little lamb, and then laid himself down and waited for the shepherd. When
he came, the wolf said: ‘You wicked boy! Have you forgotten me? Have you
forgotten the promise you made to me? Give me the lamb.’ ‘Ah!’ answered
the shepherd, ‘you are a villain! You have devoured my lamb, and now you
want to eat me too.’ ‘Listen,’ said the wolf, ‘when you come to a marsh
full of water and flowers, and a little child is standing in it, and
crying, and you see a breadcrumb lying on the ground, and another child
standing on each side of it, one of the names of whom is Hans, and the
other Hansel, let the little one go, and take the other; I will eat the
first, but will spare the second.’ The shepherd thought: ‘The wolf will
certainly soon have a roast shepherd, if I do not get away from him.’ So
he ran to the police and gave the wolf in the bargain.

The wolf, however, did not leave the matter thus, but went to the father
and mother of the two children, and cried out: ‘I am a wolf, and have
carried off your children into the forest, but this shepherd boy is coming
after me, and will kill me; if, therefore, you love your children, you
must help me.’ ‘Oh, wolf,’ said the father, ‘why have you done such a
wicked thing? We will do everything you wish.’ Then the wolf said: ‘Listen,
I am at present eating little Hans, and if you do not throw down to me, as
quick as you can, two pounds of breadcrumbs and a pound of meat, I will
stop eating and let the child go.’ The father ran to the baker and made
him bring the bread, and the butcher the meat, and then he threw it all
into the forest. The wolf did not stop there, but cried out: ‘This is not
enough, unless you bring me, as quickly as you can, six pounds of bread
and three pounds of meat.’ The father ran to the baker and the butcher
again, and they brought the bread and meat. When the wolf had satisfied
his appetite, and had made a roast of both the children, he stretched
their bodies out, and laid themselves down on each side of the path, and
then went to sleep.

Early in the morning, when the father was coming to feed his little flock
of sheep, he saw the two children, and almost fainted with fear and
grief, and then he awakened their mother. She wept and lamented, and when
they had looked at the children and seen that they were dead, they
sorrowed and bewailed them for three days. Then they buried them, and
their grief was more than they could bear. ‘Alas!’ said the mother,
‘what shall we do now? We will wander from place to place, that we may
forget our sorrow.’ ‘Yes,’ said the father, ‘that is a good thought.
Let us go into a strange country, and there we may perhaps hear of some
place where we can earn our livelihood.’

So they took their little flock of sheep with them, and walked day and
night without stopping, always following different paths. At last they
came to a great forest, and as they were very tired, they thought they
would rest for a while. The shepherd built a little hut, and the woman
gathered together twigs and heath, and made a fire, and they sat down
close by it, and watched their sheep. ‘I do not like living here,’ said
the mother, ‘how lonely and dreary it is.’ ‘I am quite satisfied,’ said the
father, ‘and here we can at any rate take care of ourselves.’

One day, as the woman sat by the fire, she looked through the forest,
and saw two little children coming towards her. ‘Ah!’ she cried, ‘how
delightful! To see children again! They are so like Hans and Hansel.’
As they came nearer, she went out and gave them some food, and asked if
they belonged to any one, and where they came from. ‘Oh, yes,’ said they,
‘we belong to no one, and we come from the other side of the forest.’
Then the woman said: ‘You must be weary,’ and she made up a bed for them
by the fire, and next morning she gave them something to eat, and they
went out to feed the sheep with the two children.

In the evening when they came back, a man was sitting by the fire. ‘Where
have you been?’ said the mother. ‘In the forest looking for food, and
finding none,’ answered the children. ‘Ah!’ said the woman, ‘it is a
waste of time looking for food here, we must soon think of something else
to do.’ ‘I am quite satisfied,’ said the man, ‘and here we can at any rate
take care of ourselves.’

The two children, Hans and Hansel, always went out with the shepherd and
his wife when they took their sheep into the forest, and gathered up the

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Enchanted Fiddle

There was once upon a time a poor peasant named Hans, who worked hard all
day long, and yet could not earn enough to support himself and his wife.
‘How can we manage to live?’ said he. ‘What will my poor wife get to eat?’
‘I’ll tell you what, Hans,’ said she, ‘you must try and get a job in
town, then we shall have something to live upon.’ So Hans left his little
cottage, and went into the town, where he soon found a place as waiter in
a public-house. He worked hard, but his wages were small, and at the end
of a month he had not earned half enough to take home to his wife.

‘What shall I do?’ said he. ‘How can I get anything to take home to my
wife?’ So he went into the back kitchen, and took an old fiddle that
hung on the wall, and began to knock it together as well as he could.

Now the landlord of the house had an enchanted fiddle, which could be
played by anyone, but when it was played by a true artist, it played of
its own accord. When therefore he heard the waiter in the back kitchen
knocking away at the old fiddle, he went in and said, ‘Hark you, Hans,
that fiddle is not yours, and if you play it, it will play of its own
accord, and then you will have some trouble. If you can play it, I will
give it you, but if it plays of its own accord, you must go away and never
come back.’

Hans said, ‘I will soon try.’

Then he took the fiddle and went into a corner, and the fiddle began to
play of its own accord, and danced upon the strings the most wonderful
things, so that Hans had to laugh and clap his hands. ‘Ah!’ said the
landlord, ‘you must go away, you cannot stay here.’

But Hans begged so hard that the landlord let him have the fiddle, and
said, ‘Take it, and if you can play it, it will play of its own accord,
but if it plays of itself, away you must go.’

Hans took the fiddle to his lodgings, and when he had eaten his supper,
he took it out and tried what he could do. He had been a waiter in the
town, it is true, but he had been a soldier before, and had often played
the fiddle then, so he soon made the best of it, and played a merry tune
on it.

Now as he was in the middle of a reel, the fiddle stopped, and said,

 ‘Humans are such silly things!
  How can they play me, and not understand my song?’

Hans was so astonished that he fell off his chair.

‘Now,’ said the fiddle, ‘I’ll tell you a tale. There was once upon a time
a king who had twelve beautiful daughters, and as they were all very
beautiful, and had the most charming manners, and were kind and good
to everybody, the king thought he would have a great feast given, and
would give each of his daughters as a prize to the best singer, dancer,
and artist of all kinds who should appear at the feast. Now the feast was
held, and singers and dancers came from far and near, but the king and his
daughters stayed below in the hall till some one came who should please
them so much that they could not leave them.

When all were gone, there came in a little dwarf, who bowed down to the
twelve princesses, and said, ‘I am an artist.’ Then he took a box of
pins, and drove a pin into the floor in front of each princess, and
before he had done this they had all twelve pins in the floor, and the
dwarf said, ‘Now I want to play at king and queen with you.’ Then he
began to dance round and round, and the princesses were forced to dance
after him, and whenever he came to any pin they had to stop upon it, and
wait till he came round to it again.

This amused the king and princesses so much that they quite forgot where
they were, and danced on and on, till the time came for the king to give
his twelve beautiful daughters as prizes. But the dwarf said, ‘One more
dance, one more dance!’ Then he made all twelve of them dance together
together, and as they were all joined together, and the dance was so
pretty, that no one could help laughing and clapping their hands.

But the twelfth princess, who was the prettiest of all, slipped away
from the others, and ran behind the scene, and there she found a hollow
tree, and into this she crept, and the huntsmen who were to have taken
her away, took the eleventh instead of her, and the king gave the dwarf,
together with the eleventh princess, as a prize.

When the dance was over, the king looked round for his twelfth princess,
but could not find her, and thought his heart would break, for he loved
her better than all the others. Then the huntsmen said, ‘We will soon
find her, for she has left a white slipper behind her.’ So they looked
about, and found the slipper, and it was quite white, for it was always
kept clean.

The dwarf, too, wanted to have the twelfth princess, and he had two
servants, who were little dwarfs like himself, and they searched the
wood, and found the slipper, and it was quite white still.

Then the fishers went and looked for her by the brook, and found her,
and the slipper was quite white still.

The shepherds looked for her upon the hills, and found her, and the slipper
was quite white still.

The hunters looked for her in the wood, and found her, and the slipper
was quite white still.

The fowlers looked for her in the meadows, and found her, and the slipper
was quite white still.

The schoolmasters looked for her in the schools, and found her, and the
slipper was quite white still.

The sexton looked for her in the church, and found her, and the slipper
was quite white still.

The parson looked for her in the church, and found her, and the slipper
was quite white still.

The squire looked for her in his court, and found her, and the slipper
was quite white still.

The king looked for her in his palace, and found her, and the slipper
was quite white still.

But the twelfth princess, who was the prettiest of all, had run behind
the scene, and there she stayed.

Now the hunt was given up, and the king was very sorrowful, and thought
his heart would break, for he loved the twelfth princess better than all
the others. Then the dwarf said, ‘I can find her, for her slipper is
quite white still.’

‘Do so,’ said the king.

Then the dwarf went his way, and the princess came from behind the
scene, and gave the dwarf’s little servant the slipper that was not quite
white still, and the servant took it to the dwarf.

And the dwarf came back to the king, and said, ‘I have found the princess,
and she is coming with me.’

Then the king was very glad, and thought his heart would burst with
joy, for he thought the twelfth princess was coming.

But it was only the eleventh, who was not half so beautiful as the
twelfth, and was not half

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
Once upon a time, there was a poor peasant named Hans, who had three sons. Now, Hans had no cattle, no sheep, nor any thing else with which he could earn a livelihood, so that he and his wife were very unhappy, and did not know how they should get bread enough to eat. At last they agreed that the eldest son should go out into the wide world and try his luck, and thus earn some money for the family. So he took leave of his father and mother, and set off on his journey.

He walked and walked till at last the road led him through a dark wood. As he was passing through it, it became so dark that he could scarcely see what he was about; and as he was very much afraid, he said, ‘If I but meet a good friend, I shall be happy.’ Not long was he left waiting: for a man soon came in sight, who seemed to be in great trouble, and was tearing his hair and beard, and crying out: ‘Alas! alas! how shall I provide for my poor wife and children? What will become of us?’

‘I feel very sorry for you, my friend,’ said the youth, ‘but I am no rich man myself; yet will I do my best to help you.’

Then he took out what little money he had, and gave it to the man, and said: ‘There, that is all I can give you.’ The other, seeing that the youth had nothing left, would have been well pleased; but he said: ‘No, my friend, you must work harder than that.’ Then he led him to the side of a hill, where some stone was to be quarried, and said: ‘If you will work as a quarryman, and hew stone for me, I will give you food and drink, and pay you what wages I can.’ The youth consented, and began to work; and when the day was ended the man gave him a piece of bread and cheese, and said: ‘That is all I can give you for your work.’

However, the next day the bread and cheese were larger, and the day after they still more so; and so it went on for some days, till the piece of bread was as large as a loaf, and the cheese as big as a wheel. Then the man said to the youth: ‘I can give you no work here any longer; you must go into the town and try to earn a living.’ ‘Where shall I go?’ said the youth. ‘I know not.’ ‘Then look up into the sky, and the first place where the sun rises will be your destination.’

The youth did as he was told, and found that the first place where the sun rose was a town not far off. So he went thither, and as he could find no work in the town, he went out into the country and began to look for some place where he could earn his livelihood.

At last he came to a mill, and as he passed by he saw an old woman sitting behind the door, crying. ‘Why do you weep?’ said he. ‘What is all this?’ ‘Ah, me!’ said the old woman, ‘I am so hungry that I can find nothing to put into my mouth.’ Then the youth offered to work for her, and said: ‘I will work hard, and do what I can to earn my bread.’ ‘That is well,’ said the old woman; ‘then cut down that tree, and make me a windmill.’ The tree was not far off, and the youth cut it down, and made a windmill so nicely that it turned very well. ‘Now,’ said the old woman, ‘you must stand behind the mill and sell the meal.’ As the youth had nothing to live upon, he could not do this, and said: ‘I must have something to eat first.’ Then the old woman gave him a dish of beans, but they were not nearly enough to satisfy him; so he said: ‘I must have more, or I shall die.’ ‘Very well,’ said the old woman; ‘if you can eat two more dishes of beans, you shall have plenty to eat, and as much as you can earn.’

Then the youth sat himself down, and ate one dish of beans after another, till at last he had eaten seven in all; and the old woman kept what he had earned, and said: ‘Now, you shall have a room to sleep in, and plenty to eat.’

So the youth worked hard, and earned a great deal of money; and when he had saved up a hundred talers, he said to the old woman: ‘I must go home to my father and mother, and see them once more; so pray give me my pay.’ But the old woman took no heed of him, and said: ‘Not so fast, not so fast! work on a little longer.’

Then the youth worked on, and earned a hundred talers more; but still the old woman would not give him his pay, and said: ‘You work too quickly; you must wait a little longer.’ However, he worked on, and earned a third hundred talers; and then the old woman said: ‘Now you may have your pay.’

So she gave him a great sack, full of ducats and talers, and said: ‘Take this, and go your way.’ Then the youth took leave of the old woman, and set out on his journey homewards.

As he was travelling along, he came to a wood, and it became so dark that he could not see what he was about, and said: ‘If I but meet a good friend, I shall be happy.’ Not long was he left waiting: for a man soon came in sight, who seemed to be in great trouble, and was tearing his hair and beard, and crying out: ‘Alas! alas! how shall I provide for my poor wife and children? What will become of us?’

Then the youth took out all the money that he had earned, and gave it to the man, and said: ‘There, that is all I can give you.’ The man, seeing that the youth had nothing left, would have been well pleased; but he said: ‘No, my friend, you must work harder than that.’ Then he led him to a great hill, where a mine of gold was, and said: ‘If you will work there, and bring out the gold, I will give you food and drink, and pay you what wages I can.’

So the youth went to work, and laboured hard; and when the day was ended the man gave him a piece of bread and cheese, and said: ‘That is all I can give you for your work.’

The next day the bread and cheese were larger, and the day after they still more so; and so it went on for some days, till the piece of bread was as large as a loaf, and the cheese as big as a wheel. Then the man said to the youth: ‘You must go into the town and try to earn a living.’ ‘Where shall I go?’ said the youth. ‘I know not.’ ‘Then look up into the sky, and the first place where the sun rises will be your destination.’

The youth did as he was told, and found that the first place where the sun rose was the very town where his father lived. ‘The End’

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor woodman, who had nothing to give his wife and
children to eat, but one little piece of bread. So he put it on a dish,
and went into the field to work, leaving his wife at home alone. Now
there was a wolf in the forest, who watched all opportunities of doing
mischief, and had often made himself merry at the expense of the
woodman’s family. As the woman walked backwards and forwards between
the house and the field, carrying the pail of water or the dish of milk,
the wolf, who lay in ambush behind a tree, ran after her, and every time
she reached the house, before she had time to shut the door, he snatched
the dish or pail out of her hand, and ran off with it.

When the woodman came home to his dinner, he found the dish empty, and
saw what had happened. ‘Alas, dear wife!’ said he, ‘what shall we eat
now?’ ‘What can we do, my husband?’ answered she; ‘the wolf has taken
our one piece of bread, and I have nothing to give you but this cup of
water.’ ‘One thing at least we may do,’ said the man; ‘we will work
together, and cut some wood, and I will hew it into handles, and we will
make hoes and spades, and when spring comes we shall be able to earn
something by working in the fields for other people.’ So they agreed
that this was the best way to provide for themselves, and sat down to
consider how they should begin their work. The woman said, ‘I should like
to know if the handles are long or short.’ ‘How can I tell that?’ said
the man; ‘I leave that to you.’ Then the wife said, ‘I should like to
have a hoe, that would reach from the ground to my knee when I am working
with it.’ ‘You shall have it,’ said the man; ‘but I am glad you know so
much about these things.’ Then the wife said, ‘I should like to have a
spade likewise, that would reach from my knee to the ground when I am
working with it.’ ‘You shall have it,’ said the man; ‘you are a true
workwoman.’

The next day the man cut down a tree, and hewed it into two pieces,
one of which was as long as his wife had wished for her hoe, and the
other as long as she had wished for her spade. Then he sharpened one
end of the one, and one end of the other, and brought the tools to his
wife.

The wolf, who had seen what the man and his wife were doing, and knew
that they were making hoes and spades, could not help laughing, and said
to himself, ‘When they begin to work in the fields with these, they will
be sure to tire themselves, and I shall have plenty of opportunities
of making myself merry at their expense.’

Not long after, in the spring, all the fields were full of people,
working at the harvest. The woodman and his wife went from place to place,
offering their services, and always the wife worked with the hoe, and
the husband with the spade. Now, there was a farmer who had a field of
barley, where the ears were so long that the stalks bent down to the
ground, and the grain was very good; but the farmer could not get it all
up, so he said, ‘I will give a taler for every bushel that anyone will
pick up.’ The woodman and his wife agreed to try what they could do, and
went to the field; and the wife said, ‘I will work here, where the ground
is even, and you work by the hedge, where it is uneven.’ As they began
to work, the farmer came and looked at them; and when he saw their
strange tools, he laughed at them in his heart, and thought they would
not get much, for the hoe and the spade were not the right kind of
tools for picking up corn. However, he said nothing, but went away. The
woman worked on, and every now and then lifted up her hoe, and brought
a large dish full of corn; and the man likewise worked on, and every now
and then lifted up his spade, and brought in a dish full. The farmer came
again to look at them, and saw that the dish which the woman brought
full of corn was so heavy for her, that she could hardly carry it; and
when he went away, and came back to the field where his own people were
working, he said to them, ‘You shall not go again to the field to work,
for I have two people come who can do more than all of you; look how
they work, and how they bring in the corn.’

The farmer’s people, when they saw the woodman and his wife, were
curious to know how they could work in that manner, and went to look
on. The wolf, too, was curious to see what the woodman and his wife
would do next, and crept behind a heap of muck, that he might the better
see and hear what was going on. The man and his wife went on working,
and the woman said, ‘I must have some water to drink,’ and the man said,
‘I should like a draught of beer.’ ‘That’s right,’ said the farmer; ‘you
shall have both; only rest a while, till I get it ready.’

The wolf, who had heard all there was said, thought he should like to
have a draught of beer too, if he could get it; so he crept nearer,
that he might hear if they were going to call the farmer again. When
they began to work again, the farmer looked on, and saw that the dish
which the woman brought full of corn was so heavy for her, that she could
hardly carry it; and when he saw that, he was quite sorry to think that
two people should be able to do so much more than all his servants; so
sorry, that he could not help laughing. And when the man took up his
spade, and brought in so much corn at once, he laughed still more, and
thought to himself, ‘It is a rare thing to see people who can work like
that.’

Soon afterwards, the woman said, ‘I must have a drink of water,’ and
the man said, ‘I should like a draught of beer.’ The farmer sent his
servant boy to get it, and told him to stay with them, and see how much
they should take in at once. The boy stood behind the muck-heap, and
the wolf thought he should like to stay there too, and hear what the
boy should say, and what the man and woman should do next.

The woman went on working with her hoe, and every now and then lifted
it up, and brought in a large dish full of corn; and the man worked on
with his spade, and every now and then lifted it up, and brought in a
large dish full. The boy, who was standing behind the muck-heap, counted
how many dishes they brought in at once; and the first time it was seven,
the next time nine, and the third time eleven. When the wolf heard
that, he jumped up, and pushed the boy out of the way, and ran off with
his tail feathers flying, to get ready for merry making.

The boy was a little afraid, and ran to his master, and said, ‘I am
sure master, the woodman and his wife are very strange people; they must
be witches, for they work quite alone in the world, and nobody can tell
where they come from or where they go to.’ ‘They certainly are very
strange people,’ said the farmer; ‘but as they bring in so much corn,
they shall continue to work here; and I am quite willing to buy up all
the corn that they pick

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Magic Tinderbox

In a village once lived a poor man with his wife, who loved each other very much. They had nothing to eat, and nothing to wear, and the man went out into the wide world to try and earn some money, but he did not succeed, and came home again, and then there was nothing to be seen in their house but four bare walls. ‘Alas!’ said the wife, ‘what will become of us?’ ‘I will tell you what will become of us,’ answered the man; ‘we shall die of hunger.’ ‘Then had better do it at once,’ said the wife, ‘and make an end of it.’ So they sat down together on a bench, and took their hands from their breasts, and let them fall upon their laps, and died.

It happened that the man’s master came to the village, and hearing that his servant was dead, went to the house, and paid the woman what was due to her, and then went away again. But when the woman saw the money, she repented, and said, ‘I will not die, I will contrive to keep alive.’ So she took the money, and bought with it two fat geese, and cooked and ate one of them, and with the blood she painted two little cakes, and placed them on a dish, and set them in the bed where her late husband had slept, and then laid herself on the other side of the bed, and fell asleep.

Now it came to pass that the man’s ghost was at home, and he heard someone snoring in his bed. ‘Who is there?’ said he. ‘Lift thyself up,’ answered one, ‘and look round, and see who is here.’ Then he lifted himself up in the ghostly form in which he appeared, and looked round, and saw the bed full of fire, and the two cakes of bread roasting, and the goose broiling, and the woman lying on the other side. ‘Well,’ said he, ‘I know not who you are, but you have got the best of it, for I am your servant, and will do all you tell me to do.’ Then he laid himself down again, and the woman awoke, and saw two cakes roasted brown, and a fat goose broiled, and said, ‘Blessed be the day and night when I am so lucky again!’ So she ate and was satisfied, and when she had done, she fell asleep again.

The ghost of the man again appeared, and said, ‘What shall I bring you tomorrow?’ ‘Oh, ho!’ said she, ‘what a silly fellow you are! Can you not guess what I like best?’ ‘No,’ said he, ‘I cannot.’ ‘Then listen,’ said she; ‘I like brown bread and good ale best.’ ‘Is that all?’ said he, ‘that you like brown bread and good ale?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘that is all.’

The next morning, long before it was light, the woman got up, that she might see who would come. She had not long to wait, for there was a knocking at the door, and she heard a man say,

 ‘Open the door, my pretty maid,
  Open the door to thy grave,
  Open the door, I say!’

Then she went and opened it, and saw two men standing outside, one taller and thinner than the other, with a withered face, and a raven-black hat on his head.

‘Good day, good woman,’ said they; ‘what have you to sell?’

‘What will you sell?’ said she.

‘We will sell you brown bread and good ale,’ answered they.

‘What a lucky find!’ said she; ‘come in, come in!’

So she brought them in, and set them to table, and they ate and drank, and soon finished all that was got up that night for the ghost. When they had done, they paid her with a beautiful loaf of brown bread and a jug of ale, and said, ‘Will you not then let us have your handsome young man?’ ‘What handsome young man?’ said she. ‘Your handsome young man that is lying there in the bed.’ ‘Oh!’ said she, ‘he is but a silly fellow, and knows no better than to bring brown bread and good ale, and that is all he can do.’

The two men went their way, and the ghost of the man came and knocked at the door, and said, ‘What do you bring me today?’ ‘I bring you brown bread and good ale,’ answered he. ‘Alas!’ said the woman, ‘is that all you can do?’ ‘No,’ said he, ‘I have brought you something better; I have got money, and have bought food enough to last for a month.’ ‘Where have you been?’ said the woman. ‘I have been to the mill, and have turned the mill in exchange for the bread and ale.’

The next morning came the two men again, and knocked at the door, and said,

 ‘Open the door, my pretty maid,
  Open the door to thy grave,
  Open the door, I say!’

Then the woman opened the door, and said, ‘What will you sell?’ ‘We will sell you fine red wine and sweet cakes,’ answered they. ‘What a lucky find!’ said she; ‘come in, come in!’

So they came in, and sat down and ate and drank, and paid the woman with a large jug of red wine and a basketful of sweet cakes, and asked for her handsome young man. ‘Oh!’ said she, ‘he is but a silly fellow, and knows no better than to bring wine and cakes, and that is all he can do.’

The two men went their way, and the ghost came and knocked at the door, and said, ‘What do you bring me today?’ ‘I bring you wine and cakes,’ answered he. ‘Alas!’ said the woman, ‘is that all you can do?’ ‘No,’ said he, ‘I have been to the baker’s, and have helped him in the oven, and have got all that we could wish for.’

The two men came again the next morning, and knocked at the door, and said,

 ‘Open the door, my pretty maid,
  Open the door to thy grave,
  Open the door, I say!’

Then the woman opened the door, and said, ‘What will you sell?’ ‘We will sell you roast meats and fine beer,’ answered they. ‘What a lucky find!’ said she; ‘come in, come in!’

So they came in, and sat down and ate and drank, and paid the woman with a large dish of roast meat and a cask of beer, and asked for her handsome young man. ‘Oh!’ said she, ‘he is but a silly fellow, and knows no better than to bring roast meat and beer, and that is all he can do.’

The two men went their way, and the ghost came and knocked at the door, and said, ‘What do you bring me today?’ ‘I bring you roast meat and beer,’ answered he. ‘Alas!’ said the woman, ‘is that all you can do?’ ‘No,’ said he, ‘I have been to the butcher’s, and have helped him to kill a calf, and have got the best of the meat, and have got the best of the beer that was in the cellar.’

The two men came again the next morning, and knocked at the door, and said,

 ‘Open the door, my pretty maid,
  Open the door to thy grave,
  Open the door, I say!’

Then the woman opened the door, and said, ‘What will you sell?’ ‘We will sell you a fine fat calf,’ answered they. ‘What a lucky find!’ said she; ‘come in, come in!’

So they came in, and said, ‘We will only take our pay this time, and not sell

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a king who had a beautiful garden, planted with all sorts
of fine trees and flowers. In the midst of the garden stood a large pond
of clear water, and in the pond lived a golden fish. This golden fish
was much more beautiful than all the other fish in the pond, and it
swam about in the water with a great many small golden fishes, which
were its children.

Now it came to pass that the king fell very ill, and thought of nothing
but how he should amuse himself when he should get well. Then his court
was told to invent something that should make him merry. So they built a
beautiful palace of glass, in the garden, close by the pond, and the
king was told that in this palace lived a golden fish, which was more
beautiful than all the fish in the world. And when the king was well
enough to go out, he went into the glass palace, and looked down into
the clear water, and there he saw the golden fish swimming about with
its children. And he watched them so long that his heart rejoiced within
him, and he said, ‘I will take the golden fish home with me, and it
shall swim in a golden bowl in one of my palace rooms.’ Then the king
spoke to his court, and said, ‘How can it be brought about that the
golden fish comes home with me?’ The court answered, ‘That can be done
easily enough; you only have to send one of your people to take hold of
it, and lift it out of the water.’ But the king said, ‘No, that will not
do; the golden fish must come willingly.’ Then the cook was sent into
the garden, and told to catch the golden fish, and bring it home alive
and unwilling.

Now the cook took a large net, and went into the garden, and peeped into
the glass palace. Then he laid the net carefully over the pond, and
waited till the golden fish came close to the top. But when it saw the
net, it darted away as quickly as lightning, and the cook had waited in
vain. So he went home and told the king that it was impossible to catch
the golden fish, for it always saw the net and swam away. Then the king
said, ‘Then shall nothing be lacking for my table but the golden fish;
but when I am eating it, it shall be unwilling to come.’

The next day the cook went again into the garden, and took with him a
large piece of bread, and scattered it over the water. Then came all
the small golden fishes and many other fishes, and ate the bread, and
were quite busy in doing so. But the golden fish stayed below, and did
not come up at all. However, the cook waited till all the other fishes
had eaten enough and were finished, and then he took his net, and made
a snap at the golden fish, and brought it away with him.

As soon as the fish felt itself in the net, it knew that it should be
taken home to the king’s table unwilling, and in its grief and anger it
became as heavy as lead. The cook could hardly lift it up, and carried
it out of the garden with the greatest trouble. Then he put it into a
large bowl of water which he had brought thither with him, and carried
it in his turn to the king.

When the king saw the golden fish lying at the bottom of the bowl, he
could not help laughing, and said, ‘Alas, poor fish! thou art sure to
be eaten, but wilt thou not eat anything before thine hour comes?’ Then
the cook went and fetched some of the water out of the pond, in which
the golden fish had lived, and put some of the water-plants in the bowl
with the fish. But the golden fish did not touch a single drop of the
water, or any of the plants; and when the cook had gone away, it threw
itself backwards and forwards in the bowl with all its strength.

The king was much grieved to see this, and said, ‘Poor golden fish! wilt
thou not eat anything? I will myself fetch thee some of the finest
food. Haste ye, therefore, and let all the cooks in the palace come
here, and cook whatever they most like, and I will see whether there
is not something here that will please thee.’ Then the king had the
water out of the bowl taken away, and ordered the best cooks to come
thither and cook for the golden fish. One cooked a fine dainty of fish
from the pond, and another cooked a fine roast fish, and a third cooked
a dish of fish soup, and all other kinds of good things that fish can
eat. But the golden fish saw them all, and would not eat a single thing.

Then the king grew very angry, and said, ‘You must die, after all, but
you shall at least taste death with a good appetite. I will have you
cooked myself.’ And the cooks cut up the golden fish, and put it on the
grate, and made a fire under it, and let it roast. But the golden fish
did not stop to be roasted; it suddenly sprang out of the oven, and in
its fright leapt into the king’s face. Then the king could not help
laughing, and said, ‘Will you be at peace now? You have had your way,
and you have come home unwilling. Now eat as much as you like, only do
not forget that I am to eat you afterwards.’

Thereupon the golden fish became quite friendly, and ate heartily, and
when it had had enough, it laid itself quietly at the bottom of the
bowl, and did not move again.

The king had the bowl of water carried back to the garden, and put the
golden fish again in the pond where it had lived. And from that time
forth, it came daily to the glass palace, and let itself be taken up,
and was carried to the king’s table; and when it saw the king, it laid
itself down quietly in the bowl, and ate whatever was put before it.
And so the king always had a merry meal, for as long as he lived.

The End.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Shepherd Boy and the Wolf

In a village lived a shepherd boy, who had a faithful dog named
Sharpy. The boy was very fond of his dog, and took great care of him,
giving him plenty of food, and letting him lie in his bed with him
at night.

One day the shepherd took his flock to the wood to feed, and the boy
and Sharpy went with him. After they had been there some time, the
shepherd said, ‘I am going to look for some wood, and will not be back
until evening; take care that the sheep do not run away, and that no
wolf comes and carries one off.’

As soon as the shepherd was out of sight, the boy and Sharpy sat
down under a tree to rest, and the boy said, ‘Sharpy, we will take
turns to watch the sheep, and sleep by turns; you shall watch first,
and I will sleep a while.’ So Sharpy watched the sheep, and the boy
fell asleep.

Now it so happened that a wolf came creeping by, and seeing the sheep
so easily taken care of, began to think how he might get one of them
for his supper. At length he picked out a very fat sheep, and crept up
quite close to it, ready to pounce and kill it. But as he was getting
ready, he heard a dog snarling, and looking round saw Sharpy lying
close by the sheep. ‘That won’t do,’ said the wolf; ‘if that dog had
a mind to he would certainly bite me; I must get him out of the way.’
So the wolf crept up quietly to Sharpy, and seized him by the throat,
and shook him so that the bones rang together. Sharpy, however, held
on his ground, and bit the wolf’s face, till at last the wolf let him
go, and ran off howling, cursing, and spitting blood, into the wood.

Sharpy soon recovered, and having barked and whined till the shepherd
boy awoke, told his tale. Then the boy said, ‘Whoever that was, he
meant mischief; let us away to the shepherd, and tell him of it.’ So
they took the sheep, and went in search of the shepherd, who when he
heard what had happened was very angry, and said, ‘You have done well,
Sharpy, to defend yourself, but you should have watched more closely,
for it was a wolf who came to carry off one of the sheep.’ ‘Then,
master,’ said the boy, ‘shall I watch now, or sleep?’ ‘Watch, you
good-for-nothing,’ said the shepherd; ‘watch, and if the wolf comes,
you must give him battle, and I’ll soon come up and help you.’

So the boy watched, and Sharpy lay down close to him. After a time
the wolf came creeping up, and seeing that all was safe, began to be
of a mind to carry off one of the sheep. But Sharpy saw him, and
sprang upon him, and bit him in the leg. The wolf, however, soon got
away from him, and ran into the wood. Then the boy called out, ‘Master
shepherd, master shepherd!’ But the shepherd said, ‘Sharpy, you have
done well, go on and watch; I shall soon come up to you.’

In another hour or so the wolf came back, and determined upon a new
stratagem. He began to eat some of the grass, and made a show of
eating very heartily; then he looked round, and saw the boy sleeping,
and that Sharpy was lying down. ‘All is safe,’ said he to himself;
‘this time I shall get my sheep.’ So he crept up quietly, and was
just going to seize one, when down went Sharpy upon him, and held him
fast. The wolf, however, struggled and struggled, but all in vain;
at last he gave up all hopes of getting away, and said, ‘Will you
and I make a bargain? If you let me go, I will not touch your sheep.’
‘No,’ said Sharpy, ‘I will not let you go unless you promise not to
come back again.’ ‘That is asking too much,’ said the wolf; ‘how can I
be sure you will let me go when I have kept my word?’ ‘I don’t know,’
said Sharpy; ‘but if you will not make the bargain I shall not let
you go at all.’

So the wolf saw that he should get nothing by parleying, and said,
‘Very well, I will trust you; you shall have my word not to touch your
sheep, and not to come back again.’ ‘And now,’ said Sharpy, ‘as you
have used such cunning to get my boy to trust you, you shall have
my word not to bite you again.’

Then the wolf really went away, and did not come back to the wood for
a long time to come.

At last, however, he gathered together all the wolves in the country,
and they came creeping and crawling into the wood where the shepherd’s
flock was. And the wolf said, ‘I want to tell you that the shepherd’s
boy and his dog Sharpy are lying there, and we may get all their
sheep without any trouble.’ ‘Where are they?’ said the other wolves.
‘Asleep,’ answered the wolf; ‘they think we have forgotten them, and
do not suspect any mischief.’

Then the wolves were glad to hear this, and all of them set to work
at once to carry off the sheep. The boy and Sharpy soon awoke, and
the boy said, ‘Sharpy, we shall not be able to keep off all this
pack of wolves; let us run and give the alarm to the shepherd.’ But
Sharpy said, ‘No, we must try to save all the sheep; if we lose one
it will be a great pity; the shepherd can come and help us.’

So on they went, barking and snarling, at the wolves, and the wolves
at them; but the wolves were many, and the boy and Sharpy were but
two, and every now and then a wolf got past them, and carried off a
sheep. At last the boy saw that all was in vain, and called out as
loud as he could, ‘Shepherd, shepherd!’ But the shepherd did not come
soon, and every minute saw one of the flock carried off. At last the
shepherd came; and when he saw what had happened, and that only one
sheep was left, he called out, ‘Sharpy, Sharpy!’ Then up went Sharpy
to him, and the shepherd caught him by the ear, and scolded him, and
said, ‘You who should have watched have let all the sheep go, and I
am sure I don’t know what will become of you.’

‘Oh, master,’ said Sharpy, ‘the wolves came, and I could not help
much, for they were so many, and we were but two; and the boy here
did not help at all, for he slept all the time.’ ‘And you, my boy,’
said the shepherd, ‘why did you not come and wake me up when you
called?’ ‘I did call, master,’ said the boy, ‘but you did not hear
me.’

Then the shepherd said, ‘You have both been very silly; I have had
you both a long while, and I thought you had some sense. Sharpy, you
shall have no more sleeping by the sheep; you must lie at the end of
the village, where you will be safe; and,

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor widow who lived with her two children in a lonely cottage
among the mountains. The children were called Hans and Christel, and their
mother loved them dearly, but they had little to eat, and often went to bed
hungry.

One winter’s night, when the snow had fallen deep in the woods, and the wind
howled dismally round the cottage, Hans awoke and said to his mother, ‘I am
so hungry that I cannot sleep; let Christel and I go out and cut some wood,
and I am sure I shall be able to work up enough energy to earn something by
it.’ ‘Alas! my poor child,’ said the mother, ‘it is so dark and stormy that you
cannot go out, and even if you could, there is not a stick of wood to be had
within many a mile.’ ‘I must try,’ said Hans, ‘I will take Christel with me,
and if we are in danger we will come back.’ So they wrapped themselves in
their cloaks, and girded on their little scythes, and went forth into the
storm.

They had not gone far before they saw two lights in the distance, moving about
here and there, and going up and down like a dance. ‘See,’ said Hans to
Christel, ‘it must be good fairies who are dancing there, and they are so
merry that they are not afraid of the storm; let us go and look at them,
and if they are kind fairies perhaps they will give us something to eat.’

So they went nearer and nearer, till at last they came close to the two lights,
and saw that they were torches held in the hands of two little dwarfs, who were
working hard and gathering up the wood upon a sledge. Hans and Christel stood
watching them for a while, and then Hans cried out, ‘Why do you work so hard,
you little men?’ ‘Because,’ answered the dwarfs, ‘we have to gather wood
till daylight, and then we have not leisure so much as to light our pipes at
our ease.’ ‘What do you want with wood?’ said Hans. ‘Why, we light our fires
with it,’ answered the dwarfs, ‘and then we can warm ourselves a little, for
the storm and the cold wind are so sharp that we cannot stand it.’ ‘Where do
you live?’ asked Hans. ‘In that cavern,’ said the dwarfs, pointing to a deep
hole in the mountain. ‘How very nice and snug that must be!’ said Hans, ‘with
your fire burning all the year round!’ ‘Yes,’ said the dwarfs, ‘but the wind
blows so through the mountains that the cold air comes in, and then we have
to get up and shut the doors.’

Hans and Christel began to pity the little dwarfs, and said, ‘We will work
with you, and help you to gather wood, in return for something to eat and
drink.’ So they took each dwarf by the hand, and brought him home with them,
and when their mother saw four little men in the cottage, she was very much
frightened, and tried to push them out again; but they begged for mercy, and
said they were very cold and wet, and would only stay to dry themselves by
the fire.

So they sat down and rested, and then began to tell the children all they
knew about the world, and about the fairies and the birds and the beasts; and
they told tales of all the mischief that wicked witches and bad fairies do
in the world, and how they spoil the poor and good, and make themselves
dainty meals of them. And they told many merry tales of their own, of the
pranks they had played upon one another, and of the tricks they had played
upon the bears and the foxes, and all the birds and beasts.

When it came to be time to go to bed, the mother said, ‘Pray let us have one
of your fine torches to light us up the stairs.’ ‘With all my fortune,’ said
the dwarfs, and they gave her one of their torches, and it burned for three
days and three nights, and then went out.

The next morning the children rose early, and went with the dwarfs into the
wood to work; and Hans cut a great deal, and Christel gathered it up upon a
sledge, and the two little men watched and made all right. When noon came,
the mother brought them out a loaf of bread and a little pot of ale, and they
sat down and ate and drank, and then went on with their work till it began
to be dark. Then the children said they must go home, for they could not see
the way, but the dwarfs begged that they would take them home with them, for
they did not like to go home alone to their cold cavern.

So they took them in, and when the mother saw four people at her table she
was very much frightened, and wished that she had ten times as many to wish
them away. But they begged for some little room where they could sleep, and
at last she showed them a very small closet under the stairs. So they took
their torches and went in, and the mother shut the door and locked it. But
when she went to bed, she heard a most violent noise and clattering, as if
all the torches in the world were breaking at once, and a great part of the
house was shaken to pieces.

The next morning she went to the little room to see what was the matter, and
to her great wonder and fright the four little men were still there; but they
bowed to her very deep, and said they could not get out, for somebody had
locked the door and carried away the key. Then she was very much grieved,
and said she dared not keep them, and they said she must let them have something
to eat and drink, or they should die for hunger. So she gave them some bread
and milk, and after that they worked hard, and cut and planed and carved,
and made all kinds of beautiful things, till the mother told them they might
have whatever she had in the house, only they must tell her what they
wanted, for she would get it for them.

They worked on thus for some time, and then said they must have some clothes
to put on, for their old ones were all worn out. And the mother said, ‘I will
weave you some shirts and jackets and waistcoats and hose, of the finest linen
and the best colours, only tell me what you want each for.’ So they said,
‘One of us will have a red waistcoat, and another a yellow, and the third a
green, and the fourth a blue.’ And when the shirts and jackets were ready,
they were all pleased, and said they had never seen or worn such fine
things.

Then they said they must have hats to put on, and the mother said she would
weave them four of the finest straw hats, with broad red ribbons; and they
said she should have gold for the ribbons, and as much gold and silver as
she could carry.

But when the hats were ready, and they were going to put on the ribbons, they
said they would have no red ribbons, but that the first should have a
white, the second a yellow, the third a green, and the fourth a blue ribbon.
Then the mother was very angry, and said, ‘You ungrateful creatures! you
promised me gold for the ribbons, and I have given you the best I had, and
you like them not, and will have common colours!’ And away she went and wept
bitterly.

However, she soon comforted herself, for she found that she had more money

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Three Little Pigs and the Wolf

Once upon a time, there were three little pigs who set out to build themselves
homes. The first pig built his house of straw. The second pig built his house of
sticks. But the wise little pig built his house of bricks.

Now it came to pass that a wolf came by. ‘Halloo! Halloo!’ cried he, ‘which of
you little pigs is at home?’

‘Here am I!’ said the first pig, who lived in the straw house. ‘Come in, come
in!’ he cried, and the wolf pushed the door aside and went in, and before the
pig could say ‘How-do-you-do,’ down went wolf, with cracking and crackling. But
the wolf jumped up, shook himself, and said: ‘You silly pig, what a paltry house
you have built! I will soon finish it for you.’ So saying, he drew a deep breath,
and blew the house down. Then the wolf turned to the pig and said: ‘Now, pig,
how do you like that?’ But the pig said nothing, for the wolf had already run
out, and was hurrying down the road to the second pig’s house.

‘Halloo! Halloo!’ cried the wolf, ‘who lives here?’

‘Here I do!’ said the second pig, who lived in the house of sticks. ‘Come in,
come in!’ he cried, and the wolf pushed the door aside, and in he went. ‘How
now, pig?’ said the wolf, ‘how do you like that?’

But the pig, like the first, said nothing, for the wolf had already run out of
the house, and was making the best of his way to the brick house.

‘Halloo! Halloo!’ cried the wolf, ‘who lives here?’

‘Here I do!’ said the wise little pig, who lived in the house of brick. ‘Come
in, come in!’ cried the pig, and the wolf, thinking it was the same kind of
house as the others, pushed the door aside and went in. But the wolf soon
found out his mistake. ‘You silly wolf!’ said the pig, ‘you would have done
well to have eaten up both your brothers, and then you would have had some
brains.’

‘What’s that you say?’ cried the wolf.

‘I say,’ answered the pig, ‘that you would have done well to have eaten up both
your brothers, and then you would have had some brains.’

Then the wolf, who was very angry, cried: ‘I’ll eat you, and then you’ll have
plenty of brains to be of use to you!’

‘Come along,’ said the pig, ‘there’s plenty of room for you. If you please to
sit yourself down on that stool, and let me tie your legs with this rope, you
will save me a great deal of trouble.’

The wolf sat down, and the pig put a rope round his legs, and said: ‘Just wait
a little, I must soon fetch some water to cook you in.’

Then the pig ran out of the house, and bolted the door. ‘Wolf,’ he cried, ‘you
shall have plenty of water to drink, for you will be cooked in it.’

The wolf began to be afraid, and said: ‘I see what you are about, you sly pig,
you will be too quick for me!’

But the pig came back with a bucket of water, and threw it over the wolf’s
head, and the wolf, with a splash, went off in a rage, and the door was
bolted.

‘The End’

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
Once upon a time, there was a poor woodcutter who lived with his wife and two children in a little cottage at the edge of a great dark forest. One day, as he was going through the forest to sell his wares in the town, he cut down a tree, and as he was pulling it away, he saw a little child in ragged clothes lying on the ground and crying. ‘Poor little thing,’ said the woodcutter, ‘who has forsaken thee? Come with me, and I will take care of thee.’ So he picked up the child, and took it home to his wife, and gave it some of the milk that he had with him, and said, ‘I will take care of this little child, and we will bring him up with Dick and Mary.’ ‘Oh, yes,’ said the wife, ‘he may well have some of our milk; his mother must have died, and he will, no doubt, be thankful to have bread to eat, and fire to warm him.’

So they brought up the little child with their own, and he grew strong and healthy, and was soon as fat and rosy as Dick and Mary. But one day, as the woodcutter was going out to the forest to cut wood, he saw a man coming towards him, who seemed to be in great trouble. ‘What makes that, my friend?’ said the woodcutter. ‘Alas!’ replied the other, ‘my little child has run away from me, and I know not where to find him. Pray look in your hut, for if he has gone there, he may have been tired and gone to sleep.’ The woodcutter told him that a little child had been found in the forest, and that they had brought him up with their own children; but they knew nothing of where he came from, and had never seen anyone looking for him. ‘Oh, heavens!’ cried the man, ‘that little child must be mine! I will go with you and see him.’ Then he went in, and as soon as the little child saw him, he threw his arms round the man’s neck, and said, ‘Father! father!’ Then the man fell on his knees, and kissed him, and said, ‘Yes, indeed, my son, you are my son; I am your father, and I have been looking for you three long years.’

The woodcutter and his wife were very much grieved to see their little foster-child go away, but they could not help wishing that the poor man would provide for him, as he seemed so glad to have him back again. So they asked him if he would not take him with him into the town where he lived, for it would be a great place for him to go to, where there would be schools and everything else to teach him. ‘Yes,’ said the man, ‘I will take him with me, and I will provide for him.’ Then he took the little boy on his knee, and said, ‘Now, my son, tell me true what you were doing in the forest.’ ‘I was looking for my father,’ said the boy. ‘Where did you get that fine cloak which you are wearing?’ asked the man. ‘I found it lying on the ground,’ said the boy. ‘Where did you get the golden cup which I see you holding in your hand?’ ‘I found it in the brook,’ replied the boy. ‘And where did you get the horse that you are riding?’ ‘I found him standing at the gate of the forest,’ said the boy.

The man listened to what the boy said, and then he called his servants together, and told them what had happened. ‘Go into the town,’ said he, ‘and search in the market, and you will see a cloak there which is exactly like the one my son has got; and go to the goldsmith’s shop, and you will find a golden cup like the one he is holding; and go to the stables, and you will see a horse like the one he is riding.’ Then the servants went and looked, and everything the man had said was true; so they brought the merchant before the judge, and he was sentenced to lose his son for having stolen him.

The End

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a forester who had a faithful and diligent servant, called
Karl, who was respected and loved by all, and who had a good and honest
heart. It happened that the forester had to go into the town on some
business, and took his wife with him; so that Karl was left in charge of
the house. It was about Christmas-time, and the snow lay deep upon the
ground. One evening, as Karl was sitting by the fire, he heard a gentle
tapping at the window. He went and opened it, and saw a little grey
mouse standing outside, who said to him: ‘Oh, do let me in! The snow is
so deep, and I am so cold and hungry!’ ‘Come in then,’ said Karl, ‘and
welcome! but you must take care not to run about and disturb the
household, or you will have worse than a rod beaten for it.’ Then he
brought the mouse to the fire, and gave it a piece of bread and butter,
and set a dish of milk close by it. The mouse ate and drank, and then
stretched itself, and said: ‘Oh, it is so pleasant here! but I must go
now, or I shall be late.’ ‘Where do you want to go at this time of night?’
asked Karl. ‘I want to visit all my friends,’ answered the mouse, ‘and
every one invites me to his house, but I have such a long way to go!’

As the mouse was so pretty and pleasant, Karl could not help giving it
leave to go about the house as little as possible. The next day, when
the forester and his wife returned home, they were astonished to see a
little table and chair standing in the corner, and a small knife and fork,
and a plate and bowl, all of solid silver. ‘Who has been here?’ said the
wife. ‘I let a poor little grey mouse in last night because he was so
cold and hungry, and I think he must have got a table and chairs for
himself somewhere.’ ‘I don’t know where he got them,’ said the forester’s
wife; ‘but I don’t like the company we have been keeping, and I wish
you had not been so soft-hearted.’

The next day the forester went into the town, and the wife was alone
with Karl. In the evening, when the snow still continued to fall, she
heard a gentle tapping at the window, and opening it she saw a little
snowflake standing without, that said: ‘Let me in, I am so very cold!’
‘Where do you come from?’ asked the wife. ‘I am the king of the Snow
People,’ answered the snowflake, ‘and we have had a great feast today,
and now I am left behind, and am so very cold!’ ‘But you are not a very
large guest,’ said the wife, ‘you may come in, but you must not take
up too much room.’ Then she brought the snowflake to the fire, and gave
it a drop of brandy and a piece of sugar, and set it on a plate close
by the fire. The snowflake soon stopped shaking, and said: ‘Now I can
stay here till my people are finished with their merry-making, and then
I will go home.’ Before the night was half gone, the snowflake said: ‘I
must be going home now.’ ‘Where do you want to go at this time of night?’
asked the wife. ‘I want to visit all my friends,’ answered the snowflake,
‘and every one invites me to his house, but I have such a long way to
go!’ ‘You may go anywhere you please,’ said the wife; ‘but take care you
do not disturb my house, or you will have worse than a rod beaten for
it.’ Then the snowflake went away.

The next morning there stood on the table a great snow-sleigh with eight
snow-horses, and a little house all of solid silver. ‘Oh!’ cried the
wife, ‘what shall we do?’ The servant Karl said: ‘I think the Snow King
must have sent them as a reward for my kindness to his messenger.’ ‘But
I don’t like them,’ said the wife; ‘I am sure they bring nothing but
trouble with them.’

The forester did not come home that night, and the wife was alone with
Karl. Towards evening there was a gentle tapping at the window, and
opening it she saw a little piece of the midge fluttering about, that
said: ‘Let me in, I am so very cold and hungry!’ ‘Where do you come from?’
asked the wife. ‘I am the king of the Midge People,’ answered the midge;
‘we have had a grand feast today, and now I have been left behind, and
am so very cold and hungry!’ ‘But you are not a very large guest,’ said
the wife; ‘you may come in, but take care you don’t trouble the house,
or you will have worse than a rod beaten for it.’ Then she brought the
midge to the fire, and gave it a drop of brandy and a piece of sugar,
and set it on a plate close by the fire. The midge soon stopped shaking,
and said: ‘Now I can stay here till my people are finished with their
merry-making, and then I will go home.’ Before the night was half gone,
the midge said: ‘I must be going home now.’ ‘Where do you want to go at
this time of night?’ asked the wife. ‘I want to visit all my friends,’
answered the midge, ‘and every one invites me to his house, but I have
such a long way to go!’ ‘You may go wherever you please,’ said the wife;
‘but take care you don’t disturb my house, or you will have worse than
a rod beaten for it.’ Then the midge went away.

The next morning there stood on the table a great midges’ house all of
solid silver. ‘Oh!’ cried the wife, ‘what shall we do?’ The servant Karl
said: ‘I think the Midge King must have sent it as a reward for my
kindness to his messenger.’ ‘But I don’t like it,’ said the wife; ‘I am
sure it brings nothing but trouble with it.’

The forester did not come home the next night either, and the wife was
alone with Karl. Towards evening there was a gentle tapping at the window,
and opening it she saw a little feather from a goose standing without,
that said: ‘Let me in, I am so very cold and hungry!’ ‘Where do you come
from?’ asked the wife. ‘I am the king of the Wild Geese,’ answered the
goose feather; ‘we have had a grand feast today, and now I have been
left behind, and am so very cold and hungry!’ ‘But you are not a very
large guest,’ said the wife; ‘you may come in, but take care you don’t
trouble the house, or you will have worse than a rod beaten for it.’
Then she brought the goose feather to the fire, and gave it a drop of
brandy and a piece of sugar, and set it on a plate close by the fire.
The feather soon stopped shaking, and said: ‘Now I can stay here till
my people are finished with their merry-making, and then I will go home.’
Before the night was half gone, the feather said: ‘I must be going home
now.’ ‘Where do you want to go at this time of night?’ asked the wife.
‘I want to visit all my friends,’ answered the goose feather, ‘and every
one invites me to his house, but I have such a long way to go!’

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Enchanted Ring

In a village in the Black Forest dwelt a poor wood-cutter with his wife, and
they had one child, a daughter, who was very beautiful. And when she was twelve
years old, she was as beautiful as the prettiest bird that ever flew. And the
wood-cutter and his wife loved her dearly, and she was like a little lamb to
them.

One day the father cut too deep, and the axe fell, and the blood gushed
abundantly. He was very frightened, and cried out: ‘Alas! what shall we do? I
am dying, and who will provide for our dear little daughter?’ ‘Be quiet,’ said
his wife, ‘I will go into the forest and pray God to save your life, and I am
sure if He grants my request, I will do him one in return, and grant one wish to
the first creature, be it man or beast, that meets me.’ So she went, and when
her prayer was heard, and her husband’s life was saved, a little grey mouse
ran up to her foot, and cried out: ‘Good woman, grant me one piece of bread,
and I will be very thankful.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said the woman, ‘take
away as much as you will.’ Then the mouse spread her little feet, and took
away a lump of bread as big as a loaf, and ran away with it into the hole under
the stairs. The next day the wood-cutter’s wife went again into the forest to
pray, and said: ‘Dear God, I am so very happy that my husband’s life has been
spared, that I wish one of our dearest wishes to be granted. We have a
beautiful child, and I wish that she may some day marry a king.’ When she had
finished her prayer, and was returning home, a bird with golden wings flew
up to her, and cried out: ‘Good woman, grant me the boon of one wish, and I
will be very thankful.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said she, ‘take what you will.’
Then the bird spread its wings, and took away so much food as would have
supported the whole village for a whole year, and flew away.

Soon afterwards a suitor came from a great way off, who said he was a king’s
son, and when he saw the wood-cutter’s daughter, he was so enamoured of her
beauty that he wished to marry her. But the mother said: ‘I know the father
was once a poor man, and I have made a wish that my daughter should marry a
king.’ Then the suitor said: ‘I am a king’s son,’ and the wedding was soon
celebrated.

The young queen had a beautiful palace built, and lived there very happily
with her husband for a long time. But at length he said to her: ‘I am told
that in the Black Forest there is a hidden treasure, and I wish you would go
there, and bring me all the gold and jewels that you can find.’ Then the queen
answered: ‘I will do it gladly, for your sake, and will stay there three days
and three nights.’ So she took leave of her husband, and went her way, and
when she came to the Black Forest she heard a sound of merry music. She
followed it, and saw a company of dwarfs dancing and capering together, and
in the middle of them was a handsome young man. Then the dwarfs missed their
companion, and cried out: ‘All is lost! we have been treacherously betrayed!
has not the time come for us to take our revenge?’ And they seized her, and
took her before an old woman, who sat in judgement over them. And the old
dame said: ‘You have brought misfortune on us by your visit; we will punish
you for it, and you shall wear the iron ring.’ Then they bound her feet and
hands, and put the iron ring on her finger, and led her away to a cave.

There she saw a great heap of gold and jewels, and the dwarfs said to her: ‘You
must sit here, and count the jewels, and when you have done that, and have
worn away the iron ring, you shall be set free, and we will give you as much
as you can carry away with you.’ Then they left her alone, but she saw that
the task would be a hard one, for the ring grew larger and larger, and hurt
her finger very much. At first she counted the jewels, but when she had been
three days and three nights looking at them without being able to tell how
many there were, she was very much frightened, and began to feel very sad and
miserable.

She stayed on for seven years, and every day she took a little walk in the
cave, and at last she came to a door which she had not found before. And
when she opened it, there lay a little bread and a drop of wine, and a light
burned in the chamber. And she ate of the bread and drank of the wine, and
felt a little stronger, and sat down and watched the light. And soon the
little grey mouse, that had been her first benefactor, came crawling in, and
said: ‘Why have you forsaken us, dear queen? we have been faithful to you,
and you have forgotten us.’ Then she told them all her sorrows, and how she
had been forced to stay there against her will, and how she could not free
herself from the iron ring. But the mouse said: ‘Late at night, when all the
dwarfs are asleep, go to the door, and take off the iron ring, and throw it
into the water that runs in front of the palace, and come back and put on
another ring that lies upon a chest in your bed-chamber, and that will be
our reward.’

The queen did as she was told, and when she awoke in the morning the iron
ring was gone, and on her finger was another of gold, and the day after that
another still, and every day a finer ring, until at last all her misfortunes
were at an end. And she counted up all the jewels, and put them in a sack,
and took them with her when she went away.

She journeyed on for many days and nights, till at length she came to a
hill, and at the top of the hill sat an old man, who bade her welcome, and
said: ‘Where do you come from, dear child?’ ‘From the Black Forest,’ said
she. ‘What have you there?’ asked the old man. ‘Jewels and gold,’ answered
she. ‘How much?’ ‘Enough to support you and yours for many generations.’
‘Will you give them to me?’ said the old man. ‘No,’ said she, ‘I will keep
them for myself.’ But the old man said: ‘If you will not give them to me,
you will at least give them to my son, who is king of this country.’ Then she
said: ‘I will willingly give them to your son, on one condition; that is,
that he will take them, and not leave me without marrying me.’ The old man
agreed to this, and the son came, and married her, and they lived happily
together till the end of their days.

The End.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor woodman who cut wood in the forest, and lived with his wife in a
hut upon the outskirts of a village. One evening, as he was sitting by the fire, he
said to her: ‘I will not go into the forest again, for I am sure I shall see a bear, and
if he gets hold of me, what chance shall I have?’ ‘Do not be afraid,’ said his wife,
‘only take the little knife that I have given you, and keep it always by you.’ Next
morning, the woodman took his axe and went into the forest. Suddenly a bear met
him, and seized him so that he could not move. In spite of all his struggles, the bear
held him fast, and would have killed him, if God had not helped him. For as the bear
was tearing him with his claws, the little knife which his wife had given him, fell out
of his pocket. The bear saw the knife, and let the woodman go, that he might pick
up the knife. The woodman, therefore, quickly ran away, and the bear, thinking that
he wanted to run away with the knife, would not venture to go after him.

The woodman, however, did not run away too fast, but stood still and looked back
at the bear. Then the bear said: ‘Good woodman, why do you forsake your country?
I am a mighty sorcerer, and can grant you great riches. Only listen well to what I
say. Every year, when the cherry-trees in the valley begin to bloom, go thither and
you will find a golden egg. Take it away with you, and every day one of your children
shall sit in the forest and watch it, until another egg follows. When eight such eggs
have been gathered, a beautiful hall will stand in your country, full of gold and
silver, and you will be a rich man.’ The woodman agreed to this, and when the time
came, and the cherry-trees began to bloom, he went into the valley, and found the
first golden egg. His eldest son and daughter sat with him and watched it, and the
second year another egg was found, and the second children watched it, and so on
year by year, until all eight eggs were found, and the youngest watched the eighth.
Then a beautiful palace of gold and silver stood in the woodman’s country, full of
treasures, as the bear had said.

The woodman became very rich, and thought only of his riches, and forgot the God
who had given them to him. He no longer offered up any prayer to Him, nor did he
remember the poor and needy. And God, who sees all, was grieved at his heartlessness,
and sent a famine throughout the land. The woodman, however, still had plenty of
money, and said: ‘The Lord hath blessed me abundantly, and hath given me all these
riches, that I may enjoy them.’

Then he built a great table, and laid it with all kinds of rich fare, and sent servants
into every land, to hunt out the best wines in the world, until his cellar was full.
And every day he sat down and feasted, and grew fat and sleek, and forgot the God
who had created him.

Meantime the famine became so great that no one could support himself, and people
came from a great way to beg alms of him. But the woodman’s heart was hardened,
and he gave them nothing, and said: ‘What have I to do with the poor wretches? Let
them die and trouble me no more.’

Now there was a man in the land, whose only son was very dear to him, but he was
sick unto death, and no physician could heal him. Then his father went to the rich
woodman, and fell on his knees before him, and besought him, saying: ‘If thou wilt
give me my son again, and he shall be as other men, I will give thee all that I
have, yea, and myself will become thy servant for ever.’ The woodman looked at him
scornfully, and said: ‘I will heal thy son, but thou shalt give me thy only daughter
to wife.’ The man consented to this, and went home rejoicing, and his son was
cured.

The woodman, however, married the daughter, and thought he should now have some
rest, and could enjoy his riches in peace. But God had not forgotten him. There came
a time when he could no longer feast and make merry, for the famine became still
more cruel, and people died like flies. Then the woodman was grieved, and said:
‘I will give food to the whole land, and let mine own want what it will.’ So he
caused all his golden and silver ware to be melted down, and made bread and beef and
wine for the people, and thus the land was relieved.

And now came the bear, who had been sent by God, and said to him: ‘Why have you
done this? Why have you given food to the people? Have you forgotten that you are
a rich man, and that you have a palace full of gold and silver? You have acted like
a fool.’ Then the woodman said: ‘I am indeed a fool, but my heart is lighted within
me, and I feel as if I were quite a new man.’

The bear was angry at this, and threatened him with a still greater punishment, if
he had not used his riches as he ought. ‘I will soon come again,’ said he, and
went away.

The woodman, however, did not care what the bear said, but went on doing good to
the people, and gave away all that he had, until there remained nothing of his
riches. Then the bear came back a second time, and said: ‘Why have you done this?
Have you forgotten that you are a rich man? You have been a fool indeed!’ ‘I acknowledge
that I have been a fool,’ said the woodman, ‘but my heart is so light within me,
that I cannot help it. I feel as if I were quite a new man.’

The bear was very angry at this, and threatened him with still heavier punishment,
if he did not use his riches as he ought. ‘I will soon come again,’ said he, and
went away.

The woodman, however, did not care for the bear’s threats, but went on doing good,
and gave away all that he had, until there remained nothing of his riches. Then the
bear came back a third time, and said: ‘Why have you done this? Have you forgotten
that you are a rich man? You have been a very foolish man indeed!’ ‘I acknowledge
that I have been a fool,’ answered the woodman, ‘but my heart is so light within
me, that I cannot help it. I feel as if I were quite a new man.’

The bear was very angry at this, and cried out: ‘You refractory rascal! You have
used my treasures, but have given them away again. Now then, you shall fare as I
am pleased to will. You shall become a bird, and fly away through the world, and
never more return to your country.’ So the woodman at once took wing, and flew
away, and his wife went with him. Thus were they punished for having forgotten God.

The bear went to the palace, and cried out with his mighty voice: ‘I am a mighty
sorcerer, and have power over all the world. Every year, when the cherry-trees in
the valley begin to bloom, go thither and you will find a golden egg. Take it away
with you, and every day one of your children shall sit in the forest and watch it,
