prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Snow Queen

Long, long ago, in the cold country up under the North Star, there lived a poor old woman, who could foretell the future. She had a beautiful daughter, whose eyes were like the prettiest stars in the sky. One day, when the little girl was playing by the sea, a burning coal from a ship that passed by fell into her eye, and the old woman was so frightened, that she said: ‘The bloodthirsty Snow Queen has pierced your eye with her arrow, and you will die some day.’ Then she took a brush of fine sable, and painted an eye in the girl’s face, so that no one should know that the real eye was gone.

Poor Lina had to keep herself hidden away from the world, for she was very beautiful, and everyone who saw her was made unhappy.

One day, when the snowflakes were falling around, and the rosy clouds in the sky looked like flames, the Snow Queen came and knocked at the door. ‘Lina, Lina,’ cried she, ‘why do you hide yourself so? Come with me, and you shall see the most beautiful things in the world.’ Then the old woman wept, but the Snow Queen said: ‘There, I have frozen her heart, and she will never care for you again.’ So she took poor Lina away with her, and they flew over the sea in a sled drawn by reindeer, till they came to the Palace of the Snow Queen.

There were countless rooms in the palace, all full of the most wonderful things; but Lina felt very sad, and knew that she should never be happy again.

Once the Snow Queen said: ‘Lina, will you go with me and look at the world as it lies beneath the sea?’ Then she took her by the hand, and they went out on the sea-ice, and the Snow Queen clapped her hands, and all the sea was cleared away, and they could look down and see the fish swimming about in the red coral groves. But Lina felt very sad, and the Snow Queen said: ‘There, I have frozen her heart, and she will never care for you again.’

Another time the Snow Queen said: ‘Lina, will you go with me and see how the stars are made?’ Then she took her by the hand, and they went out upon the sea-ice, and the Snow Queen clapped her hands, and all the stars came sailing down in the sky, and they might have caught them and kept them, if they liked. But Lina felt very sad, and the Snow Queen said: ‘There, I have frozen her heart, and she will never care for you again.’

And so it went on; they went to the sun and the moon, and looked at the earth from afar; they saw the birds in the air, and the animals upon it, and the fishes in the sea; but Lina felt very sad, and the Snow Queen said: ‘There, I have frozen her heart, and she will never care for you again.’

At last the Snow Queen said: ‘Lina, will you go with me and see how people are made?’ Then she took her by the hand, and they went out upon the sea-ice, and the Snow Queen clapped her hands, and all the good and bad people in the world began to come together, and stood before them in a great crowd. The Snow Queen said: ‘Lina, shall we take the good people, and make them into palaces and churches, and make the world beautiful with them?’ ‘No,’ said Lina, ‘that would not be right; for good people are the best adornment for the world.’ Then the Snow Queen took the bad people, and clapped her hands, and they were all stuffed into a needle, and then the needle was thrown into the sea. ‘There,’ said she, ‘I have taken away all the wickedness from the world; and now, Lina, your heart is quite frozen, and you will never care for anyone.’

But Lina wept, and said: ‘Alas! what will become of me?’ ‘You shall be queen here,’ said the Snow Queen, ‘and rule over soft snowflakes, and dance with me round the moon.’

Then the Snow Queen clapped her hands, and a great crowd of snowflakes came flying in the air, and one of them said: ‘Who is the most beautiful here?’ ‘I am,’ said another. ‘No, I am,’ said a third. ‘Let us have a trial, and decide the matter between us,’ said the Snow Queen; ‘the most beautiful of us shall be queen, and Lina shall be second, and shall be queen of the stars.’ Then they began to dance and twirl round in the air; and Lina felt very sad, and thought: ‘I know very well that the Snow Queen will be queen over the snowflakes, for she is so much more beautiful than I am.’

But the stars danced down from the sky, and the first star that came was the Morning Star; then came the Evening Star; and they danced in among the snowflakes, and the Morning Star said: ‘Who is the most beautiful here?’ ‘I am,’ said one. ‘No, I am,’ said another. ‘Let us have a trial, and decide the matter between us,’ said the Morning Star; ‘the most beautiful of us shall be queen of the heavens, and shall ride in the chariot of the sun.’ Then they began to dance and twirl round in the air; and the Snow Queen felt very sad, and thought: ‘I know very well that the Morning Star will be queen of the heavens, for she is so much more beautiful than I am.’

And the Morning Star said: ‘Who is the most beautiful here?’ Then the Evening Star said: ‘That I certainly am not.’

‘And I am not either,’ said the stars that dance in the daytime.

‘And I am not either,’ said the stars that shine in the night-time.

‘And I am not either,’ said the comet.

‘And I am not either,’ said the meteor.

‘And I am not either,’ said the falling-star.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Milky Way.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Aurora Borealis.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Aurora Australis.

‘And I am not either,’ said the North Star.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Little Bear.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Great Bear.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Pleiades.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Seven Brothers.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Twins.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Hunter.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Chariot of the Sun.

‘And I am not either,’ said the Moon.

Then the Morning Star said: ‘I am the most beautiful of all, and therefore shall be queen of the heavens, and ride in the chariot of the sun.’ And the Evening Star said: ‘I am the most beautiful, and shall be queen of the heavens, and ride in the chariot of the sun.’ And the Morning Star said: ‘Let us have a trial, and decide the matter between us.’

Then the Morning Star went and rode in the chariot of the sun for a whole day; and the Evening Star went and rode in it for a whole day; and the Morning Star said: ‘Look, my stars, how beautiful I look in the chariot of the sun!’ ‘Yes,’ they said, ‘you look very beautiful.’ Then the Evening Star came and said: ‘Look, my stars, how beautiful I look in the chariot of the sun!’ ‘Yes,’ they said, ‘you look very beautiful.’

And the Morning Star said: ‘I will ride in the chariot of the sun for a whole year, and then my beauty will be still more

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor old woman who had two daughters, one beautiful and good, and one ugly and wicked. The old woman loved her eldest daughter very much, but the wicked girl was very ungrateful, and scorned her mother because she was so poor, and said she would have nothing to do with her any more. So the old woman left her to shift for herself, and took her eldest daughter into her house, and loved her, and cherished her, and she helped her mother in all her work.

It happened that some rich visitors came to the country, and the old woman heard that they were in search of a girl to be a chambermaid. She at once sent her eldest daughter to them, but the wicked girl heard of it, and envied her sister so much that she slipped behind her, and ran as fast as she could to the place where the visitors were, and got there first, and said she was the eldest daughter. The visitors did not know any better, and took her into their service, and she thought now she should have a good time, and be very happy. But her mistress did not keep her long. She was very silly and clumsy, and spoiled everything she touched, and the servants laughed at her behind her back, and she did not know it.

Her sister, in the meantime, stayed at home with her mother, and helped her in all her work, and was very kind and good to her. And one day as they were sitting together by the fire, the old woman said, ‘I should like to see my other daughter once again, she was so pretty and so well behaved.’ Then the other said, ‘If it please you, I will go and bring her, for she must be very sorry and unhappy to be left alone with no one to take care of her.’ ‘No, no,’ said the old woman, ‘that would be impossible; she has left me quite alone, and I can never repay such kindness. She knows very well how poor we are, and yet she has forsaken us, and I would not on any account go and trouble her.’

But her daughter said, ‘I will go and find her, and if she will not come back with me, I will at any rate take a message to her.’ ‘Well,’ said the old woman, ‘if it please you, go, but take care of yourself.’

Then the good girl put on her bonnet, and took a loaf of bread in her bag, and set out on the road in search of her sister. It was a long way, and the road was very bad, and she had to walk a long way before she came to the town where her sister lived. And as she was very hungry, she took out the loaf of bread, and cut herself a slice, but it was all spoiled, and turned sour in her mouth. Then she said, ‘Alas! alas! what shall I do? I cannot go back, and I cannot go on; my sister will think I have run away, and forgotten all about her.’

While she was thinking what to do, a little dwarf came up to her, and said, ‘Why are you so sad?’ ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I am very hungry, and my bread is sour, and I do not know what to do.’ Then the little dwarf took pity on her, and said, ‘I will give you a piece of bread that will taste sweet to you, though it be as sour as vinegar to other people.’ So he gave her a small piece of bread, and she ate it, and it seemed to her as if she had never tasted anything so sweet and dainty in all her life. Then she thanked the little dwarf very much, and said, ‘I cannot give you anything in return, for I have nothing but this old knife.’ And she gave him her knife, which was not of any use to her, for it had one side straight, and the other wavy.

The little dwarf said, ‘That is a very odd knife, but as you seem so grateful, I will give you three wishes; you may choose whatever you like.’ Then the good girl thought for a while, and said, ‘I like everything well enough, but I do not know what to wish for; I will take care not to use up all my wishes at once.’ So she thanked the little dwarf, and said she would think about it, and then went on her way.

She walked on till it became dark, and then she saw a large castle in the distance, and she thought she would rest there for the night. So she knocked at the door, and a servant came and said, ‘What are you seeking?’ ‘I seek a night’s lodging,’ said she. ‘It is late, and I am very tired.’ Then the servant said, ‘My mistress will not be at all pleased to see you, for she does not like to have any one stay in the castle at night.’ ‘If that be the case,’ said the girl, ‘I will go away again; but do tell me where I can find a night’s lodging.’ ‘You had better go to the mill,’ said the servant; ‘the miller will be very glad to have you.’

Then the girl went to the mill, and the miller said, ‘O that you had come half an hour earlier! for I was just going to light up the oven, and then you should have had some good bread to eat.’ So she stayed with the miller all night, and in the morning he gave her some beautiful sweet bread, for the bread that she had brought with her had all been spoiled.

Then she set out on her way again, and in the afternoon she came to the town where her sister lived. And the little dwarf came to meet her, and said, ‘I see you want to go into that town, so I will go with you.’ Then he took her by the hand, and they went into the town together.

The wicked girl was just then standing in the street, and when she saw her sister she looked very much surprised, and said, ‘Where have you sprung from? I thought you had run away, and had forgotten all about me.’ ‘No,’ said the other; ‘I have had a very long walk, for I went to visit my mother, who lives a great way off.’ Then the servant came up, and said, ‘My mistress will be very glad to see you, for she has been looking for you a long while.’

When the wicked girl went in to her mistress, she thought to herself, ‘I will soon set my sister at work, and then she will get into trouble, and I shall laugh at her.’ So she said, ‘Mistress, may not I tell you what? I am very much tired; pray let my sister take my place, and I will go out and rest.’ But the mistress said, ‘No, no,’ that was not necessary; she could rest whenever she pleased.

However, the wicked girl was very insistent, and at last her mistress said, ‘Very well,’ if her sister would exchange places with her, she might do as she liked. Then the other said, ‘I don’t know how the business is managed; I never was chambermaid in my life.’ But her sister said, ‘I will help you all I can, and if you get into any trouble, I will take your place.’

So they exchanged places, and the wicked girl went out, and the other took her place. And the servant came up, and said, ‘My mistress wants her room swept out.’ Then the good girl got on her hands and knees, and began to sweep; but the bad one said, ‘How silly you are!’ and took the broom from her, and gave her a besom, which was so hard and brittle that it broke in two pieces as soon as she touched it. Then the good girl said, ‘I see I cannot sweep the room; what am I to do?’ ‘Why,’ said the bad one, ‘I will tell you what; take this dish, and go into the kitchen, and bring me some hot coals.’

So she took the dish, and went into the kitchen, and said, ‘The chambermaid sends you the dish

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Enchanted Ring

There was once a poor old woman who had only one hen left in the world,
on which she wholly lived. This hen at length put brood, and hatched out
five chicks. As the old woman was standing over the brood, and could not
easily get away, the youngest chick, without waiting to be called, ran
under her left arm, and the other four ran under her right. She was
thereupon forced to remain standing a while longer, and as she stood she
fell into a brook that ran near her house. She was in a fair way to be
drowned, but the five chicks cried so piteously that their mother came
running, and drew her out. When she had recovered from her fright, she
took care to build a bridge over the brook, that she might be able to go
thither whenever she wanted to look after her hen and chicks.

Some time after this, she went there, and took with her a cake and a
flask of wine. As she sat by her hen and chicks, enjoying her dinner,
she saw a gold ring lying in the grass, which glittered like fire. ‘What
can this be,’ said she, ‘and who can have left it here?’ Then she took
it up, and put it on her little finger, where it fitted so well that it
seemed as if it had been made for it.

She had not sat there long before she heard a gentle voice behind her
say:

 ‘Put your hand in your bosom!’

The old woman started so that she fell against a stone, but she answered
nothing, but put her hand in her bosom.

The voice then spoke again:

 ‘Take the ring off thy finger!’

But she was so fond of the ring that she did not venture to do it, and
answered nothing.

The fifth time that the old woman heard the voice, she plucked up her
courage, and took the ring off her finger, and put it in her pocket.
Then she turned round, but there was nothing to be seen.

She had, however, no peace the rest of the day, but heard a continual
whispering and buzzing in her ears. The next day she went to the brook
again, and sat down by her hen and chicks. The whispers and buzzing in
her ears soon began again, and she heard a soft voice that seemed to
come from the ring in her pocket, saying:

 ‘Lift up thy thumb!’

But the old woman did not venture to do it.

The third time that the voice spoke, and said:

 ‘Take the ring out of thy pocket!’

she was afraid, and took it out, but put it on her finger again as soon
as she had done this.

The old woman heard no more whispers or buzzing in her ears, but as she
was going home in the evening, the ring said:

 ‘Pick up the stone!’

and pointed to a stone lying in her path.

The old woman stooped down and picked up the stone, and when she did
so a dwarf appeared, that was so small that he could with great difficulty
fill the palm of her hand. He besought her, with many words, not to be
angry with him for having thus troubled her, and said: ‘I have been
forced to take up my abode in the stone, and have been near starving.
Have pity on me, and take me with you.’

The old woman was at first unwilling, but the dwarf said: ‘If you will
not take me in, I must go back to the stone, and my torment will soon be
so great that I shall be forced to cry out, and then everyone within a
mile of me will hear me.’

Then the old woman said: ‘Little as you are, you shall have room to
move about with me, for I like you very well.’

So she put the dwarf into her pocket, and took him home with her.

The next morning she took him out, and he was so much pleased with the
sun shining on him, and with the air he breathed, that he danced for joy,
and said: ‘I have not felt so well for a long time.’

The old woman took the dwarf with her wherever she went. He always
remained in her pocket, and came out in the evening to visit her. He
was, too, a very good friend to her, for he told her when she should have
good luck in her hen, and when she should not.

Once when she was going to make a broth for herself, her dwarf said to
her: ‘Wait a while, I hear people coming.’

So she waited until two men came by, who began to sit down under a tree
to rest. The old woman took her hen, and ran to then, and said: ‘I am
so hungry that I will give you a piece of roasted meat, if you will let
me have the bones.’

The men said: ‘We have no money to buy anything, but will willingly
give you our two fine young chickens for the roasted meat.’

The old woman said: ‘I will not part with my roasted meat for your
chickens,’ but the dwarf in her pocket whispered to her: ‘Take the
chickens.’

So she took them, and when she got home she gave them to her hen to
lodge, and they hatched out between them twenty-five chicks each.

The old woman now became very rich, for she sold the chickens and their
chicks to the countrypeople, and became the richest woman in the land.

But she thought to herself: ‘I will not stop here; I must go and try my
luck in a strange country,’ and she took with her the dwarf, who always
remained in her pocket.

They travelled on and on, until at last they came to a great city, and
there was a palace in the middle of it, that shone like the sun. ‘This
must be the royal palace,’ said the old woman to the dwarf, ‘and here
must we try and get in.’

The dwarf said: ‘Wait a while, I hear people coming.’

So they waited until the queen came out to take the air. ‘Now,’ said
the dwarf, ‘go up to her, and pinch her in the leg.’

The old woman went up to the queen, and as the dwarf had told her, she
pinched her in the leg, so that she screamed out.

The king came running to see what was the matter, and wanted to know
what had happened. The queen was obliged to tell him that an old woman
had pinched her, and he said: ‘I will give the old offender up to justice,
if she can be caught.’

The old woman and the dwarf went into a narrow lane to hide themselves,
but the king’s guards were ordered to seize her on the spot, and take
her before the king.

When she was before the king, he asked her if she had pinched the queen,
and she said: ‘Yes, your majesty, and if it had not been for that, your
majesty’s wife would soon have been dead.’

‘What do you mean by that?’ said the king. ‘You shall have nothing
but death for your pains.’

The dwarf in the old woman’s pocket now whispered to her: ‘Tell a tale,
and say that you are a famous witch, and that you can change yourself
into all sorts of shapes.’

Then the old woman began her tale, and said: ‘Your majesty, I am a
wonderful witch, and can change myself into all sorts of shapes. I can
change myself into a bird, and fly round the sun; I can change myself
into a fish, and swim in the

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a miller who had one beautiful daughter, and as she was
growing up she became very beautiful indeed; and when she was fully grown
the miller said, ‘I will give her to the man who can do the most for
her.’ Now a king’s son came and boasted that he could do much for her,
and he was followed by a poor soldier, who said modestly that he could
do very little. But the miller said, ‘Neither words nor promises: show
us what you can do.’ Then the king’s son said, ‘I will set her in the
highest window of the castle, so that she may be seen from afar.’ And the
soldier said, ‘I will give her a roast chicken every day.’ When the king’s
son had said this, he rode away; but the soldier stayed on, and every
day he brought a fowl which he roasted, and served it up to the miller
and his daughter. And thus for a long time the two were very happy
together.

But at last the soldier said, ‘I must have some sign of our union, so
I have asked a next of mine to come and cut a piece of wood out of his
house for me.’ Now the soldier was a tailor, and his friend who came was
his wife, who had cut a rafter out of their house. And she brought with
her a little child, which she said was her nephew, but was really her
daughter. And she besought the soldier to take her in, as she was a
poor woman, and had nobody in the world to help her. Then the soldier
took her into his house, and said to the miller’s daughter, ‘This is my
mother, and this is my little brother.’

After a while the soldier said to the miller, ‘I have served you long
enough; now I want you to say when I am to take my wife home.’ And the
miller answered, ‘You must take her home directly.’ But the soldier said
to his wife, ‘Be careful and see to it that we take away with us all
our furniture.’ Then the miller’s daughter went to her room to get
her things ready for her journey, and when she opened her trunk the
little girl ran in and took it away. But the girl saw a looking-glass
in which she knew her mother wanted to look, so she ran with it out of
the trunk and kept it for herself. The next day the soldier came to take
his wife away, and as they were going out the miller said, ‘I am now
going to judge: you have won my daughter, and you must do as I tell you.
You must take her with you on the same donkey which you rode when you
came here.’ Now the soldier was a strong man, and he got on first, and
his wife mounted behind him, and the little girl got on behind her
mother, and they all rode off on one donkey.

When they got to the soldier’s house the wife said, ‘I am very tired;
I must lie down and rest a while.’ So she went into the room where the
looking-glass was, and said to the child, ‘Take me up that looking-glass,
I want to look in it.’ Then the little girl took the looking-glass in
her hands, and held it before her mother’s face, and as she did so she
wished her mother and herself away, and in a moment they both vanished,
and only the little girl remained. And the soldier said, ‘I am now
master of the house, and you are my daughter.’ And from that time
forth he had a merry little wife, who was always singing and dancing,
and everybody said, ‘Blessed be the day which brought her to us!’ And
the miller’s daughter went home to her father, and they lived happily
together until the miller died, and then she went back to the soldier,
and they lived happily together all the rest of their days.

The End.

The Wolf and the Seven Little Kids

In a dark forest dwelt a wolf who was very much respected by all the beasts,
because he was the eldest and wisest of the woods. Now it came to pass that
this wolf had seven little kids, who played about the forest and were very
merrily off, but they were very, very naughty. They tore up the old men’s
beards, and pulled the old women’s hair, and pinched the little children
when they could catch them, and did a great many other mischievous things.

At last the wolf called them all before him and said, ‘You must either
become good, or I will eat you up every one.’ But they were not at all
frightened, and said they would run away and never come back to their
father any more. Then the wolf let them go, and thought no more about
them, for a long while.

One day as he was walking by himself in the forest, he heard a most piteous
crying, and he followed the noise, and it seemed to come from a thick
bush. When he got there he found a little lamb lying on the ground, with
its legs and tail bound fast together, and the shepherd’s dog standing
close by it, barking and making a great noise. ‘You wicked beast,’ said the
wolf, ‘what have you done?’ ‘Hark ye,’ said the dog, ‘the lamb was so
naughty, and butted my master with its horns, so I have bound it and will
run and fetch the shepherd, and he will know what to do with it.’

Just then came the shepherd in sight, and the wolf said, ‘Pray, good man,
what will become of your lamb?’ ‘Oh!’ said he, ‘it is lost; it must be killed,
for it has been so bad and vicious that it has butted my little boy, and
butted my girl, and butteted all about the place, till I could not keep
it any longer: so I have made up my mind to kill it directly.’ ‘Lord have
mercy on you,’ said the wolf, ‘and spare its life; I will take it with me
into the forest, and it shall be as safe there as a king in his palace.’
The shepherd saw that the wolf was very fond of the lamb, and would take
care of it, so he said he would not kill it, but would willingly give it
to the wolf to keep. Then the wolf took it up in his mouth, and went away
with it into the forest, and the little lamb soon became quite at home
there, and ran about with the seven little kids, and butted all the old
beasts about the forest, and was as merry as could be.

One day the wolf said to the little lamb, ‘Your master the shepherd has
made a hole in your right ear with his club for butting people; pray take
care not to butt anybody, or else he will come and take you away, and I
shall be very sorry to lose you.’ ‘Don’t worry yourself about that,’
said the little lamb; ‘I’ll take care not to butt anybody.’

Another day the wolf called the little lamb aside, and said, ‘Your master
the shepherd has made a hole in your left ear with his staff for butting
people; pray take care not to butt anybody, or else he will come and take
you away, and I shall be very sorry to lose you.’ ‘Don’t worry yourself
about that,’ said the little lamb; ‘I’ll take care not to butt anybody.’

But one day, when the wolf was away, up came a little goat, and the little
lamb, that could not help itself, gave it a butt in the side with its
horn, and said, ‘There, you are fat and sleek, and can take it.’ Then the
goat said, ‘You rogue, you have butted me, and I’ll tell my master, and he
will not let you live in the forest any longer.’ Then the little lamb was
very much frightened, and said, ‘Alas! what shall I do?’ So the goat ran
away, and soon came up to the old goat. ‘Guess who I have in my mouth,’
said the little goat. ‘What? The little lamb?’ said the old goat. ‘Yes,
that’s right,’ said the little goat. ‘Well, he’s had the cheek to butt
me.’ Then the old goat said, ‘I’ll soon take him away from you; he’s no
fit to live in the forest.’ So the old goat went with the little goat to
the wolf, and said, ‘Dear Mr Wolf, that bad little lamb of yours has been
butting my little goat, and I’m sure he’ll be doing other people a bad
turn some day or other; pray take him away.’ ‘Where are you, little lamb?’
said the wolf. ‘Here I am,’ answered the little lamb. ‘How can you be so
naughty?’ said the wolf. ‘I’m not naughty,’ said the little lamb. ‘Yes,
you are,’ said the wolf, ‘and you shall die for it.’ Then he ate up the
little lamb, and the old goat went away.

A short time after, the wolf called one of his kids to him, and said, ‘My
little kid, you are very pretty, and I’m sure you’ll be a fine sheep some
day; but you must take care you don’t run about the forest and butt
everybody, or I shall be forced to eat you up.’ ‘Don’t worry yourself
about that,’ said the little kid; ‘I’ll take care not to butt anybody.’

Another day the wolf called the little kid aside, and said, ‘Your master
the shepherd has made a hole in your right ear with his club for butting
people; pray take care not to butt anybody, or else he will come and take
you away, and I shall be very sorry to lose you.’ ‘Don’t worry yourself
about that,’ said the little kid; ‘I’ll take care not to butt anybody.’

But one day, when the wolf was away, up came a little calf, and the little
kid, that could not help itself, gave it a butt in the side with its
horn, and said, ‘There, you are fat and sleek, and can take it.’ Then the
calf said, ‘You rogue, you have butted me, and I’ll tell my master, and he

said the calf. ‘What? The little kid?’ said the old bull. ‘Yes, that’s
right,’ said the calf. ‘Well he’s had the cheek to butt me.’ Then the old

pray take him away.’ ‘Where are you, my kid?’ said the wolf. ‘Here I am,
sir,’ answered the little kid. ‘How can you be so naughty?’ said the wolf.
‘I’m not naughty,’ said the little kid. ‘Yes,

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
Once upon a time, there was a poor woodcutter who lived with his wife and two children in a little cottage at the edge of a great forest. They had nothing to live upon but one loaf of bread, and one glass of milk a day. Sometimes when there was no work to be done in the forest, the man would go there with his little axe to cut fuel, that he might at least have a fire in the evening; and his wife would say to him, ‘Be careful that you do not stay too late, for I am uneasy when you are gone.’ But he always answered, ‘Don’t worry, I’ll be back long before night.’

One day, as he was going through the forest, he heard a strange noise, as if someone was crying for mercy. He listened, and heard it again; so he left his axe and went to see what was happening. When he came to the spot, he saw a little old woman, with a very high, pointed hat, sitting on a mossy stone, and her face was all covered with blood. ‘Good woman,’ said the woodcutter, ‘what has happened to you?’ ‘Ah,’ answered she, ‘I have been out walking in the forest, and the branches of a tree caught me and scratched my face; carry me home with you, and I will be grateful to you for all you can do for me.’ The woodcutter lifted her up, and carried her home to his wife, who at first was afraid of the blood-stained face, but at last took pity on her, and allowed her to lie upon the bed. Then the woodcutter fetched some white cloths, and bound up her face, and she said to him, ‘Little as you are, you have a strong arm, and are good and kind-hearted; if you will do anything that I ask you to do, I will be your friend, and will grant you three wishes.

The woodcutter said, ‘I will think of that.’ Then his wife gave the little old woman something to eat and drink, and she ate and drank, and very soon began to recover strength.

When it was dark, the woodcutter and his wife went to bed; but he forgot all about the three wishes, and lay awake a long time thinking of his troubles. At last he got up, and went to the little old woman, and said, ‘I have thought of what you said; you shall be my friend, and grant me three wishes.’ ‘Very well,’ said she; ‘what are they to be?’ ‘First,’ said the woodcutter, ‘I wish that I may always have plenty of food for my wife and children.’ ‘Your wish is granted,’ said the old woman.

Then the woodcutter went back to bed, but he lay awake a long time thinking; at last he got up again, and went to the little old woman, and said, ‘I have thought of another wish; I wish that I may always have plenty of money.’ ‘Your wish is granted,’ said the old woman.

Again the woodcutter went to bed, but he lay awake all night thinking; at last, just as the first cock crowed, he got up and went to the little old woman, and said, ‘I have thought of my third wish; I wish that you would take me to the fairies’ feast.’ ‘That is no easy thing to do,’ said the old woman; ‘the fairies are very angry with you for cutting down their tree, and they want to take your life.’ Then the woodcutter begged so hard for it, that the old woman at last said, ‘I will do what you wish, but you must be careful and do nothing wrong, or you will be in danger.’

The next morning, as the woodcutter was going out, the little old woman gave him a cloak that would make him invisible, and said, ‘Put it on when you go to the feast.’

Then the woodcutter went straight to the fairies’ feast; and when he got there, the fairies were sitting in a ring, dancing and singing:

 ‘Round and round the ring goes merrily,
  Ring the living rosary!
  Here’s a health to the fairies’ glee,
  Ring the living rosary!’

And as they sang and danced, they threw down nuts and apples, and all sorts of sweet things; and now and then a fairy would throw a gold piece into the ring.

The woodcutter stood still and watched them; and when they had been dancing a while, they took a walk in the wood, and left a fairy sitting in the ring. Then the woodcutter put on his cloak, and took the fairy’s place in the ring, and the fairies came back and took him for the fairy, and danced and sang as before, and threw down nuts and apples, and all sorts of sweet things; and now and then a fairy would throw a gold piece into the ring.

So the woodcutter gathered together a great many nuts and apples, and a large sum of money; and when the fairies came back, they took him for the fairy, and did not know him, and took him with them into the wood. Then he followed them, and listened to all their secrets; and they told him how they got their power of enchanting men and women, so that they did what the fairies wished, and how they could make themselves invisible, and could take any form they pleased.

When he had learned all this, he was still not satisfied; so he stayed till they came to a great lake, in the midst of which there was an island, and on the island stood a palace of gold and crystal. ‘That is the fairies’ palace,’ said they to him; ‘and there live the king and queen of the fairies.’ Then he wished himself at home; and when he awoke, he found that it was all a dream.

However, when he went to the forest to cut fuel, there lay a great pile of nuts and apples at his feet; and when he went home in the evening, there were a heap of gold in the corner of the room. And so, from that time forward, there was plenty of money for the woodcutter and his wife and children.

Then the woodcutter built a large house, and the old woman went to live there with him; and she told him that he had one more wish, and that he might wish for anything in the world. At first he did not know what to wish for; then he thought of his old mother, who was very poor and unhappy, and he wished that she might be rich and happy. Then the old woman said, ‘Your mother is already rich and happy; go and see for yourself.’

So the woodcutter went to his mother’s house, and there he really found his mother rich and happy; for on one side of her stood a heap of gold as large as a calf, and on the other side a pile of nuts and apples almost as large; and around her stood all her old friends, feasting and making merry.

Then the woodcutter was very glad, and he stayed and feasted with them; and when he was going away, his mother begged him to stay and be her companion; but he said, ‘I cannot stay, for I have a wife and children.’ ‘Then at least do this,’ said his mother; ‘stay with me for three days and nights.’ But the woodcutter said, ‘I cannot do even that; for I must earn my living.’ ‘Then do this,’ said his mother; ‘take this sack of gold, and lay it by your mother’s side in the bed, and then you will have done all I ask you.’

So the woodcutter took the sack of gold and laid it by his mother’s side in the bed; and when he wanted to go away, he pushed the old woman, that she should get up; but the sack of gold rolled away, and the old woman fell down dead. Then he was very sorry, and went to his wife and children, and lived happily to the end of his days.

The End.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
Once upon a time, there was a poor old woman who lived in a hut on the outskirts of a village. She gathered fuel for herself in the forest, and one day as she was gathering wood, she found a little child, half-dead, and scarcely breathing. She took pity on it, and carried it home with her, and took care of it, and nursed it, and it soon became well. ‘Poor little thing,’ said she, ‘who hath abandoned thee in the forest, and how shall I dispose of thee?’ She thought a while, and then said, ‘I will take thee to the mill, and give thee to the miller’s wife, who will take care of thee.’ So she took the child and carried it to the mill, and gave it to the miller’s wife, who had long wished for a child, and said she would take good care of it.

The old woman went her way, thankful in her heart that she had saved the child’s life. The miller’s wife loved the child dearly, and took great care of it, and it grew strong and healthy, and was as happy as a child could be in so poor a house.

One day the miller said to his wife, ‘Let the child have something to ride upon, that it may have some pleasure.’ So the wife made a little sledge for the child to ride upon, and it was very pleased with it, and whenever the miller went out, or the miller’s wife went to the village, the child took its little sledge and went with them.

Now this sledge had a very strange fate. Wherever the child took it, it was sure to meet with some mishap; the sledge would either overset, or the child would fall off, or the wheels would come off, or the axle-tree would break, or the sledge would catch in a hole and drag the poor child along upon the ground. Nothing would do but the sledge was bewitched. Then the miller and his wife were very sad, for they did not know what to do, and they were afraid to let the child go out at all.

Meanwhile the child grew bigger, and began to run about by itself, and one day the miller said to his wife, ‘The child is big enough to help me in the mill; he can run the wheel, and set the sacks upon the donkey, and bring the meal down from the loft; so let us try him.’ The wife agreed, and the next morning the child went with the miller to the mill.

The mill was situated in a wood, and the day was warm, so the child said to the miller, ‘It is very warm, I am sure, let the windows be opened.’ But the miller said, ‘The wind might blow the cinders into the fire, and put it out, so we had better not open the windows.’ However, the child again said, ‘It is very warm, I am sure, let the windows be opened, or else I shall be choked.’ Then the miller said angrily, ‘Do you think you are the only one who is to work in the mill? Do you think nobody was here before you? Go up to the loft and fetch the meal, and stop your chattering.’

So the child went up to the loft and brought the meal down, but as he was going up he looked through a crack in the ladder and saw a little grey old man sitting in the corner. ‘Bless me!’ said he, ‘what a funny little man! I’m so glad I’ve seen him!’ and he clapped his hands for joy. But the little grey man fumed and blew, and said, ‘Unwise child! why hast thou awakened me? Thou shalt suffer for it.’ Then the child came back with the meal, and the miller said, ‘Why so long? Have you not brought the meal down?’ ‘Yes,’ said the child, ‘and I have seen a funny little man up in the corner.’ But the miller said, ‘Thou art a silly child, to sit chattering with every tomfool that comes into thine head; go and see to the donkey, and bring him down some more meal.’

So the child went and brought the donkey down, and as he was going back the little grey man called to him, and said, ‘Take some of the meal, and throw it full in the mill.’ Then the child did so, and the mill would not work. ‘Thou art right in that also,’ said the little grey man; ‘the mill will not work, and thou shalt have no rest until I am satisfied.’ Then the child went back to the miller, and said, ‘The donkey will not stay, he wants to go home.’ ‘Thou silly child,’ said the miller, ‘how can the donkey go home, when he has had nothing to eat? Go and fetch him some more meal.’

So the child went and took the meal to the donkey, and as he was going back the little grey man said, ‘Take some more meal, and throw it into the mill.’ Then the child did so, and the mill worked with such a noise and whirl that the donkey was frightened, and ran away, and the meal was scattered about. ‘Thou art right in that also,’ said the little grey man; ‘the donkey has run away, and thou shalt have no rest until I am satisfied.’ Then the child went back to the miller, and said, ‘My lord miller, the donkey has run away, and the meal is scattered about.’ ‘Thou silly child,’ said the miller, ‘what wilt thou not do to vex me? Go and bring the donkey back, and make the meal up, and then go up to the loft again, and fetch me some more meal.’

So the child went and brought the donkey back, and made the meal up, and then went up to the loft again for more meal. ‘Stay,’ said the little grey man, ‘take some more meal, and throw it into the mill.’ Then the child did so, and the mill worked with such a noise and whirl that all the meal was scattered about, and the donkey ran away, and the child after it. ‘Thou art right in that also,’ said the little grey man; ‘the donkey has run away, and thou shalt have no rest until I am satisfied.’

Then the little grey man went up to the miller, and complained to him that the child had set all his house in order, and had scattered all his meal about, and had run away with his donkey, and had lost all his livelihood. ‘Thou art a very unlucky child,’ said the miller; ‘go out into the wood, and lament and bewail thy fate, and I will give thee a loaf of bread and a piece of cheese, that thou mayst live upon it.’ So the child went out and ate the bread and cheese, and then the little grey man came to him, and said, ‘Why dost thou stay there? Go out farther into the wood, and lament and bewail thy fate, and I will give thee a loaf of bread and a piece of cheese, that thou mayst live upon it.’ Then the child went on, and ate the bread and cheese, and the little grey man came to him again, and said, ‘Why dost thou stay there? Go still farther into the wood, and lament and bewail thy fate, and I will give thee a loaf of bread and a piece of cheese, that thou mayst live upon it.’ So the child went on, and ate the bread and cheese, and the little grey man came to him again, and said, ‘Why dost thou stay there? Go still farther into the wood, and lament and bewail thy fate, and I will give thee a loaf of bread and a piece of cheese, that thou mayst live upon it.’ Then the child said, ‘I will stay no longer, I will do all thou biddest, only promise me one thing--that thou wilt tell me why it is that I have this bad luck.’

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor woodman, who cut wood in the forest, and lived in a
cottage with his wife. One evening, as he was sitting by the fire, smoking a
pipe, and looking thoughtfully into the flames, his wife said, ‘What are
you thinking about, dear husband?’ ‘I am thinking,’ said he, ‘how we will
live from henceforth, for I have cut all the wood in the forest.’ ‘Then we
must work together,’ said the wife, ‘and earn our livelihood in some way
or other.’

The next morning the man rose early, and went into the forest to cut
down a tree, and the woman gathered together all the rings and brooches she
had, and went into the town to dispose of them. She walked the whole day
from shop to shop, but could dispose of nothing, and returned home in the
evening very much grieved and disheartened. ‘Alas! dear husband,’ said she,
‘no one would buy even one of my rings or brooches; I have not earned so
many penn’orth to buy bread with.’ ‘Never mind,’ said the man, ‘I have
cut down a fine large tree, and have made two shillings by it.’ ‘Two
shillings!’ cried the wife, ‘I have not earned even half a farthing.’

The next day the man went further into the forest to cut down a tree,
and the woman rose early, and took with her all her jewels, and went to a
town many miles off. She walked the whole day from shop to shop, but could
sell nothing, and came home in the evening very much grieved and tired.
‘Alas! dear husband,’ said she, ‘no one would buy even one of my jewels;
I have not sold one farthing’s worth.’ ‘Never mind,’ said the man, ‘I have
made four shillings this day.’ ‘Four shillings!’ cried the wife, ‘I have
not sold a farthing’s worth.’

The third day the man cut down a very large tree, and the woman took all
her jewels to a great city, and walked the whole day from shop to shop, but
could sell nothing, and came home in the evening very much tired and
disheartened. ‘Alas! dear husband,’ said she, ‘no one would buy even one of
my jewels; I have not sold so much as a farthing’s worth.’ ‘Never mind,’
said the man, ‘I have made six shillings this day.’ ‘Six shillings!’ cried
the wife, ‘I have not sold so much as a farthing.’

The fourth day the man felled a large tree, and the woman took all her
jewels to a town many miles off, and walked the whole day from shop to
shop, but could sell nothing, and came home in the evening very much tired
and grieved. ‘Alas! dear husband,’ said she, ‘no one would buy even one of
my jewels; I have not sold so much as a farthing’s worth.’ ‘Never mind,’
said the man, ‘I have made eight shillings this day.’ ‘Eight shillings!’
cried the wife, ‘I have not sold so much as a farthing.’

The fifth day the man felled a very large tree, and the woman took all
her jewels to a great city, and walked the whole day from shop to shop, but
could sell nothing, and came home in the evening very much tired and
grieved. ‘Alas! dear husband,’ said she, ‘no one would buy even one of my
jewels; I have not sold so much as a farthing’s worth.’ ‘Never mind,’ said
the man, ‘I have made ten shillings this day.’ ‘Ten shillings!’ cried the
wife, ‘I have not sold so much as a farthing.’

The sixth day the man felled a very large tree, and the woman took all
her jewels to the capital of the kingdom, and walked the whole day from
shop to shop, but could sell nothing, and came home in the evening very much
tired and grieved. ‘Alas! dear husband,’ said she, ‘no one would buy even
one of my jewels; I have not sold so much as a farthing’s worth.’ ‘Never
mind,’ said the man, ‘I have made twelve shillings this day.’ ‘Twelve
shillings!’ cried the wife, ‘I have not sold so much as a farthing.’

The seventh day the man felled a very large tree, and the woman sat
down in a corner and wept, for she saw very well that no one would buy her
jewels, and yet she had none other means of earning a livelihood. In the
evening, as she sat thus weeping, there was a knocking at the door, and a
little dwarf came in, and said, ‘Why do you weep, dear child?’ ‘Alas!’
said the woman, ‘what can I do to earn my livelihood? I have tried all I
could, and yet have not been able to sell even one of my jewels.’ ‘What
do you call that box which stands in the corner?’ said the dwarf. ‘Ah!
dear sir,’ said the woman, ‘that is full of my jewels.’ ‘Then take them
all out, and bring me what you have there.’ As the woman took out one
jewel after another, the little dwarf paid her a shilling for every one,
and at last paid her all down in money. ‘I have now all my money again,’
said the dwarf, ‘and I will give you an excellent piece of advice. Sell
no more of your jewels, but take that money, and buy with it two fine
heifers, and every morning when your husband goes into the forest to cut
down trees, you go with him, and in the evening when he comes back, give
the heifers drink out of the bottle which stands in the corner, and out of
every bottle which is empty, fill it up with the cow’s milk, and next day
sell the milk. I warrant you that in a month’s time you will have as much
money as will buy a cow, and the cow will give you as much milk as you
can use, and more than you can sell.’

The woman did as the dwarf advised, and in a month she had not only as
much money as would buy a cow, but had also milk enough for her own use.
The little dwarf then came again, and said, ‘Now, as you have got a cow,
give the heifers away, and take care not to sell the cow, but keep it,
and every morning when your husband goes into the forest to cut down
trees, go with him, and in the evening when he comes back, give the cow
drink out of the bottle which stands in the corner, and out of every bottle
which is empty, fill it up with the cow’s milk, and next day sell the milk.
I warrant you that in two months’ time you will have as much money as will
buy two cows, and the two cows will give you as much milk as you can use,
and more than you can sell.’

The woman did as the dwarf advised, and in two months she had not only
as much money as would buy two cows, but had also milk enough for her own
use. The little dwarf then came again, and said, ‘Now, as you have got
two cows, give the one away, and take care not to sell either of the cows,
but keep them, and every morning when your husband goes into the forest to
cut down trees, go with him, and in the evening when he comes back, give

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Snow Queen

Once upon a time there was a good and kind old man, who had a beautiful
daughter called Gerda. This Gerda was so good and kind that the sun itself
seemed to shine out of her eyes when she looked upon the world with them,
and her heart was pure as the brightest day.

One day, when the snowflakes were dancing in the air, and the rooftops were
white, and the ground was covered deep with soft snow, Gerda and her little
brother, Käthe, were standing together in their pretty garden, and picking
flowers. Suddenly a sharp piece of ice cut Käthe’s eye, and a drop of blood
ran down. But the piece of ice was no common piece of ice: it was a splinter
from the window of the Snow Queen, who had flown over the world that morning,
and thrown the pieces of ice about like hail.

Käthe felt nothing at first, but when he went home and looked in the glass,
he saw with horror that one of his eyes was no longer like the other; it was
as hard and white as the Snow Queen’s palace, and sparkled like ice. Then
he screamed with fear and misery, and his mother came and looked at him,
and saw what had happened. She tried to comfort him, but it was of no use;
so she sent for Gerda, and said, ‘Go and find the Snow Queen, and pray her
to take Käthe to be her playfellow for ever, that he may be cured.’

Then Gerda kissed her brother, and said, ‘I will soon come back, Käthe;
be at ease, and take care of yourself, till I come.’

So Gerda took her brother’s hand, and looked at it for the last time; it
was still warm, but already she could feel that it was growing cold. Then she
went away, and her heart was very heavy, but still she was so full of love
to her brother that she did not once think of her own troubles.

She soon came to the great highway that leads over the whole world, and
there she saw a little man, who had been crushed by a cart, and lay on the
ground, and was quite yellow, and did not look very nice. ‘Do come and help
me up,’ said the little man; ‘my cart crushed me, and it hurts me to lie
here.’ ‘What a nasty dirty place,’ thought Gerda, as she sat down, and
took hold of the little man; ‘but he is in a way, so I must help him.’

So she lifted up the little man, and set him upon her knee, and soon
he was quite comfortable, and began to tell her all sorts of things.

‘See how the world looks from up here,’ said he; ‘how green the fields are,
and how blue the sky! I wish I had a nice juicy apple.’ Then he looked
round and saw a tree full of apples, and said, ‘I wish you would climb up
and throw me one.’

Gerda did not at first like this, for she thought, ‘What if I were to fall
down and break my neck?’ But the little man said, ‘Oh, don’t be silly;
you will be quite safe.’ So Gerda climbed up the tree, and picked a juicy
apple, and threw it down to the little man; but as she was sitting among
the branches, the wind blew so, that she could not get out again, but was
forced to sit and wait till someone came.

Meanwhile the little man was rolling the apple along the ground, and
looking up at Gerda, and at first he did not seem very sorry for her; but
when it began to grow dark, and she was still stuck fast, he called out,
‘What a silly girl you are!’ and began to cry, and was very sorry for her.

Then he went home to his mother, who lived in a house under the ground,
and begged her to help Gerda. The mother took pity on her, and gave her
son a knife, and said, ‘Cut a deep piece out of the seat of the chair, so
that when Gerda sits down upon it she will fall through into the earth, and
we will soon be able to help her.’

So the little man did as he was told, and took the chair, and sat by the
roadside, where Gerda could see it, and read the following words, painted
in golden letters:

 ‘Sit upon the chair, and you will fall
  Into the earth, and thence I may help thee best of all.’

Gerda read this, and trusted what was written; so she sat down, and at
once fell through the seat into the earth, and a trap-door sprang shut above
her. Then two little men came, and lifted her up, and carried her through
a long tunnel to the little man’s house. They gave her food and drink, and
when she had rested herself, they told her that they would take her to the
Snow Queen.

The little man’s mother came to see Gerda, and gave her a cloak that would
carry her through the air, and a sledge to sit upon, and a whip to drive
it. ‘Now, Gerda,’ said she, ‘drive on, and the wind will blow you along;
only take care not to lose the cloak, for if you do, you will fall to the
ground, and that would be very bad for you.’

Then the little man gave Gerda a piece of bread, and said, ‘Take this
bread, and throw crumbs now and then on to the ground, so that the little
bird, Lapp-Laddoo, may follow you, for he will sing and tell you a song,
that will help you to find the Snow Queen.’

So Gerda put on her cloak, and took her bread, and drove her sledge away
over the fields and woods, and the wind blew so strong that it was as if
it would blow the sledge along whether she whipped it or not. Sometimes
she threw a crumb of bread on the ground, and then Lapp-Laddoo came hopping
up, and sang:

 ‘Till the crumb is eaten,
  Till the crumb is gone,
  Tell me where the Snow Queen’s palace is situated,
  Tell me where it is sited,
  On the hill or in the valley,
  In the mountain’s cave or on the tree-top,
  In the briar-hedge or in the thorn-bush,
  In the red-stone castle or the granite rock.’

And then Gerda knew the song would help her, and she drove on, till at
last the bread was all gone, and Lapp-Laddoo flew away.

One day, as Gerda was driving along, looking about her, and thinking of
Käthe, and of her journey, and of everything at home, and of everything she
should see and do, till at last her mind became so troubled that she did
not know what she was about; and she did not drive or whip, but let the
sledge run on very fast. At last down it went, with a loud noise, into a
deep valley; and the cloak was all torn off, and Gerda sat upon the cold
sledge in the snow.

Then she was very much frightened, and began to cry; and the snow fell
fast, and covered her and the sledge so that she could not see a thing. And
there she sat for a long time, till she was quite tired, and could cry no
more.

At last, by good luck, a little old woman came by, who took Gerda up on
to her sledge, and covered her with a cloak, and took her to her cottage.
There she let her rest herself, and gave her food and drink, and asked
her what had happened.

G

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor woodman, who cut wood in the forest, and lived in a
hut with his wife, and his two children. Now it came to pass that the wood
was all cut, and the man knew not how he should get any more to earn his
livelihood; so he said to his wife: ‘Alas, what shall we do? I cannot get
any work, and we shall have nothing to live upon.’ ‘Then, my husband,’
said she, ‘let us go into the forest, and cut a little more, though what
we get to sell may not be worth more than our trouble in carrying it
home.’ So the man said: ‘That will be better than doing nothing; let us
go therefore, and cut what little we can.’

Then the woman said: ‘I will tell you a good story by the way; it will pass
away pleasantly, and the time will seem very short.’ ‘Yes,’ said the man,
‘do tell a tale.’ ‘There was once a man,’ said she, ‘who had a faithful
friend, to whom he was very much attached, and who had often saved his
life; but this friend had a wife who was very ugly, and the man could not
bear to see his friend go home to her. One day, therefore, he said to him:
“I wish you would leave your wife, and be my friend alone.” “That is
impossible,” said the other; “my wife and I have made a pact together, and
we cannot break it.” The man was angry at this answer, and said: “If you
will not leave your wife, I shall no longer have anything to do with you.”
Then the friend begged so hard that he agreed to make the attempt he was
asked to make; but he said: “I cannot do what you wish without making a
great sacrifice, for I shall have to give up my only child, which I love
dearly.” “That is nothing,” said the other, “you will still have me for a
friend.” So the friend yielded to his entreaties, and left his wife; but he
was very unhappy, and soon went to visit her, and said: “I cannot live
alone; we will make up our minds to part from our child, and then we shall
be able to stay with each other.” The wife answered: “It would be a great
sacrifice for me to give up my child, but if my husband thinks it necessary,
I am willing to do it.” Then they went together to a strange land, where no
one knew them, and there they sought for a place where they could leave
their child to die; but they could not find any spot so dreadful and horrible
that they thought it would be a fit one. At last they came to a large
marsh, which was surrounded on all sides by high trees, and in the middle
there was a little island, full of beautiful flowers. There they thought
they should be quite sure of leaving the child in safety, for no one could
get there, on account of the deep mire that surrounded it. So they took
their child there, and laid it on the grass, and the mother went away with
a heavy heart, and the father followed her.

But the child was an handsome boy, and God sent two angels from heaven to
watch over him; and they took care that no hurt should come near him. The
birds built their nests around him, and the rabbits and hares came to him,
and played with him; the deer came and browsed by his side, and the roe and
the chamois came to drink to the water that ran round the island. And the
boy grew up, and knew nothing of the world, but was good and kind and
peaceful.

After some time the two angels went to him, and said: ‘Your time has come;
you must go forth into the world.’ Then the boy was sad, and did not wish
to leave the beautiful flowers and the animals that had been so kind to
him; but the angels took him by the hand, and led him away.

And now the woodman and his wife had made a pile of their wood, and were
going home with it on their shoulders, when the man said: ‘I will tell you

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
Once upon a time, in a village that lay in a green valley, where the nuts
were very plenty, there lived a poor woodman with his wife and two children.
They were very happy, for the woodman cut fuel for the people of the town,
and so earned a little money; but the best of their fortune was, that they
had a little plot of ground in a wood, where they planted hazel-nuts and
chestnuts, and these gave them a part of their living. One day the woodman
cut down a great tree, and as he was pulling it, it fell against another
tree, that was all alive and full of sap, and the sap ran out and dried up
all the leaves upon the tree. Then the woodman said: ‘How sad it is that
should happen! I cannot bear to see such a beautiful tree die; I will take
care it shall not be all lost, and cut it into rods, and make whips out of
them.’ So he did so, and made seven whips, and put them up in the corner of
the room, where they looked very neat and tidy.

Now it happened that the king of the country passed through the village,
and spent the night at the inn. As he was sitting in the parlour, his eyes
fell on the whips that hung in the corner, and he said: ‘What are these
things?’ ‘O’ said the landlord, ‘they are made of a magical witch’s willow,
and have great power; for every morning and every evening seven birds come
and sing and dance about them; and whosoever will cut one of these whips,
and weave it into a basket, and take it away with him, shall find it full
of the finest pearls the next morning.’ ‘That is a noble gift,’ said the
king; ‘I should like to have one of those baskets.’ Then the landlord said:
‘I will soon get it for you.’ So he went to the woodman, and told him what
the king had said about the baskets, and asked him if he would not give him
one of the whips, and weave a basket out of it. ‘Certainly,’ said the woodman,
‘I have plenty of them.’ Then the landlord took one of the whips, and took
it to the king.

The next morning, when the king got up, he took the basket, and hung it on
his arm, and went out into the court; and as he went, the seven birds came
flying about the whip, and sang and danced; and when they had done, there
were seven thousand pearls in the bottom of the basket. The king was overjoyed
at the sight of this, and went straight to his palace, and showed the
basket to the queen.

The queen had a daughter, who was very beautiful, but so proud that no
one could please her; and when she saw the pearls, she said: ‘I should
like to have one of those baskets for myself.’ Then the king said to the
landlord: ‘Go to the woodman again, and tell him that the queen would like
to have one of the whips.’ The landlord did so, and brought the queen one
of the whips.

The next morning the queen took the whip, and had a basket woven for it,
and took it with her into her bed-chamber, and laid it on her bed. But as
soon as she had left the king’s room, the seven birds came and sang and
danced about the whip; and when they had done, the basket was full of fine
pearls. The queen was delighted to see this, and thought no one knew it;
but the king had seen all that happened, and went into the bed-chamber,
and took some of the pearls out of the basket, and laid them on the table.
Then he called his daughter to him, and said: ‘Look, my child, at the
pearls which the basket has given, and try to please yourself with them.’
But the princess said: ‘La! father, those are coarse pearls, I want fine
ones yet.’

The next morning the queen took the whip, and had a basket made for it,
and took it into her bed-chamber, and laid it on her bed, thinking that no
one saw what she did; but the king saw it all, and took some of the finest
pearls out of the basket, and laid them on the table, and sent his maid
to the princess’s room, and told her to take some of the pearls, and to
lay them before her daughter. Then the maid did as she was told, and the
princess saw the fine pearls, and said: ‘At last, father, I am pleased,
now these are what I call pearls.’

The queen saw that the princess was pleased, and thought she should have
the whip for herself; so the next morning she took it, and had a basket
woven for it, and took it into her bed-chamber; but the king took the basket
away, and carried it into his study, and kept the fine pearls. Then the
queen went to her bed-chamber, and laid herself down upon her bed, and
thought that no one saw what she did; but the king saw it all, and went
into the study, and took some of the finest pearls, and laid them on the
table, and sent his maid to the queen’s bed-chamber, and told her to take
some of the pearls, and to put them by the princess’s pillow, so that when
she awoke in the morning she might think that the basket had been full of
them.

But the queen found the pearls, and thought that the basket must have been
full of them, and laid herself down upon her bed, thinking that no one saw
what she did; but the king saw it all, and went into his study, and took
away the real pearls, and laid some common pebbles on the table, and went
into the queen’s bed-chamber, and took the pearls that were by the
princess’s pillow, and laid them by her own pillow; and then he went out
of the bed-chamber, thinking that the queen had gone to bed, and that no
one saw what he did.

But the queen found the pearls by her pillow, and thought that the basket
must have been full of them, and laid herself down, thinking that no one
saw what she did; but the king saw it all, and went into the study, and
took away the real pearls, and laid some common pebbles on the table, and
took the whip out of the corner, and went into the queen’s bed-chamber,
and took the seven birds away from the whip.

Then the queen awoke in the morning, and thought that the basket must have
been full of pearls, and called her maid, and said: ‘Go and tell the princess
that she must be richer than I am; for by the side of her pillow there
lie pearls which the basket has given us in the night.’ The maid went and
told the princess this, and she jumped up in a great flurry, and looked
at the pearls, and said: ‘Let the whole palace know that I have these
pearls; I will not keep them to myself.’ Then the maid ran to the king,
and told him that the princess wanted to show the pearls to the whole
palace; and the king said: ‘Let her do as she will.’

Then the princess went to the palace, and showed the pearls to the queen,
and said: ‘These are the pearls which my pillow has given me.’ But the
queen looked at them, and saw that they were common pebbles, and said: ‘I
too have had some pearls; let me show you mine.’ Then she took the real
pearls

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a king who had a beautiful garden, in which stood
a tree that bore golden apples. These apples were always ripe at
New Year’s time, and the king ordered that they should be placed
in a dish and shown to his guests. Strange to say, the tree bore
but one of these apples every year, and the king thought that this
was very unlucky, for he had many thousand guests to his table, and
one apple was not near enough for all of them.

Now, it chanced that this king had a daughter who was very
beautiful, but so proud that no prince in Christendom was good
enough for her. Then a suitor came from afar, who was called
Drosselmeier, and he was master of the art of making dolls and
living-gardens, and could do many wonderful things. He loved the
king’s daughter, but she did not care anything about him, and was
scornful and rude to him.

The king, however, liked Drosselmeier very much, and one day he
said to him, ‘I have a wish to make you happy, so I will give you
the golden apple out of the tree for your New Year’s gift.’ Then the
girl heard of this, and grew very thoughtful and uneasy. She went
to her father, and said, ‘If you give the apple to Drosselmeier,
I shall have nobody else, for I want to be his wife.’ The king
answered, ‘Dear child, he will have you whether he gets the apple
or not.’

On New Year’s Eve, when the king and all his court were sitting
at the table, and Drosselmeier was also there, the king ordered that
the dish with the golden apple should be brought in. Then the king
said, ‘Drosselmeier, here is the apple for you; I give it to you
as a token of my good will.’

And Drosselmeier took the apple, and said, ‘I thank your majesty
very much, but I like the apple no better than I did when it was
hanging on the tree.’

When the girl heard that, she was very much frightened, and thought
to herself, ‘If the apple pleases him no better now than it did
before, he must have some other sort of apple for his New Year’s
gift.’

The next morning she sent a servant to Drosselmeier, and asked
him whether he had any other kind of apple, for the golden apple
was not to his taste. Then Drosselmeier said, ‘Yes, I have other
apples, but they are not of gold, and one of them is not enough
for you, for you want to eat one after every meal.’

‘Where do the trees grow from which these apples come?’ asked the
king’s daughter.

‘In my garden,’ answered Drosselmeier.

Then the king’s daughter went to him, and said, ‘Dear Drosselmeier,
if you love me, let your garden be near my father’s palace, so that
I may go there whenever I like.’

‘That is easily managed,’ said Drosselmeier, ‘only you must
promise to come thither three times every day, for it is a living
garden, and requires constant attention.’

The king’s daughter agreed to this, and went home, and caused a
walk to be laid out to Drosselmeier’s garden.

It was not long before the garden began to be neglected, for the
king’s daughter never went there as often as she had promised. And
Drosselmeier sent word to her that the apples were all being eaten
up, and that if she did not take more care, there would be none
left. Then she said she would go and water the trees, but she only
went three times a week, and not even then stayed long.

At last the garden was quite neglected, and only a few withered
trees remained standing in it. Then Drosselmeier sent word that
unless she came and watered them, the trees would all die. But she
answered, ‘Let the garden be quite lost, I care nothing about it;
it troubles me very much indeed.’

When Drosselmeier heard that, he went to the king, and said, ‘I
cannot live any longer in a country where people are so ungrateful
and do not keep their word.’

‘What is all this about?’ said the king. ‘Has not my daughter
treated you well?’

‘Your daughter,’ answered Drosselmeier, ‘has broken her word, and
neglected a promise, and has thus destroyed my garden. I cannot
stay here.’

Then the king was very angry with his daughter, and said, ‘You
must bring Drosselmeier’s garden back to its old beauty in three
days, or you shall lose your life.’

But the king’s daughter knew not how to set to work to make the
garden green again, and sat in her chamber very sorrowful and
thoughtful. Presently her old nurse came in, and said, ‘Why are
you so sorrowful?’ ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I must make Drosselmeier’s
garden green again in three days, or I shall lose my life, and I
do not know how to do it.’

Then the nurse said, ‘I have an old book here, full of magical
formulas, and one of them may help us. Let us try and see what we
can find.’

So they took the book, and read and read, till their eyes ached,
but they found nothing about a living garden. And the first day was
already gone.

On the second day the king’s daughter went out and sat down by
the withered trees, and her heart was very sad and full of grief.
Then a little dwarf came and sat down by her, and said, ‘Why are
you so sorrowful?’

‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I must make this garden green again in two
days, or I shall lose my life, and I do not know how to do it.’

‘What are you called?’ asked the dwarf.

‘I am called--’

‘Do not tell me your name,’ said the dwarf; ‘only tell me what
kind of a bird your father was.’

‘My father was not a bird,’ answered she.

‘Then he was not a king?’ said the dwarf.

‘No, he was not a king.’

‘Then he was not a king’s son?’

‘No, he was not a king’s son.’

‘Then he was not even a court official?’

‘No, he was not a court official.’

‘Then what was he?’ said the dwarf.

‘He was a poor woodman.’

‘And what is your mother?’

‘She is a woodman’s wife.’

‘And how many brothers and sisters have you?’

‘Five brothers.’

‘What are they?’

‘One is a court official, the other is a king’s son, a third is
a king, a fourth is a bird, and the fifth is a dwarf.’

Then the little dwarf was happy, and clapped his hands for joy,
and said, ‘I am your brother the dwarf, and I will help you.’

On the third day the king’s daughter went to Drosselmeier, and
said, ‘I have lost my father, my mother, and all my brothers; but
here is my brother the dwarf, and he has undertaken to make the
garden green again.’

Then Drosselmeier said, ‘I will trust
