The Enchanted Ring

In a village in the Black Forest there lived a poor woodman with his wife, who toiled hard all
the day long to earn their bread, but often had little or nothing to eat. One day the woman
said to her husband, ‘I will try my luck and cut some wood in the forest, and you can help
me to carry it home.’ So the man said, ‘It will be a good thing to do, for I am very tired
and my hands ache.’

They rose early next morning, and before the sun had climbed half-way up in the heavens,
they had cut and piled up so much wood that they could not carry any more. The wife said,
‘I will lay down by the wood and rest a while, till you come back with another load.’ So
the husband left her, and went home with the wood on his back.

As he was turning round to go back to the forest, he looked sharp and saw with a heavy
heart that she still lay at the foot of the hill, and seemed to be asleep. ‘I will not
wait longer,’ said he, ‘or the evening will overtake me, and then she would certainly
die.’ So he took up the wood and went home, and thought of nothing but how to get
someone to bring his poor wife home. At last he went to the parson, and said, ‘If you
will not help my wife home, she will surely die.’ ‘What has happened?’ asked the parson.
‘She left the forest this morning, to bring wood home with me, and I did not come back
soon enough, and she fell asleep where the wood is piled up, and I left her alone.’ Then
the parson said, ‘I will go with you,’ and they went together, and found her still lying
as if asleep. The parson said, ‘You may go home, I will stay with her.’ So the woodman
went home, but his wife did not awake again, and the next day she was dead.

The parson buried her with his own hands, and when he came back to the village he
said to the woodman, ‘As you and I were the only people she had in the world, I will
take you into my house, and you shall be my servant.’ The woodman agreed to this, and
worked hard for the parson, and did all that he was told.

One day the parson said to him, ‘I am going to the town, and will stay some time, so
you must take care of myself and my house.’ When the parson was gone, the woodman
thought he would walk out and take the air. As he went along, a little dwarf, about
half as high as a man, and as black as coal, came in sight. He came up to the woodman,
and said, ‘Why do you turn your faces so sadly?’ ‘What is that to you, you little fellow?’
said the woodman. ‘Why, I am very sorry for you,’ said the dwarf. ‘What have I done?’
said the woodman. ‘You have nothing to eat, I know, and your master is away, and you
are afraid I shall tell tales and get you into trouble when he comes back.’ ‘How can
you know that?’ said the woodman. ‘Why, I can see everything that happens, and I know
a great many things.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of your knowing? You should do good
with your gift, and not take it about with you like a trinket in your pocket.’ ‘Oh! you
are very saucy, and I don’t much like you.’ ‘Well, if you please, I will tell you a good
deal of what is going on in the world, and in the parson’s house too.’ ‘Well, but what
is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you would like to know what becomes of the pretty girl who
is to be married tomorrow, and whether she will be faithful to her husband, or not.’
‘Well, but is not that silly chatter?’ ‘Oh, yes! I can tell you many things that are a
good deal better worth knowing.’ ‘Well, but what are you himself?’ ‘Why, I am an
enchanted dwarf, and can only take my proper shape three times in a year; and this
is one of those times.’ ‘What do I get by all this?’ said the woodman. ‘Why, I will
tell you a great many things that you would like to know.’ ‘Well, but what is all
this worth?’ ‘Why, I will give you a golden horseshoe, that all the horses in the
world will obey, if you will let me.’ ‘What is that to me?’ said the woodman. ‘Why,
you can put it on any horse you like, and ride him as you please.’ ‘Well, but what
is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can ride to the sun and moon with him, if you like.’
‘What is that to me?’ ‘Why, you can go to any country you please, and see everything
that is going on in the world.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can
see the most beautiful country that ever was seen, and where there is plenty of
everything.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can stay there as long as
you like.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can bring home with you
whatever you like, and be very much better off than you are.’ ‘Well, but what is
the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can marry, and have children, and they will be better off
than you are.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can live as long as you
please.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can live for ever.’ ‘Well,
but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can be king of the country, and have everything
your own way.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can take all your
friends and relations with you.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can
bring my father and mother out of the sea where they have been enchanted, and set
them free.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, I will give you my magic ring,
and with that you can get whatever you wish.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’
‘Why, you can wish for gold and silver, and everything that your heart desires.’
‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can wish for the most beautiful
dresses, and the finest jewels.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can
wish for the prettiest flowers, and the rarest fruits.’ ‘Well, but what is the use
of that?’ ‘Why, you can wish for the finest birds, and the most beautiful animals.’
‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can do anything you like.’ ‘Well,
but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can tell your master the time of day, and
what the weather will be, and whether it will rain or not.’ ‘Well, but what is
the use of that?’ ‘Why, you can tell your master whether he will live or die.’

whether he will be happy or unhappy.’ ‘Well, but what is the use of that?’ ‘Why,
you can tell your master whether he will be beloved or hated.’ ‘Well, but what is

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Three Little Pigs and the Wolf

Once upon a time, there were three little pigs who set out from their home in search of their fortunes. ‘Brothers,’ said the first, ‘what shall we do? Let us make some agreement among ourselves, that we may not be parted.’ ‘Yes,’ said the second, ‘let us always keep together, and if we meet with any little house, we will build it up together, and live in it.’ ‘Yes,’ said the third, ‘that is a good plan; but let us make haste, for the night is coming on.’

So they journeyed on, till at length they came to a little house made of straw. ‘Here,’ said the first pig, ‘is not room enough for us three to live in this house; let us build a larger.’ So they pulled down the little house, and built a larger one of straw, and then said, ‘Now, this house shall be large enough for us.’ Then the first pig said, ‘I will go into the wood, and cut down some trees, and bring them home, that we may make chairs and tables for our house.’ So off he went, and the second pig said, ‘I will go with him, and lend him a hand.’ So on they went together, and the third pig sat at home in the empty house, with the door left wide open.

Now the wolf watched them as they went along, and when they were a little way off, the wolf ran up to the house, and pushed the door quite open, and then said, ‘What a noble house you have, Mr Pig! I am very hungry; may I lodge with you for a night?’ ‘Oh, no!’ said the pig, ‘we have only three little rooms, and one of them is my bed-room; so we cannot lodge you.’ ‘Only think,’ said the wolf, ‘I shall run you into the wood, and tear you to pieces, if you do not let me in.’ So the pig ran off, and the wolf went in and sat himself down in the chair, and when he sat down the chair broke to pieces, and the wolf fell down upon the floor. Then the wolf got up and went into the bed-room, and there the pig found him, and cried out, ‘Will you eat my bed?’ ‘No,’ said the wolf, ‘but where is that pig who let me in? I will eat him.’ ‘Oh, you wicked wolf!’ said the pig, ‘I am the one; but if you have any claim upon me for letting you in, you must wait till my two brothers come home.’

Meantime the two other pigs had been cutting down the trees, and making the chairs and tables, when they saw a large black cloud of smoke coming in the air. ‘What a strange thing!’ said the first pig, ‘there is no wind; look, how high that smoke rises in the air.’ ‘That is no smoke,’ said the second pig; ‘it is a heavy black cloud.’ ‘Let us run home as fast as we can,’ said the first pig; ‘something must have burnt the house down.’ So away they ran home, and when they got there the wolf was sitting in the chair with a frightened look, and the chair was broken to pieces. ‘What a strange thing!’ said the first pig; ‘our chair has burnt!’ ‘No,’ said the second pig; ‘it is not the chair that has burnt; it is the house.’ ‘Let us go into the bed-room and see if that is burnt.’ So they went into the bed-room, and there lay the wolf, and he said, ‘Your house is all burnt down, is not it?’ ‘No,’ said the first pig; ‘it is you that are burnt.’ ‘Oh, yes,’ said the second pig; ‘you were sitting upon the chair, and it broke to pieces, and you fell into the fire.’ Just then up sprang the wolf, and off he ran. ‘There he goes,’ said the first pig, ‘running away for burning his behind.’

The wolf soon stopped, and lay down under a shrub, and when he saw afar off three people coming along, he cried out, ‘Good morning, good people, what a beautiful morning!’ ‘Yes,’ said the first, ‘it is a beautiful morning, but it is a long time since we have had anything to eat.’ ‘If that be the case,’ said the wolf, ‘I will treat you to some nice pork chops.’ ‘Oh, joy!’ cried the others; ‘take us to the house.’ ‘Come along,’ said the wolf; ‘my house is close by.’ So he took them into his mouth, and as he was going to swallow them down, they pushed out all the bones of his body, and then ran away.

The wolf soon got well, and set out into the world again, and by and by he came to the second little pig’s house. ‘Good morning, Mr Pig,’ said he; ‘how many rooms have you got in your house?’ ‘Two,’ said the pig. ‘May I not lodge with you for one night?’ ‘Oh, no!’ said the pig; ‘I have only two rooms, and one of them is my bed-room; so I cannot lodge you.’ ‘If that be the case,’ said the wolf, ‘you will repent it, for I will run you into the wood, and tear you to pieces.’ So the pig ran off, and the wolf went in and sat himself down in the chair. But the chair broke to pieces, and the wolf fell down upon the floor. Then the pig found him, and said, ‘Will you eat my chair?’ ‘No,’ said the wolf; ‘but where is that pig who let me in? I will eat him.’ ‘Oh, you wicked wolf!’ said the pig, ‘I am the one; but if you have any claim upon me for letting you in, you must wait till my two brothers come home.’

Meantime the two other pigs were at work, making a house of brick for themselves. When they saw the black cloud of smoke in the air, they said, ‘What a strange thing! there is no wind, and yet look, how high that smoke rises in the air.’ ‘That is no smoke,’ said the first pig; ‘it is a heavy black cloud.’ ‘Let us run home as fast as we can,’ said the second pig; ‘something must have burnt our house down.’ So they ran home, and when they got there the wolf was sitting on the floor. ‘Our house is all burnt down, is not it?’ said the first pig. ‘Yes,’ said the second pig; ‘it is you that are burnt.’ ‘Let us go into the bed-room,’ said the first pig, ‘and see if that is burnt.’ So they went into the bed-room, and there lay the wolf, and he said, ‘Your house is all burnt down, is not it?’ ‘No,’ said the first pig; ‘it is you that are burnt.’ ‘Yes,’ said the second pig; ‘you sat upon a chair, and the chair broke to pieces, and you fell into the fire.’ ‘Out with it!’ cried the wolf, and he sprang up, and away he ran. ‘There he goes,’ said the first pig, ‘running away for burning his behind.’

The wolf soon stopped, and lay down under a bush, and when he saw afar off three people coming along, he cried out, ‘Good morning, good people, what a beautiful morning!’ ‘Yes,’ said the first, ‘it is a beautiful morning, but we have had nothing to eat for a long time.’ ‘If that be the case,’ said the wolf, ‘I will treat you to some nice pork chops.’ ‘Oh, joy!’ cried the others; ‘take us to your house.’ ‘Come along,’ said the wolf; ‘my house is close by.’ So he took them into his mouth, and as he was going to swallow them down, they pushed out all the bones of his body, and then ran away.

The wolf soon got well, and set

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Shepherd and the Star

There was once a poor shepherd who watched his flock by day and by night upon the lonely heath. His flock was small, and what he earned by selling the wool and the flesh was just enough to keep his wife and two children from dying of hunger. One evening as he sat by the fire, his little daughter came running to him, and said, ‘Dear father, there is a strange star in the sky.’ The shepherd looked up, and saw that it was true; a star burned bright in the heavens, which he had never seen before. ‘It is lucky we should see such a star,’ said he to his wife; ‘perhaps our fortunes will change for the better.’ Then he took his pipe and smoked, and his wife took her spinning-wheel and began to work, but the little girl crept up to her father’s knee and said, ‘Tell me a tale, father.’ ‘What tale would you have?’ said he. ‘I know not which.’ ‘Then tell me the tale of the shepherd who found the treasure.’

So the shepherd began his tale.

‘There was once a shepherd like unto myself, and his flock was but small; yet he trusted in God that he should some day find a treasure, and become a rich man. One day as he was walking in the fields with his pipe in his mouth, he saw a man sitting in the grass, with his face turned to the sky. And the shepherd went up to him, and said, “What seek you here?” And the man turned his face from the sky, and looked at the shepherd, and said, “I am looking for a treasure that lies hidden beneath the green grass.” Then the shepherd said, “What is it that you see in the sky, that you should look so steadfastly thither?” And the man said, “I see a star that burns bright, and I know that all my wishes will be fulfilled when it rises here upon the earth.”

‘So they went back to the shepherd’s cottage, and sat down by the fire, and the shepherd gave his guest meat and drink. And when they had eaten and drunk, the man said, “I will tell you how we may find the treasure.” Then the shepherd’s eyes sparkled with joy, and he clapped his hands for glee. “Yes,” said the man, “we will go forth together by night, when the moon is full, and we will dig in the place where the grass grows thickest and greenest; for there the treasure lies hidden.” So the shepherd said, “My eldest son shall go with us,” and the man said, “So shall his youngest son.” Then they swore a great oath, that they would keep each other’s secret, and that they would share the treasure equally between them.

‘So they went forth by night, when the moon was full, and they found the place where the grass grew thickest and greenest, and there they began to dig. And the shepherd’s eldest son dug all one night, and all the next day, and all the night following; and so did the man’s son. And the shepherd and the man watched the two boys, that they might not play a trick and steal away. And the third night came, and the shepherd was so tired that his eyes would not stay open, and he said to the man, “I must go home and lie down, for my legs will carry me no farther; but you and the boys must watch, and dig till you come to the treasure.” Then the man said, “I will watch with the boys.” So the shepherd turned away, and went home through the heath.

‘But the man said to the boys, “My little lambs, why do you work so hard, and dig so deep, and find nothing? The treasure cannot be very far down there. Let us rest a while, and then we will dig again.” So they laid aside their picks, and sat themselves down upon the ground, and the man took a book out of his pocket, and read to them. And the boys listened, and were so pleased with the tale that they forgot to think of their labour, and sat listening till the first cock crowed. Then the man said, “Now, my little lambs, let us go to bed and sleep a while, and then we will work again.” So they laid themselves down upon the grass, and slept.

‘When the shepherd rose up in the morning, he went to the place where he had left the man and the boys; but they were all asleep, and he waked them up, saying, “Rise, rise! the day is far advanced, and we shall not finish our work if we tarry any longer.” Then the man said, “I had a wonderful dream; I dreamt that we had dug deep enough, and that we saw the treasure lying there, but that a great dragon came forth and would have stolen it away from us, if we had not pulled it out quickly.” And the boys said, “We too have had wonderful dreams; we dreamt that the dragon was already gone, and that we were sharing the treasure between us three.”

‘Then they went back to the shepherd’s cottage, and ate and drank, and told all their adventures. And the shepherd said, “Now will I go with you, and we will dig together, and see if we cannot find the treasure.” So they all went forth together, and the shepherd brought an axe with him, and cut away the grass that grew over the place where they were to dig. And when they began to dig, they found, as they had dreamt, the treasure beneath; but scarcely had they lifted it up, when the dragon came rushing out of his cave, and snatched the treasure away, and went rolling and tossing it in the air, and at last flew away with it upon his back. Then the three men stood and gazed upon each other, and sorrowed sorely for the loss of their treasure.

‘But the shepherd said, “I will run and overtake the dragon, and take away the treasure by force.” So he began to run, and the dragon flew on slowly, not thinking that the shepherd would overtake him. And the shepherd ran on so fast that he soon came up to the dragon, and took hold of the treasure, and said, “Thou villain, thou hast cheated us! Thou shalt not carry our treasure away upon thy back.” And then he began to strike at the dragon, and the dragon set the treasure down, and turned upon the shepherd, and bit him, and dragged him upon the ground, and rolled him again and again till he was dead. And when the man and the two boys saw that, they turned and fled, and left the dead body of the shepherd upon the ground.

‘And now, my child, the tale comes back to me again. The shepherd is dead, and the dragon has the treasure; and we are left with our little flocks upon the lonely heath, where there is neither meat nor drink, nor wood to burn upon the fire. And what reward shall we have for our labour? Truly, none at all.’

As the shepherd finished his tale, the little girl wept, and said, ‘O dear father, what a sad tale that is! Pray tell me another.’ ‘What tale shall I tell?’ said the shepherd. ‘I know not which.’ ‘Then tell me the tale of the shepherd who followed the bear.’

So the shepherd began his tale again.

‘There was once a shepherd like unto myself, and his flock was but small; yet he trusted in God that he should some day find a treasure, and become a rich man. One day as he was walking in the fields with his pipe in his mouth, he saw a bear running towards him. Then he was sore afraid, and turned to fly; but he soon found himself so surrounded that he could go no farther. So he said to the bear, “Why have you made me afraid, and run me in at every step? What will you do with me?” Then the

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
Once upon a time there lived a poor old woman who had but one cow. She loved that cow very much, and took good care of it; but still it gave her very little milk, so that she could not even keep herself alive upon it. Now now she heard of a powerful fairy, who had the power of giving whatever she chose to any one who would visit her. Then the old woman said to herself, ‘What can I wish for? I will not ask for riches, for what can I do with riches when I have no health to enjoy them? I will ask for a cow that will give me as much milk as I desire.’ So she set out and found the fairy, and told her what she wanted. The fairy said, ‘You must bring me, in return, the calf of the cow when it is born, and give it to my cook to kill.’ The old woman consented, and the fairy gave her the cow that would give as much milk as she wished.

So the old woman went home, and her cow gave so much milk that she could drink of it as much as she wished, and yet the cow was never empty. Then she became happy, and lived upon milk to her heart’s desire.

After a while the calf was born, and the old woman was forced to take it to the fairy, and give it to her cook to kill. Now the cook wanted to have the best part of the calf, so he cut off the head and the legs and shoulders, and gave the rest of it to the maid to make into sausages. But the old woman’s calf spoke to the maid, and said, ‘Lay me on the oven that I may cook myself, and take me out when I am brown.’ The maid did as she was told, and when the calf was quite brown, the cook wanted to throw it away. But when he lifted it up, it cried, ‘Take me to my master the fairy.’ Then the cook was afraid, and carried it to the fairy, who said, ‘What does this mean?’ The cook made bold to say that the old woman had taken the calf from him, and had killed it herself.

The fairy flew into a rage, and called the old woman before her, and threatened to take away the power of giving milk from her cow if she had taken away her calf. But the old woman said, ‘Heaven forbid that I should do such a thing! If I killed the calf, why then do you see it is alive?’ Then the fairy was forced to acknowledge that the cook had told a lie, and that the calf was still alive.

She sent the cook to the mill to be ground to death in a mill, and said to the old woman, ‘As you have kept your word, I will keep mine. Your cow shall have as much milk as you desire.’

And so the old woman went home, and her cow was still the cow that gave as much milk as she wished, and she lived happily to the end of her days.

The End.

(Source: The Blue Fairy Book by Andrew Lang)

## Moral

Honesty is the best policy.

## Questions

1. What did the old woman wish for from the fairy?
2. What did the fairy ask in return for giving the old woman the cow?
3. What did the cook want to have when the calf was killed?
4. What did the calf tell the maid to do?
5. What did the cook say when he took the calf to the fairy?
6. What did the fairy do to the cook?
7. What did the fairy say to the old woman about her cow?
8. How did the old woman live?
9. What is the moral of the story?

## Answers

1. She wished for a cow that would give her as much milk as she desired.
2. She asked the old woman to give her the calf when it was born, and to give it to her cook to kill.
3. He wanted to have the best part of the calf.
4. She was to lay the calf on the oven that it might cook itself, and take it out when it was brown.
5. He said that the old woman had taken the calf from him and had killed it herself.
6. She sent the cook to the mill to be ground to death in a mill.
7. She said to the old woman that her cow should still have as much milk as she desired.
8. She lived happily.
9. Honesty is the best policy.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Wolf and the Seven Little Kids

There was once a wolf who had lost all his hair, and could therefore
no longer be reckoned very formidable. So he went about in search of
work, and at last came to a meadow where seven little kids were lying
feeding themselves. ‘Good day, children,’ said he to them, ‘how is all
with you?’ ‘Oh,’ said the kids, ‘we are very well, but who is that
that talks with such a horrid ugly face?’ ‘I am only a poor wolf,’
answered the other, ‘and as you see, I have not a hair on my body;
but I am very weak, and have not eaten a morsel for three days; so
if you will let me share your dinner, I shall be very thankful.’ ‘Poor
thing,’ said the kids, ‘we pity you; you shall indeed share our
dinner, but you must lie down over there, a little way off.’ So the
wolf lay down a little way off, and the kids went back to their food,
and ate as before. But when they had eaten half their dinner, they
began to be uneasy, and looked round to see if the wolf was still a
long way off; but he had crept nearer, and they could not tell whether
he would not soon pounce upon them and devour them all. Then the first
said: ‘Brother Kid, shall I run, or shall we stand and defend ourselves?’
‘No,’ said the second, ‘let us stand and defend ourselves.’ ‘But I
am afraid he will bite us,’ said the first. ‘Oh!’ answered the second,
‘he will not be so bold as that; he is so ugly that even a crow would
not come near him.’ So they stood fast, and the wolf came nearer and
nearer, till at last he was quite close to them. Then he seized them,
one after another, and ate them up, and there was not one left.

The next day, as the mother of the seven kids came home and found them
all gone, she inquired what had become of them. ‘I do not know,’ said
the first little goat, ‘I was lying feeding myself, and when I looked
round, they were all gone.’ ‘But where is your brother?’ said the old
goat. ‘Oh, he ran away, he was afraid.’ ‘No, that is not true,’ said
the second kid, ‘we were all lying down feeding ourselves, and when I
looked up, they were gone, and I do not know where they have gone.’
‘But where is your brother?’ said the old goat. ‘Oh, he ran away, he
was afraid.’ ‘No, that is not true,’ said the third kid. ‘We were all
lying down feeding ourselves, and when I looked up, they were gone, and
I do not know where they have gone.’ ‘But where is your brother?’ said
the old goat. ‘Oh, he ran away, he was afraid.’ ‘No, that is not
true,’ said the fourth kid. ‘We were all lying down feeding ourselves,
and when I looked up, they were gone, and I do not know where they have
gone.’ ‘But where is your brother?’ said the old goat. ‘Oh, he ran away,
he was afraid.’ ‘No, that is not true,’ said the fifth kid. ‘We were
all lying down feeding ourselves, and when I looked up, they were gone,
and I do not know where they have gone.’ ‘But where is your brother?’
said the old goat. ‘Oh, he ran away, he was afraid.’ ‘No, that is not
true,’ said the sixth kid. ‘We were all lying down feeding ourselves,
and when I looked up, they were gone, and I do not know where they have
gone.’ ‘But where is your brother?’ said the old goat. ‘Oh, he ran away,
he was afraid.’ ‘No, that is not true,’ said the seventh kid. ‘We were
all lying down feeding ourselves, and when I looked up, they were gone,
and I do not know where they have gone.’ ‘But where is your brother?’
said the old goat. ‘Oh, he ran away, he was afraid.’ Then the old goat
said: ‘All you little rascals have been false to me, and have told me
that your brother ran away, when he was really carried off by a wolf;
so, that I may know where you live, tell me truly.’

So the first said: ‘We have been feeding ourselves on the further
side of the wood.’ ‘And you,’ said the old goat to the second, ‘where
have you been feeding yourselves?’ ‘On the further side of the wood,
like the others.’ ‘And you,’ said the old goat to the third, ‘where
have you been feeding yourselves?’ ‘On the further side of the wood,
like the others.’ ‘And you,’ said the old goat to the fourth, ‘where
have you been feeding yourselves?’ ‘On the further side of the wood,
like the others.’ ‘And you,’ said the old goat to the fifth, ‘where
have you been feeding yourselves?’ ‘On the further side of the wood,
like the others.’ ‘And you,’ said the old goat to the sixth, ‘where
have you been feeding yourselves?’ ‘On the further side of the wood,
like the others.’ ‘And you,’ said the old goat to the seventh, ‘where
have you been feeding yourselves?’ ‘On the further side of the wood,
like the others.’ Then the old goat went to the wood, and cried out:
‘Where are you, you wolf?’ And the wolf answered: ‘Who has been
calling the old goat?’ ‘I have,’ said the old goat. ‘All right,’ said
the wolf, ‘come up higher into the wood, and I will show you where I
have hidden the kids.’ Then the old goat went up into the wood, and the
wolf seized him, and devoured him, and afterwards threw his skin aside,
and lay down in it himself. When the old goat was dead, the wolf went
out and called the first kid, and said: ‘All is well, you may come
out; I have killed the old goat, and there is no one now to harm you;
so come and put on your clothes.’ ‘Oh,’ said the first kid, ‘my clothes
are up in the bush there; I will go and get them.’ ‘No, you don’t,’
said the wolf, ‘I will go myself; you shall stand there and wait
near me.’ Then the wolf went into the bush, tore down all the old
goat’s clothes, put them on, and came out with a savage face and a
horrid grin. ‘Well,’ said he to the first kid, ‘now go and find the
others, and make them come out; I have disposed of their clothes also,
and put them all on.’ So the first kid went away and called the second
kid, who came and stood before him. ‘What are you looking for, little
kid?’ said the other. ‘I am looking for my clothes,’ answered the
second kid. ‘Where have you put them?’ ‘I have put them behind the
stone-bench there; I will go and get them.’ ‘No, you don’t,’ said the
first kid. ‘I will go myself; you shall stand there and wait near me.’
Then the first kid went with the second kid’s clothes, and did the
same with them as he had done with the first. After this, he called
the third kid, and made him put on his clothes, and so he did with the
fourth, fifth, sixth, and seventh. When all were dressed, the wolf said

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
Once upon a time, in a village that lay in a green valley, where the blue
mountains shut in the horizon, there lived a poor old woman. Her only
furniture consisted of a bed, a table, two benches, and a cupboard. In
the cupboard was one dish, one spoon, one fork, one knife, and one glass.
In one corner stood the old woman’s bed; in the other was a table with
the dish, etc., upon it. Upon the wall hung a cooking-pot and a frying-pan.
In front of the house was a rack where the old woman hung her broom and
her besom. Behind the house was a little garden, in which she grew some
herbs and vegetables. In front of the house was a broad pavement, upon
which the old woman laid a bench, upon which she sat when the weather was
fine, and when she had nothing else to do.

Now it happened that the old woman had nothing to do, for she was very
poor, and could not afford to buy anything, and could not earn anything
by working, because she was so very old. So she sat upon her bench and
looked towards the road, and when any travellers came in sight she ran
out and begged a boon. But the travellers seldom gave her anything, for
they knew that she had nothing to bestow in return, and they did not
like empty-handed people.

One day, as she sat looking very sorrowful and miserable, a stranger
approached. ‘What is the matter, my good woman?’ said he. ‘Ah! sir,’ said
she, ‘what can you do or what have you got with you that would interest
me?’ ‘I have nothing to offer you,’ said the stranger, ‘but I will give
you as much gold as that dish holds.’ ‘How can you do that?’ said the
old woman. ‘Just say please,’ replied the stranger, ‘and it is done.’ ‘Oh!
if you can do that,’ said the old woman, ‘then you can give me my heart’s
desire.’ ‘And what is that?’ said the stranger. ‘Why, to have a dish
full of food set before me every day.’ ‘Is that all?’ said the stranger.
‘That is nothing to what I proposed, but if you please I will grant your
wish.’ ‘Then please God, sir, say so,’ said the old woman, ‘and I will
be very thankful.’ ‘It is done,’ said the stranger; ‘you shall have as
much food as you can eat, set before you every day.’ ‘All this is true,’
said the old woman to the people of the village, ‘and therefore I wish
everybody would wish me “Good morrow.”’ So thenceforth all the people
who passed, whether they knew her or not, called out ‘Good morrow’ to
her, and she was always well provided with good food.

Some time after this a man came into the village, who was very wise, and
famous all over the land for his wisdom. Now it so happened that as he
was travelling along, his way led him through the green valley, and as he
was drawing near the village he heard a woman singing. So he went to see
who it was, and he found it was the old woman. ‘Why,’ said he, ‘what a
noise you make! What are you about?’ ‘Why,’ said she, ‘I am singing for
joy because I have plenty to eat.’ ‘What do you call plenty?’ said the
man. ‘Why,’ said she, ‘every morning as soon as I get up, my dish is
full, and I eat and eat, and still there is room for more.’ ‘Who gave
you that as a gift?’ said the man. ‘A strange man,’ said she, ‘who gave
me a lump of gold as big as the dish, and said I might have as much as
it would hold, and told me that if anybody would please me they must
wish me “Good morrow.”’ ‘Ah!’ said the man, ‘you have not used your
wish wisely. You ought to have asked for wealth, for gold and silver, and
precious stones, and you would have had enough of all these, and could
have given the stranger something in return for his gift.’ ‘What would
you have done?’ said the old woman. ‘Why,’ said the man, ‘I should have
asked for a dish full of gold every day.’ ‘But I like my present,’ said
the old woman, ‘for I have plenty to eat, and I will not change it for
all the wealth in the world.’

Now the man thought to himself that the old woman would have been a
great deal better off if she had taken his advice; so he went away, and
travelled on through the green valley. As he went on, he saw a man who
was making a most furious noise, and jumping about and dancing. ‘What are
you about, my friend?’ said the wise man to the other. ‘Can you tell me
what has happened?’ ‘Why,’ said the man, ‘I am delighted. I am rich,
rich, rich!’ ‘What have you got?’ said the wise man. ‘Why,’ said the
man, ‘I had nothing to do, and had not a penny in the world to buy
anything with, and I met a strange man, who asked me what I would wish
for, and I said, “I wish for a dish of food that would never leave me
hungry.” And now, as I live, I am never again in danger of dying of
hunger.’ ‘Ah!’ said the wise man, ‘you might have asked for a dish of gold
every day, and then you would have had enough to eat as long as it
lasted, and would have had plenty to sell to buy food.’ ‘What’s the use
of gold?’ said the man. ‘Can it satisfy my hunger?’ ‘No,’ said the wise
man, ‘but it would buy you food.’ ‘I don’t want to trouble myself about
that,’ said the man; ‘I am very thankful for what I have got, and I will
not change it for all the wealth in the world.’

Then the wise man went on through the green valley, and as he went he
heard a great noise of laughing and merrymaking. He went to see what
was the matter, and he found a man who was dancing for joy, and who had
a gold dish full of ducats by him. ‘What are you about, my friend?’ said
the wise man. ‘What’s the meaning of all this?’ ‘Why,’ said the man, ‘I
am rich, I am rich!’ ‘What have you got?’ said the wise man. ‘Why,’ said
the man, ‘I had nothing to do, and I met a strange man, who asked me what
I would wish for, and I said, “I wish for a dish of gold.” And now, as
I live, I have got a dish of gold.’ ‘Ah!’ said the wise man, ‘you might
have asked for a dish of food that would never leave you hungry.’ ‘What
is food to a man who has gold?’ said the other. ‘Can you buy beef and
beer with ducats?’ ‘No,’ said the man, ‘but you can buy them with the
money that ducats will buy.’ ‘Well,’ said the wise man, ‘your wish is
granted, and you will always have plenty of money, but you have lost the
chance of having plenty of food.’ ‘I don’t care for food,’ said the man,
‘if I have money; what can I want with beef and beer, when I can buy
them?’

Then the wise man went on through the green valley, and as he went he
heard a great noise of feasting and revelry.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a man who had a horse that had been his companion for many years, but now was grown too old to be of any use. His master, therefore, no longer took any care of him, and let him run in the woods as much as he pleased; but still he always came home to his stable at night.

One day it so happened that the man had to go a long way, and when he was ready to start he went into the stable to get his horse and found him not there. He called him, but all in vain; then he was grieved, and said, ‘Alas! my old companion, what will become of thee in the wood, where all sorts of wild beasts abound?’

When the horse heard this he turned white with fear, and trotted home as fast as he could to his master’s house, and from that time forward never left it.

Some time after, the man wanted to go a second time, and again looked for his horse, but could not find him; and when he had searched in vain for a long time, he went into the house very much grieved, and said, ‘Alas! I see I cannot keep even one horse; they all run away from me.’

Then the horse, that was all the time standing in the field, heard him, and was so frightened that he turned white, and when his master came home he trotted up to meet him, and from that time forward always remained at home.

Some time after, the man wanted to go a third time, and looked for his horse; but he was not to be found, and his master, seeing him nowhere, said, ‘This time he has certainly run away, and will never come back.’

The horse, however, was standing all the time in his stall, and hearing his master speak of him as having run away, was so frightened that he turned pale, and when the man came home he came to meet him, and from that time forward never left home again.

One day the man wanted to go a fourth time, and went to look for his horse; but he was not there, and his master said, ‘He has run away, and will never come back.’ Then the horse, that was all the time in his stall, heard him speak of running away, and was so frightened that he turned pale, and when his master came home he came to meet him, and from that time forward never went out of his stable at all.

When the man came home the fourth time, he went into the stable and found his horse standing in his stall; but he was so pale and meagre that he could not have weighed above a hundred pounds. Then he seized him by the bridle and said, ‘Why, what is the matter with you? You have run away, have you? You have been in the wood, have you? You have been eating grass, have you? You have been drinking water, have you? You have been carrying anyone on your back, have you?’ But the horse did not say a word, and just shook his head.

Then his master took him to the field, and made him pull at the plough; but he could hardly move it, and soon fell down exhausted, and lay panting and gasping for breath. Then his master scolded him, and said, ‘You wretch! you have run away, have you? You have been in the wood, have you? You have been eating grass, have you? You have been drinking water, have you? You have been carrying anyone on your back, have you?’

And the horse did not say a word, but just shook his head.

Then his master made him rise, and took him to the mill; but when he began to work and turn the mill, he fell down and did not turn it at all, but lay there gasping for breath. Then the master was very angry, and said, ‘You wretch! you have run away, have you? You have been in the wood, have you? You have been eating grass, have you? You have been drinking water, have you? You have been carrying anyone on your back, have you?’

But the horse did not say a word, and only shook his head.

Then the master took him to the river, and made him stand in the stream, and said, ‘Now, at last, you must carry someone across; you have had enough rest.’ But when he began to do it, he fell down in the middle of the stream and could not stir, and there he lay gasping for breath, with the water running over him.

There was once a king who had a beautiful garden full of all kinds of fine flowers, and in the middle stood a large tree. It was so old that one of its branches touched the sky, and it was so big that you could not reach around it with your arms. And when the wind blew, it swayed to and fro with such a strange noise that it was said to be haunted. But the king’s daughter went there every day, and sat down under the old tree, and she could not believe that it was haunted.

One day she took with her a little basket of bread crumbs, and as she sat there eating, a small, small, very small, old man appeared. At first he was so small that he could just barely walk in and out among the tree’s roots, but he ate and grew bigger and bigger, until he was as big as a man. Then he looked at the princess, and said, ‘Lady, why do you come here every day?’ ‘Because I like to be alone, and here I am best alone,’ answered she. ‘If that be so,’ said the little man, ‘then I will keep your secret, and no one in the world shall know it; but promise me that you will promise me something in return.’ ‘What should I promise you?’ said the princess. ‘That you will give me your ring,’ answered the little man. ‘I will promise you anything only promise not to ask me for my ring.’ So they spent the day very pleasantly together, and the little man went away.

The next day the princess took with her a shining golden ring, and the little man came again, but he abode not so small as before, but sat himself upon the grass and ate no more. Then she told him everything that had happened to her, and how no one believed that she could not be haunted, for the old tree was said to be haunted. ‘Alas!’ said the princess, ‘I should like to know whether it be so or not.’ ‘Then promise me,’ said the little man, ‘that you will give me your golden ring, if I will go into the tree and find out for you.’ ‘I will promise you anything, only promise not to ask me for my golden ring.’ So on the third day the little man went into the tree, and the princess waited till he came out again. But he did not come out at all, and the princess waited till the evening, and then went home, very much grieved.

The next day she took with her a shining golden ring, and went to the tree, and said, ‘Dear little man, do go into the old tree and find out if it be haunted or not.’ ‘I will go,’ said the little man, and away he went. prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a queen who had a little daughter, still too young to run alone.

The child was fair and good, but very, very mischievous; and the queen, trying to check her naughtiness, gave her a little nut, and said, ‘From this time forward you shall be called Hazel-nut, and as long as this nut lasts, you shall have whatever it is you can say when I open the door to go out.’

The little girl liked this very much, and when her mother went out, she always stood by the door and said something, and her mother had to tell her what she should have. Thus she got books, and balls, and apples, and pears, and all things that she could think of, till the nut was nearly gone.

Then she said, ‘Mother, I want a fine doll.’ ‘What will you say when I go out?’ said the mother. ‘I will say, “I want a fine doll.”’ ‘Go on, then, and tell your father.’

But the father said, ‘My dear child, you have had many things, now you shall have air and exercise, and have the window opened.’

The little girl was very angry, and her mother heard her muttering something as she went out. She thought nothing of it, but went out herself. Then the little girl said, ‘The wind,’ and a little wind came, and blew the window all to pieces. Her father became very angry, and said, ‘You shall have nothing more, till you have paid for the window.’

The child was still more angry, and when her mother went out she said, ‘The storm.’ And a storm came, and all the roof was blown away. Then her father said, ‘You shall not have meat or drink till you have paid for the roof.’

When her mother went out she said, ‘The hail.’ And such a hailstorm came, that all the fruit in the garden was broken. Then her father said, ‘You shall not have anything to eat or drink till you have paid for the fruit.’

When her mother went out she said, ‘The fire.’ And a fire came, and burnt down the house over her. Then her father said, ‘You shall have nothing to eat or drink, nor wear clothes, till you have paid for all.’

So the little girl stood by the door, and her mother asked her what she wanted. ‘I want air to breathe,’ said she. ‘Then you shall have it,’ said the mother, ‘but you shall not have meat or drink, nor wear clothes, till you are big.’

So the child had nothing to eat or drink, nor to wear, and was very, very hungry and cold. But she was still pretty, and people came from all around to look at her, and she danced and capered about, and was merry.

Now there was a king’s son in the country, who heard of this little dancing girl, and went to see her. ‘Dance for me, little girl,’ said he. Then she danced and capered about, and was very merry. ‘Shall I dance for you again?’ said she. ‘Yes,’ said he. So she danced again, and was very merry. ‘Shall I dance for you a third time?’ said she. ‘Yes,’ said he. But this time she danced so high and so wildly, that she got upon his horse’s back, and so away.

Then the king’s son was very angry, and he followed her, and she rode on and on, till at last she came to a little cottage. ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I cannot go in, for I am clad in rags and have nothing to eat.’ Then a little dwarf came out, and he took her in, and gave her meat and drink, and made her a pretty little bed, and said, ‘Lie down and sleep.’ So she slept, and when she awoke all her clothes were got ready, and she was as pretty as ever.

Then the little dwarf said, ‘I see that you are in trouble, and that you are very, very hungry. I will take you into the town, and there you shall have meat and drink, and whatever you want.’ So he took her into the town, and she ate and drank, and bought whatever she wanted.

But when she had eaten and dressed herself, she said to the little dwarf, ‘I am very, very cold.’ Then the little dwarf said, ‘I see that you are in trouble, and that you are very, very cold. I will take you to the king’s palace, and there you shall have heat and light, and whatever you want.’ So he took her to the king’s palace, and she went from room to room, till she came to the king’s bed-chamber, and lay down by the side of the king’s son, and soon fell asleep.

In the morning the king’s son awoke, and saw her, and said, ‘Shall I kill her?’ But the dwarf said, ‘No, she is no common child.’ Then the king’s son said, ‘She shall be my wife.’ But the dwarf said, ‘She must first eat a pear, which is bigger than her head.’ Now the dwarf brought the pear from home. So they gave her the pear to eat, and when it was eaten, she became bigger and bigger, and at last was as big as a mountain. Then said the king’s son to the dwarf, ‘Now take her away, and let her go home to her own country.’ So the dwarf took her home, and set her down before her father’s house, and she was so big that her head touched the sky.

Then her father and mother came to meet her, and her father said, ‘Little Hazel-nut, how have you been travelling?’ ‘Oh, father,’ said she, ‘I have been to the sun and moon.’ ‘And how came you home?’ said her father. ‘Oh, father,’ said she, ‘the wind took me home.’ ‘What did you wear?’ said her father. ‘Oh, father,’ said she, ‘the rain and dew fell on me, and I wore them for clothes.’ ‘What did you eat?’ said her father. ‘Oh, father,’ said she, ‘the locusts and grasshoppers came and ate me.’ ‘What did you do?’ said her father. ‘Oh, father,’ said she, ‘I danced, and they clapped their hands and capered about, and set the whole land in motion, and carried me along with them.’

Then they knew that she was still the same little Hazel-nut, and they rejoiced, and danced, and feasted, and made merry, and welcomed her home.

The End

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Enchanted Fiddle

There was once a poor woodman, who cut wood in the forest, and earned just
enough to support himself and his wife, and keep themselves from dying of
hunger. One day he cut down a mighty tree, and as he was pulling it, it
fell against his foot, so that he cried out in pain, and the blood ran
abundantly. Then he was very sad, for he saw that the injury was not
light, and he could not go home. ‘What shall I do?’ said he. ‘I cannot
sit here and wait till I die of hunger, and I cannot go home and trouble my
wife with my misfortunes.’ At last he thought of the ravens, and cried
aloud: ‘Dear ravens, my friends of old, come hither and help me!’ But the
ravens did not come. ‘Ungrateful creatures!’ said he; ‘they will not help
me in my need.’ Then he cried: ‘If you are not my friends, at least you
ought to be so for fear of God!’ But still the ravens did not come. So he
walked on with his wounded foot, and after a time came to a little cottage,
where an old woman lived, who was renowned for her skill in healing all
kinds of wounds. He knocked at the door, and when she came out, he told her
his tale, and begged her to heal his foot. She looked at it, and said:
‘I will heal thy foot, if thou wilt work hard for me, and do all I bid thee
for a whole year.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said the woodman; ‘only do as thou
wilt, and I am thy servant.’

So she washed the wound with a decoction of herbs, and bound it up, and
when he had stayed a month, his foot was healed, and he was able to go home
to his wife. Then the old woman said to him: ‘Listen, woodman, I have
healed thee, but thou must keep myself in bondage for a year, and work
hard for me.’ ‘What shall I do?’ asked the woodman. ‘Every Saturday night
and Sunday I must bring you the most beautiful flower which blooms in the
forest, and every Friday evening I must bring you here the fattest venison,
and every holiday a cake made of the finest flour, and besides this I
must work in your garden, and do all the work of the house.’ ‘Is all this
needful?’ asked the woodman. ‘Oh, no!’ answered the old woman, ‘I am only
so old and weak that I cannot do as I would like, and I have no near
relatives to help me; so you must do all you can to make me comfortable,
and then I will give you a magic fiddle, which will enable you to draw
whatever you please with it.’

The woodman consented, and worked hard for the old woman, and thought
himself fortunate in having such a treasure as the fiddle to look forward
to. Every week he went into the forest to seek for the beautiful flower,
and every deer which came in his way he brought home, and every time there
was a holiday he baked a cake. But the old woman’s garden wanted constant
cultivating, and there was always some task to be done in the house.

And now it came to pass that the woodman’s wife was one day standing in
the street, and the gold from her ring fell off, and rolled into the gutter.
When she saw this she began to cry, and said: ‘Alas, what will become of
me? I know not where my husband is, and I cannot go to look for him, for
if I do I should be sure to forget the time, and then the children would
be left alone. What a wretched wife I am!’ And she wept and lamented over
her lost gold, and did not think of the time, but her eldest boy came home
from school, and her second boy came in from playing, and then she saw that
she had kept them alone, and was very sorry.

Meantime the woodman came home, and asked his wife what made her weep.
Then she told him all her trouble, and said: ‘How can you work so hard, and
leave your poor wife and children alone?’ ‘I cannot help that,’ said the
woodman; ‘I must do what I can to get the magic fiddle.’ ‘But I cannot have
you at all, if you are going to leave me in this way.’ ‘I will do what I
can to help you,’ said the woodman. ‘I will take the children with me to
the forest, and cut us a hut there, and you shall come and visit us at
any time.’ The wife liked this plan very much, and the woodman cut down a
tree, and built a hut for himself and his wife and children in the forest.
Then he made a bed of moss for his wife, and one for himself, and one for
each of his children, and brought her thither, and she was very glad to
see it. ‘Now,’ said she, ‘I will take a walk in the forest, and see how
beautiful it is.’ So she went away, and the woodman watched the children,
that they did not run about and get lost. And when his wife had been away
a long time, he sent one of his boys to call her, but he came back and said
she was not within the hut. Then he sent the other, but he also returned,
and said he could not find her. ‘What shall I do?’ said the woodman. ‘I will
go myself, and see if I can find her.’ But he sought his wife all round,
and could nowhere see her, and he was very much frightened, and ran home to
the old woman, and said: ‘My wife has been living with me in the forest,
but she has lost herself there, and I am sure she will never find her way
home again.’ Then the old woman comforted him, and said: ‘I will play on
my fiddle, and she will hear it and follow the sound.’

So she took the fiddle, and tuned it, and as she stroked the strings a
most wonderful sound was heard. Then the woodman went home, and the old
woman followed, and they both waited till they heard the woodman’s wife
approaching. At length they heard the sound of steps, and presently she
came in view, dancing merrily through the forest. When she came up to the
hut, she said: ‘Dear friends, what a wonderful music that is! I have been
following it, and I never could have found my way home without it.’ Then
the old woman said to her: ‘Pray sit down and rest yourself, and tell me
what you have seen in the forest.’ ‘Oh,’ said she, ‘I have seen the most
wonderful things! I have seen a fox, and a wolf, and a stag, and a goat,
and a wild boar, all sitting and eating out of one dish, and nobody
interfering with another’s share.’ ‘That is wonderful,’ said the old woman,
‘but come in, and tell me more.’ ‘Well,’ continued the wife, ‘I went
nearer to look at them, and they let me sit down and eat with them, and
the dish was so big, and they were so polite, that I ate and ate, till at
last I could eat no more, and then I got upon my feet to go home, but I
could not find my way, and I have been wandering about ever since.’ ‘Well,
wife,’ said the woodman, ‘you must work hard for us, and help us in the
garden and the house, as my boy and my little girl will do.’ ‘With all my
heart,’ said she, ‘I will work as hard

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Snow Queen

In a land far, far away, there lived a good and kind old man named Klaes. He had once been a great sorcerer, but he had long since given up his magic wand and spent his time in peace and quiet, making beautiful pictures on the windows of his cottage.

One day, as he was working at his window, a sharp piece of glass fell from the frame and cut his finger. As he gazed sorrowfully at the drop of blood that welled up, he happened to look through the window, and saw a dazzlingly beautiful sight. The sun was shining brightly, and the rays fell upon a myriad of little particles that were dancing and whirling in the air. ‘What a host of fairies!’ said the old man. ‘They must have brought me that piece of glass as a present, for it was a very fine one.’ Then he raised his head and called out: ‘Good fairies, in return for this beautiful gift, I wish one thing. I want a wife.’

Scarcely were the words out of his mouth, when a fairy came to the window, and tapped at it with her finger. Klaes looked at her, and she seemed to him to be even more beautiful than the sun itself. ‘You have only to wish,’ said she, ‘and your wish is fulfilled.’ Then Klaes looked round him, and saw a beautiful young woman standing in the room. ‘She is not quite so beautiful as the fairy,’ thought he; ‘but she is very pretty, and I have no doubt she will please me.’

He got up and went to meet her, and as he took her hand she said: ‘My name is Gerda, and the fairy has told me that I must love whoever has won me; so I will love you.’

So they were married, and lived happily together for a long time. But one day, when the sun was shining with great brilliance, a small splinter of glass from the window fell into the room, and wounded Gerda’s eye. In an instant she became ice-cold, and her face took on a pale and foreign aspect. ‘Alas!’ she cried, ‘all the world looks so strange to me! I cannot stay with you any longer.’

Then she went away, and Klaes followed her, but he could not overtake her, for she soon got so far away that he could no longer see her. ‘I know not what sorceress has bewitched her,’ said he; ‘yet I will follow her, and bring her back, or die in the attempt.’

So he journeyed on through a land of snow and ice, and the cold grew so great that his blood became frozen, and he was turned into an old man once more. Thus he continued for many years, and at last he came to a palace of crystal, where he saw a most beautiful room, and in the middle of it stood Gerda, looking quite happy. But when she saw Klaes she started with dread, and said: ‘I thought you were dead long since; for I have been with the Snow Queen.’

Then the old man told her how he had followed her, and how he had suffered for her sake, and how he still would suffer, if only she would go back with him. But she said: ‘I cannot go away from the Snow Queen; for she is so much more powerful than you, that she can make the sun stand still whenever she likes. I can stay here with her as long as I please, and when I grow tired I can go out and sit upon the snow, and look round at the world.’

While they were thus speaking, the Snow Queen came in, and said: ‘I have been out upon the snow, and have ridden upon a comet, and have seen the most beautiful stars in the world. Come with me, and you shall see them too.’

Then she took Gerda by the hand, and led her forth, and Klaes followed them. The Snow Queen said: ‘I am so glad that you have come, that I have had my palace of crystal heated, so that it is not colder here than it is in summer at home.’

So they went out upon the snow together, and the Snow Queen took Gerda upon her sledge, and Klaes followed behind. Then the Snow Queen said: ‘I am going to take you to my palace, that you may see it.’ So they went on through the night, over the snow and the ice, till at length they came to a beautiful palace made of snow and glass. And the Snow Queen said to Gerda: ‘You shall live here with me.’

But Klaes besought her with tears in his eyes, and said: ‘Pray let Gerda go, for she is my wife, and I will take care of her.’ ‘No,’ said the Snow Queen, ‘she shall never go back to you.’

Then Klaes begged so hard that she became angry, and said: ‘Very well, she shall go with you; but you must do what I tell you.’ ‘What do I have to do?’ said he. ‘Every year’s end, when the ravens are calling, you must go out upon the snow, and look for me; and when you find me, you must bow down and say: “I am the queen of the world; I rule over sun, moon, and stars; I must have the most beautiful red-bird in the world, and it shall sing in my right hand, and in my left hand shall sit the white dove, which brings the souls of the dead to heaven.” When you have said this, I will let Gerda go.’

Then the Snow Queen let Gerda go, and as the old man looked at her she seemed to be quite herself again, and she threw her arms round his neck, and said: ‘Now, indeed, I am happy.’

And Klaes took her home to his cottage, where they lived in joy and contentment for many years. And every year’s end, when the ravens were calling, he went out upon the snow, and looked for the Snow Queen, and bowed down to her, and said: ‘I am the queen of the world; I rule over sun, moon, and stars; I must have the most beautiful red-bird in the world, and it shall sing in my right hand, and in my left hand shall sit the white dove, which brings the souls of the dead to heaven.’

And the Snow Queen said: ‘He does all that I ask; I cannot help setting him free.’

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a shepherd who had a faithful dog, called Sultan, that was very
old, and had lost all his teeth. His master had now begun to think of getting
rid of him, as he did not think he was of much use any longer; but Sultan still
remained at the bottom of the hill where the flock fed, and slept under the
hedge close by, and was as faithful as ever.

One day the shepherd took his stand upon a hill, and the dog, seeing the
flock was safe, went to sleep; but the shepherd soon called out, ‘Sultan! Sultan!
awake, the sheep are running away!’ The dog started, and saw the whole
flock was gone, and a few lambs were straggling down the hill. ‘Alas!’ said he,
‘what shall I do?’ So he began to run after them as fast as he could, barking
loud, and making the best of his way down the hill.

The sheep, seeing the old dog coming, soon left off running, and began to
stand still, and one by one they began to turn round and face the dog, till
all were facing one way. Then Sultan came up to them, and bit one of them
in the tail, and away he ran with all his might, barking loud, over hill and
dale, till he had run about a hundred yards, when he stopped and called out,
‘Stop, stop!’ Then the sheep that he had bitten in the tail, and all the rest
that were with it, stopped, but all the rest kept running away over the
hill. Sultan came back to them, and bit another sheep in the tail, and away
he ran again, barking as loud as he could; and when he had run about a hundred
yards, and called out, ‘Stop, stop!’ that sheep and all that were with it
stopped, but the others kept running away. This happened a third time; and
then all the sheep that were left stood still, for all the sheep that were run
down were those that had been the most forward in running away.

Then the old dog sat down among them, and when he had rested himself a while,
he began to bark again, and all the sheep began to run away over the hill.
But Sultan let them run, till they had all gone, and then he called out,
‘Stop, stop!’ and all turned round and faced him.

So now the old dog knew that all the flock was together again; and he began
to bark as merry a bark as ever he could, and wagged his tail, and jumped
and danced for joy, and then began to run round and round among them, and
nipped here and nipped there, but bit nobody. And now the sheep were all
safe, and the shepherd came and brought them back to the fold. Then the old
dog jumped up and licked the shepherd’s face, and wagged his tail, as happy
as could be. ‘Well, Sultan,’ said the shepherd, ‘you have been true to me, and
I will be true to you; so you shall live and be well taken care of, and have
food enough, and rest enough, and be well taken care of, till I see fit to take
you to your long home.’ ‘Amen!’ said the dog, which, as you perhaps do not
know, means ‘So be it.’ And from this time forward the old shepherd took
better care of his faithful friend, and gave him plenty of food, and let him
lie and sleep whenever he pleased, and took good care of him till the end of
his days.

The End.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor old woman who had nothing to live upon but one little pot of lard. She was very fond of her lard, and used to sit looking at it, and saying, ‘Will it not be a pity if that should be gone?’ Now, one day, she left the house, and took the pot of lard with her, that she might not be tempted to use it. She did not lock up the house, but put the key into her apron pocket, and took the pot of lard in her hand. As she crossed the field, a little dumpling, that could speak and move, said to her, ‘Where are you going to take that pot of lard, old woman?’ ‘I am taking it with me,’ said she, ‘because I should be sure to use it if I left it at home.’ ‘If you will give me a drop, every now and then, as you walk along, I shall be very much obliged to you,’ said the dumpling. ‘Be quiet,’ said the old woman, ‘you are not my only companion; I have a great many more to look after.’ Then she gave the dumpling a little of the lard, and went on, saying to herself, ‘You must not use the lard, or you will repent it.’

As she crossed the field, a little piece of rag, that could also speak and move, said, ‘Where are you going to take that pot of lard, old woman?’ ‘I am taking it with me,’ said she, ‘because I should be sure to use it if I left it at home.’ ‘If you will give me a little of it every now and then, as you go along, I shall be very much obliged to you,’ said the piece of rag. ‘Be quiet,’ said the old woman, ‘you are not the only one; I have many more to look after.’ Then she gave the piece of rag a little of the lard, and went on muttering, ‘You must not use the lard, or you will repent it.’

As she crossed the field, a little bone, that could also speak and move, said, ‘Where are you going to take that pot of lard, old woman?’ ‘I am taking it with me,’ said she, ‘because I should be sure to use it if I left it at home.’ ‘If you will give me a little of it every now and then, as you go along, I shall be very much obliged to you,’ said the bone. ‘Be quiet,’ said the old woman, ‘you are not the only one; I have many more to look after.’ Then she gave the bone a little of the lard, and went on muttering, ‘You must not use the lard, or you will repent it.’

As she crossed the field, a little piece of string, that could also speak and move, said, ‘Where are you going to take that pot of lard, old woman?’ ‘I am taking it with me,’ said she, ‘because I should be sure to use it if I left it at home.’ ‘If you will give me a little of it every now and then, as you go along, I shall be very much obliged to you,’ said the piece of string. ‘Be quiet,’ said the old woman, ‘you are not the only one; I have many more to look after.’ Then she gave the piece of string a little of the lard, and went on muttering, ‘You must not use the lard, or you will repent it.’

At last she came to a little house, and thought she would rest there for a while. ‘Here, you may remain,’ said she to the dumpling, ‘till I come back,’ and set it down on a shelf; then she did the same with the piece of rag, the bone, and the piece of string. ‘Now, I shall have some rest,’ said she; and she sat herself by the fire and warmed herself, and took the pot of lard with her, and said, ‘I will not use you, I will not use you.’

But she could not help giving a little drop now and then into the fire, to make the flames burn more brightly; and every time she did so, her heart grew lighter within her, and she felt as if a great burden was taken from her. At last, when the pot was nearly empty, she said, ‘I will give you one drop more, fire, and then not another.’ Then she gave it to her, and the fire blazed up, and the old woman’s heart leapt within her, and all her troubles seemed to be taken away, and she felt light-hearted and happy. ‘I am rich indeed,’ said she, ‘with this little pot of lard gone, and my heart so light within me.’ So she jumped up, and danced for joy, and the old house rang again with her merry laugh.

Then she took out her key, and opened the door, and went out, and gathered together her dumpling, and her piece of rag, and her bone, and her piece of string, and took them all with her, and said, ‘I will not use you, I will not use you.’

When she came to a river she could not pass over it, for she was very old, so she said, ‘Ho! ho! here you go, my five friends, help me over.’ Then the dumpling said, ‘We will be a bridge.’ So the piece of rag laid himself across as a bridge, and the bone threw himself across, one on each side of the rag, and straightened himself out stiff as a rod. Then the piece of string hung across over the top of them, and shook itself right tight, so that none of them could move, and the old woman walked safely over, and then they drew themselves up, one after another, into a straight line, as stiff as a rod, and the old woman came back, and took them up one by one, saying, ‘I will not use you, I will not use you.’

When she came to a hill that was too high for her to climb, she said, ‘Ho! ho! here you go, my five friends, help me up.’ Then the dumpling said, ‘We will be a steps.’ So the piece of rag laid himself across as steps, one above another, and the bone threw himself across, one on each side of the rag, and stretched himself out stiff as a rod, and the piece of string hung across over the top of them, and shook itself right tight, so that none of them could move, and the old woman climbed up, step by step, and then they drew themselves up, one after another, into a straight line, as stiff as a rod, and the old woman came back, and took them up one by one, saying, ‘I will not use you, I will not use you.’

When she came to a castle, she said, ‘Ho! ho! here you go, my five friends, help me into the castle.’ Then the dumpling said, ‘We will be a ladder.’ So the piece of rag laid himself across as steps, one above another, hard by the wall, and the bone threw himself across, one on each side of the rag, and stretched himself out stiff as a rod, and the piece of string hung across over the top of them, and shook itself right tight, so that none of them could move, and the old woman climbed up, step by step, and then they drew themselves up, one after another, into a straight line, as stiff as a rod, and the old woman came back, and took them up one by one, saying, ‘I will not use you, I will not use you.’

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The Snow Queen

In a village in Norway, there lived a tailor named Kai. He was a good
tailor, and made the best clothes in all the land. But he was very proud of
his skill, and would say: ‘I am the best workman in the world.’ One day
a stranger came to the village. He was an old man, with a long white
beard, and he looked wise. Kai told him boastfully that he could make
any kind of cloths. ‘Your work may be very fine,’ said the old man, ‘but
not as fine as the snowflakes which fall from the heavens.’ ‘What!’
cried Kai, ‘cannot I make my work as fine as the snowflakes?’ ‘Certainly
not,’ said the old man; ‘go out and look.’ Then Kai went out, and the
old man took a feather from his cap and sprinkled the snow with it. When
Kai came back, the old man said: ‘Look sharp, and see if there is not one
snowflake exactly like another.’ Then Kai looked, and thought he should
never find two alike, and he became very sad and troubled, and said: ‘How
can I call myself a workman, when even the snowflakes are finer than my
work?’

As he was thus thinking, a dazzlingly beautiful girl came in. It was the
Snow Queen. ‘Do not grieve, Kai,’ said she; ‘I will soon set you free
from all your troubles. Here is a shred of my frost-silk; weave me a
little shirt with it, and cut me out a suit of clothes.’ Then Kai looked
at the shred of silk, and it was so fine that the smallest snowflake
seemed coarse and clumsy by the side of it. Still he tried to weave the
shirt, but in vain; the silk was too slippery and fine for his clumsy
fingers.

Meanwhile the Snow Queen went out, and the tailor was left alone. He
began to be uneasy, and said to himself: ‘What if the beautiful girl
should never come back?’ So he determined to weave a shirt for her, and
cut out a suit of clothes, without waiting for her order. When it was
ready he laid it on his table, and it was so fine that words are not
enough to tell how beautiful it was. Then he went out to look for the
Snow Queen, but she was gone. He searched the whole village, but she was
not to be found. At last he went out of the country, and travelled over
sea and land, looking for her, but in vain. He asked the birds of the
air, the beasts of the field, and the fishes of the sea, if they had
seen his beloved one; but they shook their heads, and said, ‘We know
her not.’

At last he came to the Palace of the Snow Queen, which was in the
heavens. There he hoped to find her; but when he got there, all the
people gazed upon him, and said: ‘Who is this? He is not like us.’ Then
they took him before the judge, who said: ‘This man is not like us; he
is not made of ice and snow like we are; therefore he must leave our
neighbourhood.’

Kai begged so hard to be allowed to stay, that they at last said he might
go and look for the Snow Queen, and bring her to them if he could find
her. So he went forth again on his journey, and sought for the Snow
Queen through the world, over sea and land, in the summer and in the
winter, in the day-time and in the night-time; but she was not to be
found. Then he began to be very sad, and thought he should never see her
again.

One day, as he was wandering through a strange country, he saw a little
boy sitting under a tree, and close by the boy there was a burnt-out
cinder glowing red-hot. The boy was picking up pebbles and throwing them
at the cinder, but they only hissed and fizzled, and flew back again.
Then Kai said to him, ‘What are you doing?’ ‘I am trying,’ said the boy,
‘to kill that cinder; but it is no use, for it always lives again and
becomes hot again.’ ‘How stupid!’ said Kai; ‘why do you try to kill it?
It is only a cinder, and will do you no harm.’ ‘Oh! yes, it has done me
great harm,’ said the boy; ‘for it burnt my leg so that I could not sit
or walk, till it healed; and now it has burnt me again.’

Kai took the boy upon his knee, and said: ‘Tell me, who burnt your leg
the first time?’ ‘The old woman did,’ answered the boy, ‘who lives in
the nut-tree.’ ‘And what has the Snow Queen to do with the matter?’ said
Kai. ‘Ah!’ said the boy, ‘the old woman took me away from my home, and
carried me with her into the nut-tree; and there she burnt my leg on the
cinder, and then set me to watch the nuts, so that no one might take
them away. And now she has taken away all my marbles, and all my pretty
things, and has threatened that if I do not work hard and watch well,
she will burn me again.’

Kai said: ‘I will soon set you free.’ Then he took a hatchet, and cut down
the nut-tree, and the old woman who was in it, fell down dead. He took
the boy home with him, and they travelled on together.

One day they came to a palace made of card-houses, and the roof and all
were so high that they could not reach it. ‘This must be the dwelling of
the Snow Queen,’ said Kai; ‘but how can we get in?’ Then the boy said:
‘I know how we can get in.’ He fetched a little piece of marsh allow,
and set fire to it; then they went to work, and set fire to the palace,
and when the flames had burnt away a part of it, they went in.

In one of the rooms they found a little girl, who was so beautiful that
Kai had never seen any one so beautiful. She was gazing upon her own
image in a looking-glass, and did not see them come in. ‘That must be
the Snow Queen,’ said Kai; ‘has not her face the most beautiful of any
you have ever seen?’ ‘Yes,’ said the boy, ‘but look at her eyes.’ Then
Kai looked, and saw that each eye was full of pins. ‘I must take care of
that,’ said he; ‘I will shut her into a cage, so that she cannot do any
harm.’ So he made a cage of twigs, and shut her in it, and they took
her with them.

They journeyed on through a country where it was always winter, and
snowed and blew hard. At last they came to a palace made of ice and snow,
and there the Snow Queen lived. When she saw Kai she was very glad, and
said: ‘Now at last I am safe, and you cannot escape me.’ But Kai said:
‘I have brought the little boy with me, who knows all about you; and
here is the little girl, who is so beautiful, but has pins in her eyes;
and here is the old woman who burnt the little boy; and here is the
nut-tree; and here is the marsh allow with which we burnt the palace.’
Then he showed her all his trophies.

And now the Snow Queen was very
