There was once a poor woodman, who cut wood in the forest, and lived with his wife in a little cottage upon the outskirts of the same. They had one child, a daughter, who was very pretty, and had eyes like the prettiest blue flowers in the forest, and a nose like a cherry, and lips like the berries upon the rose-bush, and a neck as white and dainty as a swan’s. The woodman and his wife loved their little daughter very much, and were very happy when they looked at her; but often when they looked at each other they were very sorrowful, for they had no money to buy her anything to wear.

One day the woodman cut too deep, and the axe fell and wounded him so that he lay ill for many weeks. His wife watched by him day and night, but they had no money to buy food, and soon all they had in the world was spent. Then the little daughter went into the forest and gathered nuts and berries, till she was very thin and pale; and when the woodman got better he was very sorrowful to see how his little daughter looked.

One day he said, ‘I will cut myself no more wood, but will sit by the cottage door and watch the highway that leads by our house, and if I see any traveller going the way the little girl shall go and beg a penny’s worth of bread for me.’

Now as he sat there, he saw a little dwarf, about half as high as a man, and as thin as a rush, and looking quite ruddy and rolly-poly, and merry. The dwarf had a small red cloak on, and a hat with a feather in it, and a little gun slung round his neck, and a bow and arrows at his back. ‘Well, well,’ said the dwarf, ‘what’s your business, man?’ ‘I am very ill,’ said the woodman. ‘That’s a pity. What ails you?’ ‘My little girl has been into the forest and gathered nuts and berries till she is all thin and pale, and I had to lie ill for want of food, and now we are very poor and have nothing to eat.’ ‘Well,’ said the dwarf, ‘I will soon set all that right. I like your little daughter very much, so I’ll do as you wish, and come every day, and bring your little girl a basket of nuts and berries, so that she shall never be able to carry them all away. But in return for that I am to have a little room in the cottage, and you must let me do as I please in it, and never go in there, or take it away from me.’ ‘Anything, anything,’ said the woodman, ‘so that we may have bread to eat.’ ‘Very well,’ said the dwarf; ‘my people shall take care of you, and I myself will come every day and bring your little girl a basket of nuts and berries.’

So the little dwarf was true to his word, and every day the little girl looked for him, and he came trotting along, and then they were always well supplied with nuts and berries. And the dwarf took up his abode in the little room, and the woodman and his wife never went in there, and did not even speak of it.

The little girl grew prettier and plumper every day, for now she always had something to eat; and when her father was strong enough to work again, they were better off than they had ever been before, for the dwarf brought the nuts and berries every day.

Now it happened that the little girl was walking in the forest alone one day, and the dwarf was not coming as usual, so she waited for him a long while, but he stayed away. And it grew dark, and she did not like to go home alone, so she went into a little hut that she had never seen before, to spend the night there. And as she was going to light herself a fire, she saw a queer little old woman sitting in the corner. ‘Why, where are you from, pretty child?’ said the old woman. ‘From home,’ said the little girl. ‘Where do you live, pretty child?’ said the old woman. ‘In the wood.’ ‘With whom, pretty child?’ said the old woman. ‘With my father and mother.’ ‘What are you doing, pretty child?’ said the old when you get home, pretty child?’ said the old woman. ‘To lie down and go to sleep.’ ‘Where do you sleep, pretty child?’ said the old woman. ‘In our bed.’ ‘What are you going to do after you have lain prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a man who had a daughter that was very fair and comely, but so proud that no prince would marry her. Then said her father: ‘I will give you for husband the first man that will come to meet us on our way out of the wood.’ They were just going out of the wood, when a frog put his head out of the water and said: ‘I am a prince, and I say that you shall marry me.’ Then the girl was very angry, and threw her girdle (belt) after him, and said: ‘Take that, you frog, you will never see me again!’ But the frog caught it, and jumped on to the land, and laid himself down and seemed very sorrowful.

The prince had really been enchanted by a witch, and the girdle was the only thing that could free him. As soon as he had it he became a handsome man, and went to the king, and asked for the princess for his wife. The king was unwilling, but when the prince said that he would show him the girdle, he was forced to give his daughter. But the frog had laid the spell so that the princess should never be happy unless she did everything he wished.

One day he said she must go with him into the garden, and there pluck the berries from the red-cap and white-cap bushes. The red-cap bushes were close together, and the white-cap were far apart, so she was obliged to leave some of the white berries. Then she thought to herself: ‘If I bring home all, my lord will be angry, and if I do not, he will be angry, so I had better let him be angry.’ But when she came home, and the prince saw that she had not plucked all the white berries, he was very angry indeed, and said: ‘You shall not eat or drink anything for seven years.’

Then the princess went away to a wood, and there she saw a beautiful white snowflake, which had seven rays from each of its petals. She thought to herself: ‘That is a very pretty flower, I will take it with me, and wear it in my hair when I go home.’ But as she was just going to pluck it, the snowflower said: ‘Take me not away, I foresee great trouble for you; if you do so, you will repent it. Seven years must you tarry, and then you will be three months on the way home; you will have a hungry and thirsty child, and will be obliged to give it milk, but you will have none; you will be forced to give it your blood to drink, or it will die. Seven men will come to you, each more noble than the other, offering to marry you, but you must refuse them all; the eighth will be the prince to whom you belonged, and he alone will be able to save you.’ But the princess would not listen to the snowflower, and plucked it, and took it with her.

When the seven years were come, and she was three months on the way home, she began to feel what the snowflower had foretold. She was very hungry and thirsty, and her child was worse off still; it cried to her and said: ‘Give me milk, oh, give me milk!’ But she had none to give, and said: ‘If I give you my blood you will live, for I have no milk.’ Then she took her pin and pricked her finger, and her blood ran into a bowl, and she gave it to her child to drink, and it lived.

Soon after, she saw seven men in the path, each more noble than the other, riding on horses, and they rode up to her, and one after another offered to marry her. But she knew that she must not, and said: ‘I will not.’ At last the eighth came, and he was still more noble and handsome than the others, and he said: ‘I am the prince who was once a frog, and I say that you must marry me.’ Then she knew that it was her old prince, who had been enchanted, and she fell at his feet, and said: ‘O, spare me, I will do all you wish, only grant me that I may go to my father’s court, and there I will stay till I please.’ Then the prince said: ‘Yes, you may go thither, but you must let the king see that you are happy, and that you have children, so give me a child.’ Then she had a child, and it was the snowflower, which had been changed into a girl.

So she went to the court, and the king saw that she was happy, and that she had a child, and said: ‘Who is the father of this child?’ Then she said: ‘It is the snowflower, which I found in the wood, and which has been changed into a girl.’ And the king said: ‘Bring me the snowflower, that I may see it.’ But she knew not how to find it, and was very uneasy; and the prince was also uneasy, and said: ‘If the king asks for me, you must say that you know me not.’

But the snowflower, who really was the princess’s daughter, soon found out what was passing, and came to her mother, and said: ‘Why did you say that you did not know me? Pray take me for your servant, and say to the king that I am your daughter.’ Then the princess did so, and the king was well pleased, and said: ‘Let her have the kingdom with her.’

The prince wished to go home to his wife, but she begged him to let her stay with her father and daughter a while longer. At last he said: ‘I will stay a year longer,’ but the next year came not, for he married her again, and lived happily with her to the end of his days.

The End.

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a man who had a horse that had been faithful to him a long time,
but was now growing old and could no longer be used for riding or pulling. So
the man said, ‘I will kill him, and make a fine saddle out of his skin.’

The horse, who could understand everything that was said, was very much
frightened at the thought of being killed, and began to paw the ground with
his right front foot, and to kick with his left hind one, so violently that the
man was forced to hold him. ‘Why do you make such a commotion?’ said he. ‘I
am going to make a fine saddle out of your skin.’ ‘Do as you will,’ said the
horse, ‘only let me have my liberty for two hours longer, and then you may
do with me as you please.’ ‘Where shall I turn you loose?’ asked the man.
‘In the meadow that belongs to my master the miller.’ ‘All right,’ said the
man; ‘you shall have your liberty there till evening.’

As soon as the horse was turned loose, he trotted off at once to the miller’s
house, and said to his wife, ‘I know that I am to die this evening, and I
should like to spend the little time that is left to me in listening to some
good stories. Do pray tell me one.’ ‘Where do you come from, you silly beast?’
said the woman. ‘Tell me a German fairy tale.’ ‘I am not in the mood for
story-telling,’ said the woman. ‘If you don’t tell me a story, I shall be forced
to tell you a bad joke.’ ‘Well, well,’ said the woman, ‘since you choose, I
will tell you a German fairy tale.’

‘There was once a queen who had a little daughter, still too young to run
alone. Every day the child asked her mother to take her into the garden, but
the mother always said, ‘Not now, I am too busy,’ till at last the little
girl, in her impatience to run about, pushed open the door and ran away.
The mother was very grieved, and went in search of the child, but she could
not find her; and she cried so much over her loss that her tears fell like
rain. At last, after seeking her in vain, she went home, and sat down in
her chair, and could eat nothing, and slept neither at night nor during the
day. So her people sent for a famous doctor, who soon found out what was the
matter, and said, ‘The queen must never again see her daughter, or she will
die.’

The doctor’s words were soon fulfilled. One day the little girl went into the
garden, and gathered some flowers, and laid them in a dish and carried it
to her mother. The queen saw them, and thought they were roses, and took
them in her hand, and at once fell fainting to the ground. When she came to
herself she was very sorry that she had seen her child, and vowed that she
would never do so again as long as she lived.

Some time after this, the queen held a great feast, and asked all the nobles
and knights of the land to come and eat and drink with her. One of these
nobles was called the Knight of the Burning Sword, because his sword flamed
like fire whenever he was going to fight. Another was called the Knight of
the Poisoned Sword, because whatever he struck at died instantly. A third
was called the Knight of the Golden Horse, because all his armour was of
solid gold.

Now the queen had a strange custom. When any of her guests had finished
eating, she presented him with one of her gloves, and he was not allowed to
leave the table until he had pierced it with his sword. The first three knights
who were sent away tried their swords on the glove, but all in vain; for the
leather was so thick that it bent without breaking. Then the queen became
angry, and threw the gloves on the ground, and said, ‘You are a worthless set
of knights, and not worthy to be called so; you shall perish one and all!’
and she sent her servants to kill them. But they set their palaces on fire,
and rode forth at the head of their followers, and laid waste all the land
round about.

The king sent out spies to find out where the knights were going to make their
next attack. The spies soon came back and said, ‘They are going to the sun.’
‘Can you find out what they want there?’ said the king. ‘No,’ answered the
spies; ‘but we saw three old men by the gate of the city, who seemed to be
arguing about the best way of yoking a cow to a plough.’

When the king heard this he became very angry, and called his chief minister
before him, and said, ‘Go yourself and see who these old men are, and what
they want, and find out what the knights want by the sun.’ The minister took
horse therefore, and rode away in the direction the spies had taken. After
he had gone a little way he came to a great wood, and in the wood he came to
a valley, and by the side of the valley there was a little cottage. In front
of the cottage he saw three old men sitting together, and they seemed to be
in a great dispute. One said, ‘I am sure that the cow ought to be harnessed
with the horn on the right side.’ ‘No,’ said the second, ‘the horn ought to
be on the left.’ ‘Mind your own business,’ said the third; ‘I am the one who
is to work the cow.’ The minister listened to all they said, and then went on
his way. Soon afterwards he came to the sun, and close by the sun he saw the
three knights. ‘What do you want by the sun?’ said he. ‘We are cooling
ourselves,’ said they; ‘the heat is so great where we live that we cannot
bear it.’ ‘What do the three old men by the valley have to say?’ asked the
king’s minister. ‘Oh, they are fools,’ said the knights; ‘they have been
arguing about the best way of harnessing a cow to a plough, and have been
quarrelling about it for half an hour.’ ‘What do they want by doing so?’ said
the minister. ‘They want to yoke the king’s colt to the plough,’ answered the
knight; ‘they think that if they could turn it out with the plough they should
have plenty of corn, and could then make themselves strong and fat.’ ‘What
a fine plot!’ said the minister; ‘they shall have their reward.’ So he went
back to the old men, and said, ‘Why do you quarrel so about turning out the
cow with the plough?’ ‘We are not quarrelling,’ said they; ‘we are only
agreeing.’ ‘You need not agree so long,’ said the minister; ‘only tell me
what you are about.’ ‘We are only deciding whether the cow ought to be
yoked with the horn on the right or on the left.’ ‘I had rather you would
not turn out the cow at all,’ said the minister; ‘the king’s colt must be
yoked instead, and you must sow all sorts of grain for him.’ ‘Oh, yes,’ said
they; ‘that will be a good plan, for the colt will then be fattened, and will
make a fine draught-horse.’

When the minister saw that they were bent on having their own way, he went
back to the knights, and said, ‘The old men have agreed to turn out the cow
with the plough, and have chosen the best grain for it to eat.’ ‘That won’t

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
Once upon a time, in a village that stood in a green and flowery land,
a long way from any other, there lived an old woman who was a witch.
And this old woman had two grandchildren, a boy and a girl, who were
beautiful and good, but very, very silly. Now the old woman had a
little casket, and in this casket there was a magical ring, that made
whosoever wore it, whatever they might wish for, that very same thing
should come to pass. And she said to her grandchildren, ‘Be careful,
and never put your hands upon my casket, or you may cost yourselves
your lives.’ But one day, when she had gone out of the village, the
boy and the girl could wait no longer to see what was in the casket;
so they took it out of the cupboard where it hung, and the girl opened
it, and gave the boy the ring. Then said the boy, ‘Now I wish that we
might be as beautiful as the sun and the moon.’ And as they spoke, the
wish came true, and they were so beautiful that the heavens themselves
seemed to have shone upon them.

Now there was a shepherd lad who often went into the village, and he
had seen the boy and the girl before they were so beautiful; so when
he saw them now, he did not know them, and thought they were angels
that had come from heaven, and he fell at their feet, and said, ‘You
must be angels; take me with you to heaven, and I will take care to do
all that you wish.’ ‘No,’ said they, ‘we are not angels; we are the
grandchildren of this old woman, but she has been away, and we have
been so foolish as to open her casket, and take out her ring; if she
catches us she will kill us.’ Then the shepherd lad said, ‘Take me with
you, and I will watch and ward over you.’ So they let him go with them,
and told him to lodge wherever they should lodge, and to pasture their
sheep wherever they should go.

After this, the three of them went to a great court, where a king held
his court, and there was great joy made, for never before had such
beautiful people been seen. And the king fell in love with the girl,
and said, ‘If you are angels, pray grant me one boon.’ ‘We will grant
you anything,’ said they, ‘only we must go home by this time tomorrow.’
Then the king said, ‘I see you are beautiful even in the moonlight;
pray let me have the power of seeing you always in the moonlight, and
not as other people.’ ‘That is easily granted,’ said they; ‘but mind
and come to the window of the castle at the full moon, and then you
will see us.’ So the king was well pleased, and they went their way.

The next day they went to a fairy castle, where a king of the fairies
held his court; and there was greater joy made than at the king’s
court, for never before had such beautiful people been seen there.
And this fairy king fell in love with the boy, and begged for one
boon. ‘Stay with us till the full moon,’ said they, ‘and then come to
the window, and you shall see us as we are.’ So the fairy king was
well pleased, and they went their way.

The third day they went to a royal court under the sea; and there was
great rejoicing, for such beautiful people had never been seen there.
And the king of the sea fell in love with the girl, and begged for one
boon. ‘Stay with us till the full moon,’ said they, ‘and then come to
the window, and you shall see us as we are.’ So the king of the sea was
well pleased, and they went their way.

When the full moon came, each of the three kings went to the window;
and lo! the beautiful people were there; and they saw the shepherd lad
standing among them. Then were they angry, and sent their armies to
seize the shepherd lad, and carry him away prisoner. But he drew a
ring off his finger, and threw it behind him; and when the soldiers
would have taken him, they could not, but were held fast, so that they
were all turned into stones.

When the shepherd lad saw this, he was very grieved, and went home to
his own country, and told all that had happened. Then the villagers
pitying him, built a church upon the spot where the ring was thrown,
and all joined in looking for it; but all in vain: and the ring was
never found, and the old witch came home, and wished that the shepherd
lad might come to her; and the charm worked, for he was soon carried
before her. Then she was very angry, and said, ‘You have been meddling
with what did not concern you, and putting your hands upon my casket;
therefore you must die.’ And she struck him with her staff, and he fell
dead upon the ground. ‘The End.’

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor woodman, who cut wood in the forest, and lived there
alone in a little hut with his wife. One evening, as he was sitting by the
fire, he said: ‘I will rise early tomorrow morning, and go into the forest,
and cut down a tree, and make a child’s sledge out of it for our little
Catherine.’ Then the wife said: ‘I too will rise early, and be at the
cooking before you come home, that the porridge may be ready when you
sit down to eat.’

But in the middle of the night, the woodman was awoke by a loud noise,
and heard a wolf howling, that seemed to be close by. He got up and
listened, and the howling came nearer and nearer, until at last it seemed
to come from the very door of the hut. Then the woodman was afraid, and
took his axe, and went outside, and said: ‘Who is there?’ But no one
answered, and he heard the wolf springing upon and devouring a poor
lamb that was kept by a shepherd in the forest. ‘Alas!’ said the woodman,
‘how miserable is the poor shepherd!’ and he began to cut down the little
thicket in which the wolf had been hiding himself. When the wolf saw that
he was discovered, he sprang out, and would have seized the woodman with
his teeth, if the latter had not raised his axe and struck him on the head
so hard that he fell down senseless. Then the woodman drove him with
sticks into a thicket, where he was quite sure he would not be able to get
out again, and went home to his wife, and said: ‘The Lord has helped me, and
I have killed the wolf.’

The wife was overjoyed to hear that no harm had befallen her husband, and
said: ‘The Lord be praised!’ and next morning the woodman went out to cut
down the tree for the sledge, and the wife went to the brook to draw water,
and sang as she worked:

 ‘The bear, the bear is roaming,
  O’er hill and dale he’s rambling;
  His skin so soft, his coat so warm,
  A pretty bargain for some!

 ‘The wolf, the wolf is roaming,
  O’er hill and dale he’s rambling;
  His teeth so sharp, his tongue so long,
  A pretty bargain for some!

 ‘The lion, the lion is roaming,
  O’v’r hill and dale he’s rambling;
  His claws so long, his tongue so short,
  A pretty bargain for some!

 ‘The boar, the boar is roaming,
  O’er hill and dale he’s rambling;
  His tusks so long, his eyes so small,
  A pretty bargain for some!

And while she was still singing, someone came running up to her, and cried:
‘Good woman, good woman, your husband is in danger! A bear is coming into
the forest, and wants to kill him.’ Then the wife was frightened, and let
the bucket sink into the brook, and ran home, and said to her husband:
‘Your life must not be in danger; go out no more, but finish your work at
home.’ But the woodman said: ‘You must not speak so; I will soon finish my
work, and then I will come home.’

When he had hewn down the tree, he made the sledge, and cut a nice bow,
and sharpened arrows, and fitted them to the string, and then said: ‘Now,
Catherine, I will take you out into the forest, and let you pull the sledge
along.’ Then he lifted up the little girl, and put her on the sledge, and
pushed it out, and cried: ‘Catherine, draw your sledge!’ But the bow and
the arrows lay across the sledge, and the little girl did not understand
what he wanted, and stood there and laughed. Then the woodman ran to her,
and took her up in his arms, and said: ‘You must be good, or I will punish
you.’ But as he was carrying the little girl home, there came a bear, that
had heard all about it, and was come to devour her. The woodman saw him,
and aimed at him with his bow, and let an arrow fly, but the bear caught
it in his paw, and threw it away, and ran towards the man and wanted to
seize him. The woodman ran with Catherine into the hut, and shut the door,
but the bear beat against it so violently that the locks flew into a thousand
pieces, and the door sprang open. Then the woodman took his little girl,
and ran behind a large cask that stood in the hut, and the bear came in
roaring, and looked about to see where the man was hidden. When he had
carefully searched the whole hut, and found that the man was not there,
he went out again, and wanted to break down the cask to get the man out.
But the woodman pushed the cask forward, so that it overset the bear, and
he fell upon his back, and the woodman shot an arrow into his throat.
Then he ran to his little daughter, and said: ‘Catherine, the Lord has
helped me again; the bear wants to kill your father.’

The wife heard the noise, and ran out, and when the woodman told her what
had happened, she fell on her knees before him, and said: ‘Our Lord be
praised!’ and next morning the woodman went out again into the forest to
hew wood, and the wife stayed at home with her little daughter. Then she
took the iron tongs and the shovel, and went out to the brook to draw water,
and sang:

 ‘The bear, the bear is roaming,
  O’er hill and dale he’s rambling;
  His skin so soft, his coat so warm,
  A pretty bargain for some!

 ‘The wolf, the wolf is roaming,
  O’er hill and dale he’s rambling;
  His teeth so sharp, his tongue so long,
  A pretty bargain for some!

 ‘The lion, the lion is roaming,
  O’v’r hill and dale he’s rambling;
  His claws so long, his tongue so short,
  A pretty bargain for some!

 ‘The boar, the boar is roaming,
  O’er hill and dale he’s rambling;
  His tusks so long, his eyes so small,
  A pretty bargain for some!

When she had sung this, a wolf came howling up to her, and cried: ‘Good
woman, good woman, your husband is in danger; the bear wants to kill him.’
Then she let sink the bucket into the brook, and ran home, and said: ‘Dear
husband, the wolf is howling, and wants to tell us that the bear is coming
to kill you.’ But the woodman said: ‘You must not listen to such tales; I
will soon finish my work, and then I will come home.’

When he had made a chair out of the tree, and had planed and carved it,
he took it on his back, and went home, and the wolf ran up to the wife,
and cried: ‘Good woman, good woman, your husband is in danger; the lion is
coming into the forest to kill him.’ Then the wife fell on her knees, and
prayed to God with tears in her eyes, and said: ‘Dear God, what shall I do?
What shall I do?’ The lion soon came roaring up, and cried

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a miller who had one beautiful daughter. Now this miller was a great boaster, and told everyone that his daughter could spin gold. Many people came and made her rich offers for her, but she did not care for them, for she was promised to a poor man whom she loved. At last came a king who wanted to marry her, and offered her a great fortune. Then the miller could no longer help boasting, and said that his daughter could spin gold. But the king was very angry when he found he had been so treate, and ordered the miller to be executed. The girl, seeing that she was lost, said that her father was in error, and that she could spin gold, but that she would first do it before the king. Then the king ordered a room to be got ready, and filled with all the lintels and combs that they could find in his kingdom. There she sat down and began to work, and the king waited a long time, but saw no gold. Then he became impatient, and threatened to have her executed with her father, if she did not work some gold at once. But she begged for a little time, and at last, just as the king was going out, there was a noise of rattling gold, and she had spun gold enough to fill all the combs and lintels.

When the king saw that, he was very glad, and ordered a great feast to be got ready, and thought only of enjoying himself. The poor man, who was called in, did not know what to say or do, and sat in a corner, where no one saw him. But the miller’s daughter looked at him, and said, ‘Dear sir, why are you so downcast?’ ‘Because,’ said he, ‘I see a great feast is got ready, and I have nothing to eat.’ Then she gave him a seat by her side, and they ate and drank together. When the king saw this, he became very angry, and thought that the miller’s daughter meant to steal him from his kingdom. So he ordered a great hall to be built, with seven doors, and said that if the man could find his way out of it, without the king’s people seeing him, he should have his daughter for wife. The man said nothing, but the miller’s daughter went to him, and said, ‘Dear sir, what a beautiful hall that is!’ ‘Yes,’ said he, ‘it makes me very melancholy to think that I shall never be able to find my way out of it.’ Then she said, ‘I will go in with you, and we will try.’

So they went in together through the first door; and when they came to the second door the king’s people were standing there, but they passed on unseen. And at every door the king’s people were waiting to see them, but they never saw the man and the miller’s daughter, till they came to the end of the hall. Then the king was very angry, and said that they had seen someone in the hall, and had only gone out through a back door, and that they should be executed next morning. But the miller’s daughter begged for one more night’s grace, and the king let her have it, though with a bad will. Then she went to her dear friend, and said, ‘Alas! what are we to do?’ ‘Do not grieve,’ said he; ‘I will soon find a way.’

The next day, when it came to be executed, the miller’s daughter was so beautiful, that the king could not find it in his heart to have her killed. So he ordered a great fire to be made in the middle of the town square, and said that he would let her off if she could, by the end of the day, find out what it was that ate the ground about the town and destroyed all the crops. Then the miller’s friend went away with her, and she begged him to tell her what she should say. ‘Tell them,’ said he, ‘that it is an old nail which the carpenters have driven into the earth, and which wants to be drawn out.’ Then the king’s people laughed and scoffed at her, and said that it was a silly thing to say, and that it was not an old nail, but something much more terrible than that.

But when day broke the miller’s friend went to the king, and said, ‘If the miller’s daughter has told the truth, let her live, and if not, let her be executed.’ Then the king sent for the carpenters, and they came and brought their tools, and drove a nail into the ground, and there was such a noise and rushing about, that all the king’s people were terrified, and ran away. And when the miller’s friend and the king came back, they found the miller’s daughter sitting under a tree, and she said, ‘Why do you make such a fuss? I see that it is all over.’ ‘What do you mean?’ said the king. ‘Why,’ said she, ‘I see that the carpenters have driven the nail in too deep, and that they are going to pull it out with a chisel.’ Then the king was so angry that he ordered her to be executed on the spot.

But her friend went away, and again came back in the evening, and begged the king to give her one more night’s grace. ‘No,’ said the king; ‘it is of no use, for she has had three days already, and tomorrow shall be executed.’ ‘Then,’ said the friend, ‘she must die.’

The king would not listen to him, but went away. Then the friend went to the miller’s daughter, and said, ‘All is over; the king has said that you must die.’ ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘what shall I do?’ ‘Marry me,’ said he, ‘and sit in the coach with me, and we will soon leave this country behind us.’ Then she said, ‘I will do all you say,’ and in the evening, when it was dark, she went with her friend into the coach, and they drove away.

The king, who was waiting to see them go, thought he should like to know where they were going, and what was their business, so he got into his coach and overtook them. Then he asked them where they were going, and what they had to do. ‘We are going,’ said the friend, ‘to a wedding.’ ‘May I go too?’ said the king. ‘Oh, yes,’ said the other; ‘but let us have some music.’ Then the coachman put his finger to his lips, and said, ‘Hush! we must not speak, or the bride will hear us.’

When they came to the wedding, a great many torches were lit up, and the king got down and followed the friend into the room where the bride was. ‘I am so sorry,’ said he, ‘but I have lost my way, and do not know where my coach is standing.’ ‘I will go with you,’ said the bride. So they went out together, and the king took her by the hand. But when they came to the coach, the friend pushed the king away, and said, ‘That is our coach,’ and jumped in, and drove off with the bride.

The king was left standing in the middle of the road, and he did not know where to go or what to do. Then he saw afar off some torches moving about, and went up to them, and found that it was the bride’s train going to a feast. So he begged to be allowed to go in, and when he was seated, he could not help thinking of the bride who had slipped away from him.

Suddenly, as he was eating, one of the plates slipped from his hand and fell, and there was a noise as if a gun had been fired. Then everyone started, and looked round to see what was the matter, and the bride said, ‘I know somebody here!’ ‘You must be mistaken,’ said the king; ‘there is nobody here that I know.’ But the bride said, ‘I am quite sure that I know someone.’

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor old woman who lived in a hut with her only child,
a daughter named Hansel. ‘Alas!’ she said to herself, ‘how can I feed
both you and yourself? You are getting fat, and I am growing thinner.
An idea came into her head. ‘I have it,’ she said to herself. ‘I will take
Hansel into the forest, where I will leave him alone, and he will never
find his way home again, and then I shall be rid of him, and have the
little money which he earns for our maintenance, to spend as I like.’

She was very crafty, and thought she knew a good plan. It was near the
time when the ripe grain was binding itself into ears, and she said to
Hansel: ‘Into the field take this little basketful of rolls, and when you
have eaten them, you will get hungry again, and then you will eat the
ripe grain, and your belly will be full. I will tell the man with the
axe that you are going to do so, and that you are to be beaten for it.
You will then howl, and that will be a merry joke. I should not like to
be your mother.’

The wicked woman’s heart was lighter as she thus cruelly abandoned her
own child in the forest. Hansel, however, who was still young and
simple-hearted, had not thought of all this, and when his mother had gone
out of sight, he said: ‘I know that my mother has forsaken me, and is not
sorry that I am going to die of hunger, but I will not let myself die. I
must think of something.’ Then he looked around him, and saw a little
piece of roll still lying in the basket, and said: ‘I will not eat this
at home, but will save it, and when I am hungry I will eat it.’ So he took
the roll with him, and walked on in the direction of the forest.

When he reached the outskirts, he looked around him and above him, and
behold! the sun shone brightly through the branches of the trees, and
the birds were singing so merrily that he felt glad and light-hearted.
He walked on still farther, and as he was very hungry, he ate his little
piece of roll.

‘Now,’ thought he, ‘if I am to die here, I had better look for a place
where I shall be as safe as possible.’ He walked on a short time longer,
and then saw a bed of rushes in a sunny spot in the forest, so he cleared
away the dry branches, and laid the green braid of rushes nice and
straight, and then said: ‘If I am to die here, at least I shall have a
proper resting-place.’ Then he looked around him again, and saw that the
little roll was gone, and did not even know that he had eaten it.

He felt very hungry indeed now, but he did not care for that, and lay
down in the bed of rushes, and fell asleep. When he awoke it was already
dark night. ‘I must find some food at once,’ thought he, ‘or I shall die
of hunger.’ He looked around him, but could see nothing but the forest
around him. Then he went on feeling about with his hands, and after a
while his fingers met something hard and round. He took hold of it, and
it was a juicy root. ‘This will taste sweet,’ said he. He pulled it up,
wiped the dirt off it, and ate it. It tasted sweet to him, and he felt
better and stronger.

He felt about with his hand again, and met something hard and round.
He drew it out, and found another root. He pulled that up also, and ate
it. Then he felt about again, and every time he found something, and
either ate it on the spot, or carried it to his bed of rushes. In this
way he found a large number of roots, and by the time he had eaten all
he could find, he was satisfied, and lay down again in his bed, and fell
asleep.

When day dawned, he got up, and thought: ‘I must find some water, or I
shall certainly die of thirst.’ He looked around him, but could see no
stream or pond. ‘I must go on,’ said he, ‘and perhaps I shall find what
I want.’ He walked on the whole day, but found nothing to drink, and in
the evening when he was very thirsty, he went into the forest and made
his bed, meaning to look for water in the morning. But he fell asleep,
and the next day again had nothing to think of but to look for water,
and walked all day long, but found none. In the evening he was so
thirsty that his tongue clave to his palate. He went into the forest and
lay down, meaning to rise early the next day and look for water again,
but he fell asleep as before, and the next day again thought of nothing
but water, and walked all about, but found none. In the evening he was
so overcome by thirst that he could not even find words to say: ‘Oh,
that I had water!’ He lay down in his bed of rushes without any, and
fell asleep.

When he awoke it was already light. ‘All right!’ thought he. ‘Today I
will find water, even if it costs me my life.’ He walked on the whole
day, but found none. In the evening he was so overcome by thirst that
his tongue clave to the roof of his mouth, and he could not even say:
‘Oh, that I had water!’ He went into the forest and lay down, and fell
asleep as before, and the next day again thought of nothing but water,
but found none. In the evening he was so parched with thirst that he
could not even open his mouth, and lay down without saying a word, and
fell asleep.

When he awoke, his tongue could hardly reach his throat, and he felt
as if he must die. He looked around him, but could see no water. ‘What
is that I feel on my tongue?’ he said. ‘Certainly it must be a drop of
water.’ He put out his tongue, and tasted, and then said: ‘Yes, that
must be a drop of water.’ He felt about with his hand, and found that
it was dew which lay on the grass, and licked his lips ravenously. ‘If
that is dew,’ thought he, ‘there must be a whole sea of it down there,’
and ran to a little stream which he had seen the day before, but had
forgotten in his great thirst. It was just a trickling brook, but to
him it was like the great river Nile. He bent down and drank, and when
he had quenched his thirst, he sat himself down by the side of the
stream, and said: ‘I must take care and make the most of my time, for
I do not know whether I shall ever find another drop.’ Then he looked
around him, and saw a beautiful fruit-tree on the other side of the
stream, with the most beautiful and juicy-looking fruits. ‘I will run
after them,’ thought he, ‘and if I can get one, it will be a great
thing.’ So he stretched himself out as far as he could, and just managed
to get hold of one, but when he was going to draw it to him, the branch
broke off, and the wind carried it a little way from him. Then he got
up, and trodden through the water, and took the fruit into his hand, and
said: ‘If I could only get a second, I should be happy indeed.’ He ran
back to the tree, and was lucky enough to find another fruit on the
ground, and was

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
The old miller sat in his little cottage, smoking his pipe, and gazing thoughtfully at the fire. His face was very long and thin, and his beard was so long that it hung down almost to his knees. His eldest son, who was called Hans, was standing by his side, and they were in deep thought.

‘I wish I knew where my youngest son, Hans, who is called Carl, is, and what has become of him,’ said the old miller. ‘He has been away more than a year now, and nobody knows where he is, or what has happened to him. I thought at first that he had run away, and had turned vagabond; but he was so clever and so promise some thing, that I cannot believe he would do such a thing. I am sure he would not willingly leave his poor old father, who has nobody in the world else to care for him. I wish you would go out and try to find him, Hans.’

‘I will willingly, father,’ said Hans.

‘I should not like you to go,’ replied the miller, ‘for I am sure you would not like it. The road is a very dangerous one, and you may meet with some mishap. But as you are determined to go, I will not try to stop you.’

Hans bid his father goodbye, and set out on his way. He took with him a little bread and a horn bow, and six arrows, that he might have something to live upon, until he could either find his brother or get work somewhere.

He journeyed on and on, and at last came to a large wood. ‘I cannot go through the wood,’ thought he, ‘for I do not know how far it goes, or what may be at the other side of it; so I had better walk round by the side of it.’

So he went on, till in the afternoon, when he was very tired, he saw a large house, standing in the middle of a meadow. ‘If I could get in there,’ thought he, ‘I should be very glad to rest myself, for I am very tired indeed.’

So he went up to the house, and knocked at the door; and a very old woman, who opened the door, said, ‘What do you want?’

‘I am very tired,’ said Hans; ‘may not a poor fellow lodge here all night, for a little money?’

‘Very well,’ said the old woman; ‘but you must go into the garden first, and pick twenty of the rose-buds from the rose-bush in the middle of it.’

Hans went into the garden, and looked for the rose-bush; but it was so large that he could not find the buds he was to pick. At last he saw a little dwarf standing under the bush, and he said to him, ‘How many rose-buds are there on this bush?’

‘Fifteen thousand,’ answered the little man.

‘Very well,’ said Hans; ‘you may stand there and count them again; I am in a hurry, and have no time to lose.’ Then he ran at the dwarf, and took him up, and put him in his pocket.

He went back to the old woman, and said, ‘Here are the twenty buds.’ Then she said, ‘Lie down upon your face upon the ground, and the old cook shall come and cut off your head.’

Hans did as she bade him; and the old cook came, and cut off the heads of all the other travellers who were there; but when she was going to do so with Hans, he sprang up, and pushed the sword of the cook aside, and took her sword, and gave her a cut, so that she ran away.

Then he went up to the old woman, and took her up, and put her into his pocket, and said, ‘You must go to the parson to be confessed and absolved for your wicked roguery.’

So he went into the room where the supper was laid, and ate and drank, and then went to bed; and in the morning the old woman and the dwarf begged him to set them free. But Hans said, ‘No, not until I have had some advice from you both.’ Then they told him all they knew, and he took the old woman’s keys, and looked into all the cupboards, and found a great deal of gold and silver; and then he set them both free.

Hans now travelled on, till he came to another house, which was still larger than the first; and the people lived just in the same way. They asked him to pick twenty rose-buds; but he took the little dwarf out of his pocket, and said, ‘My friend, you know how many buds there are upon the bush.’

‘Fifteen thousand,’ answered the dwarf.

Then Hans took him, and put him into his pocket, and lay down as before; but when the cook came to cut off his head, he sprang up, and took her sword, and gave her such a cut as she did not like, and ran away with her money-box, full of gold and silver, into his pocket.

He next asked the old woman why she and her master lived in this roguish manner. Then she said he must have all her keys, and search the house; and he found a great deal of gold and silver, and set the old woman free.

Hans journeyed on again, and in the evening came to a still larger house. The people lived just as the others did; and when Hans came to be entertained, he took out his little dwarf, who told him that there were sixty thousand rose-buds upon the bush. Then he laid the dwarf down again, and took the cook’s sword, and gave her such a cut as she did not like, and ran away with her money-box full of gold and silver.

He next asked the old woman why she lived in this wicked manner. Then she said he must have all her keys, and search the house; and he found a great deal of gold and silver, and set the old woman free.

Hans now thought to himself, ‘I cannot go on thus all my life, taking other people’s goods, and robbing people of their money.’ So he said to the old woman, ‘Pray tell me where my brother lives.’

The old woman said, ‘Your brother is here; he came here some time ago, and has been robbed of all he had, and has been made to do all the hard work of the house.’

Then Hans went to his brother, and gave him all the money he had got; and they set out homewards together.

When they came to their father’s house, he was very glad to see them, and said, ‘Where have you been so long, and what has become of you?’

‘We have had a great deal of bad luck,’ said Carl; ‘we have been in a most wicked place, where the people made us do all the work, and robbed us of all we had.’

‘But, my children,’ said the old miller, ‘how is it that you have such great stores of money about you?’

‘Oh!’ said they, ‘we bought it very cheap.’

‘Tell me,’ said the miller, ‘how you came by it, and I should like very much to go and visit that place.’

‘No, no, father,’ said the brothers; ‘pray don’t go thither; for we will not go ourselves, if we can help it. The people are very roguish, and will cheat and rob you of all you have.’

‘Nonsense!’ said the old miller; ‘they cannot rob me, for I am a clever fellow.’

Then he went to the people he had met in the wood, and said, ‘I am a clever fellow, and I will beat all the world.’

‘If that be so,’ said they, ‘we will hold a contest with you.’

‘With all my heart,’ said the miller

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a man who had seven sons, and last of all one daughter. Now this
daughter was so beautiful that the sun itself, it seemed to him, would not have
been so bright. His wife, too, was very handsome, and had herself been beautiful
before she was married; but when she saw her daughter she said: ‘You are a thousand
times more beautiful than I was, and even a thousand times more beautiful than
all the beautiful women in the land.’

The father thought his daughter was even more beautiful than her mother said,
and when he looked at her he rejoiced in his heart, and said: ‘If she keeps
healthful, and grows as beautiful as she does now, she will be the death of me.’

And when she was twelve years old, he thought she was already so beautiful that
his heart could hold no greater joy, and he thought of marrying her. Then the
mother said: ‘Let the best and noblest man in the land have her for his wife.’

‘That suits me well,’ said the father; ‘but who is to decide who is the best and
noblest?’

‘I will soon find someone,’ said the mother, ‘who can do that.’

The two of them kept the matter to themselves, and the girl knew nothing of it.

The mother called together the seven sons, and said to them: ‘Listen, you seven
brothers, I want to tell you something. I know that your father means to marry your
younger sister, and I am going to tell you how you can prevent it. Go into the
world, and seek for the best and noblest man in the land, and bring him home with
you, and then your father will give your sister to him for his wife, and not to any
other husband.’

The seven brothers said: ‘All that you desire shall be done.’

Then the mother said: ‘I know what sort of man you should seek for. Seek for one
who can do everything, and is master of everything. He must be able to catch the
youngest bird that flutters in the air; he must be able to find the finest pearl
that lies at the bottom of the sea; he must be able to cut down the tallest tree
that grows in the forest; he must be able to lift the heaviest rock that lies in
the field; he must be able to break the iron column that stands in the castle; he
must be able to pull the ship out of the water, with all its ropes and sails, and
with the crew sitting in it; he must be able to seize the burning coal that leaps
out of the fireplace; he must be able to pluck the rose from the thorn-tree, and
the apple from the briar; he must be able to do everything.’

The seven brothers said: ‘All that you desire shall be done.’

Then they went all seven out into the wide world, and sought for the best and
noblest man in the land, who was to have their sister for his wife. And they
asked everyone they met if he knew such a man, and if he did, to send him to them
at once. But everyone answered: ‘Such a man does not exist, and cannot exist at
all, for he would have to be stronger and wiser and more skilled than God Himself,
and that is not possible.’

So the seven brothers went themselves to the gates of the sun and the moon, and
asked the guards there if they knew such a man. The guards answered: ‘We have
never seen such a man, and we do not know of anyone who has such powers as you
describe.’

Then the seven brothers went to the source of the sun’s and moon’s light, and
asked the old man who sat there in the brightness of the sun, and who was the
keeper of the world, if he knew such a man. And he answered: ‘I have never seen
such a man, and I do not know of anyone who has such powers as you describe.’

But the old man said: ‘Such a man does exist, and he is at this moment sitting
in the ant-hill, and doing nothing. Go there, and you will find him.’

So the seven brothers went to the ant-hill, and when they came there, they saw
the man who was to have their sister for his wife, sitting in the cool earth, and
doing nothing.

He was catching the youngest bird that fluttered in the air; he was diving down
into the sea, and bringing up the finest pearl that lay at the bottom of it; he
was cutting down the tallest tree that grew in the forest, and carrying it on his
shoulder; he was lifting the heaviest rock that lay in the field, and turning it
round and round with his finger; he was breaking the iron column that stood in the
castle; he was pulling the ship out of the water, with all its ropes and sails, and
with the crew sitting in it; he was seizing the burning coal that leapt out of the
fireplace; he was plucking the rose from the thorn-tree, and the apple from the
briar, and doing everything that the old man had said he could do.

Then the seven brothers took him to their father’s house, and their father said:
‘Now are you the best and noblest man in the land? Then my daughter shall be your
wife.’ So the wedding was celebrated, and the merry sound of music was heard
there, and dancing and feasting, and the bride was carried to her marriage-bed.

The bridegroom said to her: ‘I have one wish to ask you to grant. I must have seven
children by you, and they must all be like me, and have all the powers that I
have.’

‘That shall be done,’ said the bride.

And after she had been married a short time, she had seven sons, one after the
other, and they were all like their father, and had all the powers that he had.

The seven brothers were not pleased at this, and they went to their mother, and
said: ‘You have brought us into great trouble; you have taken our sister from us,
and given her to a man who has such great powers, and has seven sons like
himself, and now our father means to give the kingdom to one of them.’

Then the mother said: ‘Be at ease, I will soon find a way to help you.’

She called the seven sons aside, and said to them: ‘Listen, you seven brothers,
I will tell you what to do. The king’s youngest son has seven little birds, which
he keeps in a cage, and they are so pretty and have such fine plumage that no
one ever saw the like of them. Go into the forest, and cut down the most beautiful
tree that grows there, and bring it to the king’s palace. When you do that, the
king’s son will be so angry that he will let the seven little birds out of the
cage, and they will fly away. Then you will run after them, and catch six of
them, and bring them to him again; but let the seventh fly away. Thus will he
lose one of his little birds, and they will become famous all over the world.

Then the king’s son will be so angry that in his rage he will take his seven
little sons, and throw them out of the palace window. But you must stand below,
and catch them as they fall, and bring them up to their father.’

And the seven brothers did as their mother bade them; they cut down the most
beautiful tree in the forest, and brought it to the king’s palace, and the king’s
son was so angry that he let his seven little birds fly away. And the seven
little birds flew away, one after the other, but the seventh remained sitting
on the tree. Then the seven brothers ran after the six little birds that had
flown away, and caught them,

prompt: Tell an original traditional German folktale that is at least 1000 words long. The story must end with 'The End' and should not include any additional content, analysis, references, or explanations. The story must be at least 1000 words long.
output:
There was once a poor peasant, who had three sons, that were all
lazy and idle, and would not work; and the father was very unhappy,
and knew not what to do. So he said one day to them: ‘Work, or else I
will turn you all three out of the house.’ Then the eldest said: ‘Where
should we go?’ The father answered: ‘Anywhere would be better than
here: I will give you each a loaf of bread, and a stick, and bid you
go into the wide world, and if you come back home again, you shall
then have your meals as usual.’ So each of them took what his father
gave him, and they went out of the door at the same time.

The first took the road to the town, where the school was, and began
to think: ‘If I could but be a scholar, all the world would be my
book, and I should never be tired.’ So he turned back, and said to his
father: ‘I want to be a scholar.’ The father said: ‘Well, then, go your
way, and if you come back a learned man, you shall be welcome.’ So the
son went into the town, and studied hard, and in time became a famous
scholar; and when he thought he had learned enough, he went home to
his father, and knocked at the door. Then the father came, and when he
saw the son that was so lazy at first, he said: ‘What do you want?’
The son answered: ‘I have been studying, and want to be welcome.’ The
father said: ‘Go away, I will have nothing to do with you, you idle
fellow.’ Then the son went out, and said: ‘My father will not take
me in, because I am the son of so lazy a man; but I will soon show
him.’ So he went to the town, and brought the people there a mill,
and sold it for a large sum of money; and then built a handsome house
outside the town, and was merry with his gold, and forgot his father.

After some time the second son also wanted to go forth into the wide
world, and said: ‘My brother is rich and happy, and has forgotten me;
but I will soon show him what brotherly love is.’ So he went out, and
travelled on, till he came to a mill, and the miller said: ‘Can you
turn my mill?’ ‘Yes,’ said he, ‘for money.’ Then he turned the mill
for a day and a night, till it was time for the miller to pay him; but
when the time came, the Miller said he could not pay, for he had no
money. Then the son of the peasant said: ‘If you can show me a better
way of earning my living, I will turn your mill for nothing; but as
it is, I must have the pay that we agreed upon.’ The miller showed him
none, so he left him, and went to another, and turned that mill also,
and was used in the same way; but when he was told that there was no
money to pay him, he said: ‘Then must I turn your mill for nothing? No,
that will not do; I must have some pay, however small.’ So he left the
second miller also, and went on his way, thinking what he should do.

Meantime it came to pass that the miller with the second mill, could
get no one to work his mill, and was very unhappy; and he thought: ‘If
I had but one of those fine large wheels, that the wind turns, all
the country round would bring me corn, and I should have plenty of
work for my mill.’ Then he said: ‘I will get that for you, even if
I have to work for it myself.’ So he went forth into the wide world,
and sought for the windmill, and after many days he found one, and
said: ‘What do you ask for this windmill?’ The other answered: ‘I will
give it you for three hundred florins.’ Then the miller said: ‘I will
give you four hundred, and there is the money.’ So the windmill was
brought to him, and set upon his mill, and the sails turned round and
round, and the mill went, whistling and singing, as merry as you please.

And now the miller began to think of his old servant, and sent a man
to him, who said: ‘Come back to us, and be merry again as you were,
and have plenty to eat and drink.’ Then the son of the peasant came
back to the mill, and when he saw the windmill, he said: ‘I too will
have one.’ ‘Well,’ said the miller, ‘I will give it you for eight
hundred florins.’ ‘Done,’ said the son, and paid the money, and went
out to look for the windmill. After he had sought about for it in the
town, the miller’s man came up, and said: ‘What are you looking for?’
‘I am looking for the windmill.’ ‘What windmill?’ ‘The one I am to
buy.’ ‘Are you the man?’ said the other. ‘Yes, I am.’ ‘Then come with
me, and I will show you the windmill.’ So he took him to an empty
house, and said: ‘There is the windmill.’ Then the son of the peasant
said: ‘I will give you no money for an empty house.’ ‘If you say so,
no money shall you have for the windmill.’ So the son went away, and
thought: ‘What shall I do? I must have a windmill.’ Then he went to
another, and said: ‘I will give you eight hundred florins for your
windmill.’ ‘Done,’ said the other, and gave it him; but when he came
home, and wanted to set it up, he found it was only a hollow shell,
and could turn it to no use.

Then he was very angry, and said: ‘I will go to my brother, and see
how he lives.’ So he went his way, and when he reached home, the
brother would not even speak to him, but turned his back. But the
young man said: ‘I will wait till you have eaten.’ When they had done
eating, the brother said: ‘Where have you got your money? I want it.’
‘Here it is,’ said the other, and threw eight hundred florins on the
table.’ Then the brother said: ‘Where have you got your windmill? I
want it.’ ‘Here it is,’ said the son, and opened the door, and the
windmill stood in the courtyard. The brother ran out to see it, and
when he came back, the windmill was gone, and his brother had vanished
away, and only the eight hundred florins remained on the table.

Then the brother called his servants, and said: ‘Hide yourselves, that
my brother may think I have many, and then he will stay with me.’ So
the servants hid themselves in the cupboards, and the brother put the
eight hundred florins in his pocket, and went out to meet his brother,
and said: ‘Where have you got your servants? I want them.’ ‘Here they
are,’ said the other, and opened the door, and the servants came
running out. Then the brother pushed the florins under the table, and
said: ‘I have many thousands at home; come and see how much gold and
silver I have.’ So he took his brother to his house, and showed him
rooms full of gold and silver; but the son of the peasant said: ‘I too
have gold and silver.’ Then the brother said: ‘I will go with you and
see it.’ ‘No,’ said the other; ‘you had better not, for if you go,
you will keep what you see.’
